—My question is directed to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy. Can the Minister inform the House of the measures that will be taken to assist individual wheat growers?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Kerin The Hon J.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —Consideration of assistance to the Australian wheat industry, as honourable members well understand, has arisen because Australia's wheat growers are experiencing substantially lower prices for their production, and this is a consequence of record world production last year-a very big harvest-and the aggressive use of production and export subsidies by the United States and the European Community. The EC subsidies now are anything up to $US140 or $US160 and US subsidies are about $50 or anything up to $70 in some markets. This has had an enormous impact on the wheat industry.

ANSWER.PARA: In considering assistance, the Government is mindful of the impact the downturn is having on a number of growers and on the rural communities which service our rural industries, particularly in the light of the current downturn in the wool industry. This last weekend I was in the wheat growing districts of Western Australia and witnessed the level of concern in the industry. The Government has decided to introduce measures which will enable the Australian Wheat Board to extend its borrowings to allow for the lifting of payments to growers, and further payments to growers will be possible at a time when decisions are being taken on next season's plantings. I would expect the Wheat Board to make a further announcement of post-harvest payments to growers shortly.

In addition, Cabinet has foreshadowed a boost in funding of the rural adjustment scheme (RAS) to cover carry-on finance for farmers. As honourable members are aware, the rural adjustment scheme provides the most effective means of targeting assistance to those most in need. Even under prevailing prices, some growers will have no cause to seek assistance from the Government, but what the Government intends does overcome a major deficiency of blanket support measures.

The extent of further funding of the rural adjustment scheme will be decided once an assessment of the RAS scheme has been completed. On the question of further cover for the Australian Wheat Board's outstanding debts from past sales to Iraq, it has been decided that the existing arrangements adequately share the burden of sanctions.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Reith Mr P.K.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Treasurer to a statement yesterday by Senator Button who, when asked whether he agreed with the Leader of the Opposition's forecast of a rolling recession, said:

QUESTION.PARA: Yes, I think there is that possibility as sectors of the economy pick up and others go down.
Does the Treasurer agree with Senator Button about the prospect of a rolling recession? On economic matters, who now speaks with authority on behalf of the Government?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Keating The Hon P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is me; and I do not agree. The fact is that it is often the case, as it was in the period of high growth, that some sectors are down and some sectors are up. This is pretty much a normal condition of most economies, including this economy. It is also true that some sectors are doing better than others at the moment. In the December quarter balance of payments figures which came out the other day, we had nearly two percentage points of net exports in the quarter; so there is production occurring. Of course, as the economy comes out of recession-and I believe it will-no doubt some sectors will be stronger than others.

ANSWER.PARA: The gloomy view put by the Leader of the Opposition that there should be a permanent rolling recession-this Jeremiah proposition that there is no hope for Australia which the Leader of the Opposition is putting all the time and bathing in its misfortunes-is a vicious view which does reflect the capacity of the economy to withstand a cyclical change, to recover from it and to come out of it with gross domestic product and employment growing, notwithstanding the fact that some sectors may not do as well as others.

ANSWER.PARA: Graph 5 on page 4 shows a very sharp pick-up in the terms of trade which has obviously amplified the imports which have come into Australia and which have now been again stemmed by Government policy. It reveals the obvious point that had the terms of trade not picked up in 1987-88 we would be running a very strong balance of trade surplus and would probably have the debt near the stabilisation point.

TALK.START.PARA: —We have just heard a rumbling from the dead centre of the Parliament, from where no noise or views come. We all know where the dead centre of the Parliament is. It is not in the middle of the table; it is over there.

ANSWER.PARA: The fact is that had that surge of income worth about $15 billion per year in each of those years not occurred, which this release by the Statistician very graphically shows, it is obviously clear we would now be running a huge balance of trade surplus, as the Government had set the economy up for the low terms of trade of 1986 in the election of 1987.

Nevertheless, what this shows is that we have again crimped import growth and brought it back under control with monetary and fiscal policy and, notwithstanding that, there has been that very strong growth in exports in constant prices which is shown here. Of course, in constant prices it is an extraordinary growth-a very strong growth. In other words, what is there is what the coalition was incapable of doing-restarting exports, restarting investment and trying to deal with the structural weakness. If one looks at the chart on page 3, it shows that the huge structural weakness-the huge structural trade gap-which was there under Treasurer Howard--

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Snow Mr J.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask the Minister for Transport and Communications whether he has seen an article by Alan Wood, which appeared in the Weekend Australian, wherein he discusses the requirements for a third runway at Sydney (Kingsford-Smith) Airport. He says:

QUESTION.PARA: It is no answer for the Prime Minister to claim that he is waiting for the completion of the environmental assessment process when this can be clearly seen for what it is, an excuse for procrastination.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Beazley The Hon K.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable member for Eden-Monaro for his question. I did see the comments that were made in Alan Wood's column. His assessment is completely incorrect. As far as this Government is concerned, subject to the environmental impact statement (EIS), we regard the third runway at Sydney as essential.

ANSWER.PARA: It is not just an alibi that that environmental statement is an absolutely essential part of the legislative concern. There is a requirement for an environmental impact statement to identify the full range of environmental impacts associated with major infrastructure developments such as the third runway. The EIS process will identify proper management measures that are necessary to mitigate the environmental impacts of the third runway development, if it is to proceed. The draft EIS was released last September and followed a three-month review period.

The Federal Airports Corporation (FAC) is now addressing issues raised in the public submissions. It is absolutely essential that the commentators on our political system comprehend the nature of the legislation that binds Ministers to act in a particular way. In circumstances such as this, where the controversy is enormous, if we fail to act in accordance with the legislative requirements on us, there will simply be challenges in Federal courts which will hold up the processes even more than the environmental impact statement procedure.

The Government is determined to build the third runway at Sydney airport subject to the successful completion of the EIS process. As an earnest of our good faith in that regard, the FAC has already commenced preliminary work on conceptual design and investigations for site reclamation for the third runway. Also, the FAC will shortly be letting a contract for design work associated with drainage and road works.

All that leads to this point: provided that those environmental impact statements come out right for the project to proceed, the third runway will go ahead and our seeking of contracts to implement such a decision will go ahead immediately that clearance is given.

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy. Could the Minister explain to the House what the benefits to Australian wheat growers would be if the wheat trade to South Africa resumed at historical levels? Would these benefits exceed the benefits resulting from the reduction in the export enhancement program?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Kerin The Hon J.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The honourable member for Page asks a question that reflects on some of the statements by the Leader of the National Party, and he is wrong in assuming that trade with South Africa is not continuing. Let me give some details to the House on the nature of the wheat trade to South Africa. Since 1979-80 Australia has exported a total of 525,000 tonnes of wheat to South Africa. The situation is that South Africa is normally self-sufficient in wheat; it mainly buys during a drought. Last December the Government confirmed to the Australian Wheat Board that it could tender, and that tender was successful.

ANSWER.PARA: Australia produces about 14 million tonnes of wheat a year on average. South African production is about 2.2 million tonnes. It is not a major producer of wheat and its imports have averaged, since approximately 1980, 93,000 tonnes. That is equivalent to the production of about 67 farms in Western Australia.

I am aware of some of the comments made by the impetuous Leader of the National Party, who believes all the work done by the current trade mission led by the Minister for Trade and Overseas Development will be to no avail and, as a consequence, wheat trade with South Africa should be resumed. This is really a big bit of nonsense.

In fact, he was quoted as saying that he is `bitterly disappointed with the outcome' of that trip. He would have had a very good point if he had been backed up either by the opinion of his party or by the facts, because the Deputy Leader of the National Party, the Opposition spokesman for primary industries, who is now travelling with the Minister, said:
. . . in very difficult circumstances, I believe we have achieved the best that was achievable . . . .
. . . I do want to commend Dr. Blewett, the leader of the delegation for the work he has done, the leadership he has given, and what has been achieved . . . .

Let me make this clear to the House, instead of this nonsense we hear from the Leader of the National Party: the real grains for Australian producers are to be won by working solidly on the substantive issues of trade liberalisation and access to market. That is what the Government is doing right now. It is slow, unspectacular stuff, but it has to be done.

One thing is clear enough: contrary to what the Leader of the National Party thinks, South Africa does not exist as some type of wheat El Dorado. If it did, the fact that Australia has no restriction on the sale of wheat to South Africa would be reflected in massively increased expected returns to Australian growers.

May I take this opportunity just to add to an answer to a question earlier on the wheat industry, in which I failed to point out that the Cabinet is still looking at the question of identifying losses specifically associated with Australia's compliance with the United Nations trade sanctions on Iraq.

—I address my question to the Treasurer. Is the Treasurer aware of reports that monetary policy in Australia was tightened in 1988 behind other countries? Is he also aware of reports that the Treasury had formally advised the Government to tighten monetary policy earlier? Can he inform the House whether there is any substance to the reports? What are the Government's intentions in relation to these reports?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Keating The Hon P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The intention is to put the reports right. The report emanated from a document published by the Leader of the Opposition over the weekend. He had this to say:

ANSWER.PARA: Even as the major industrial countries overseas were gradually re-tightening monetary policy in early 1988, Australian cash rates remained flat, notwithstanding advice from Treasury on the need to act.
But for reasons known only to Messrs Hawke and Keating, significant tightening was left to late May-June 1988, coincidentally after the New South Wales elections lost by the Unsworth Government.
That is untrue. Budget Paper No. 1 of 1989-90, on page 2.8, says:
The progressive tightening of monetary policy commencing April 1988 . . .
It was not May-June 1988. It also says on page 2.6:

The United States monetary authorities began to increase short-term rates in May 1988 . . . Increases were recorded in many other OECD countries-generally a little later than in the United States-notably the United Kingdom . . .

The United States moved in May 1988, the United Kingdom moved in June-July 1988, and we moved earlier than both of them-in April 1988. So the whole claim is untrue. As to the advice from the Treasury, the Treasury never advised me to tighten monetary policy early in 1988 because it shared a view with the Reserve Bank of Australia at the time-a view shared by the Bank of International Settlements-that monetary conditions post the stock market crash should be left accommodating otherwise there would be large wealth effects from large corporate collapses a la 1930. That was the prevailing view; it was not a view I agreed with.

I actually argued against the Treasury and the Reserve Bank to increase interest rates in January 1988 and again formally in March 1988-that is, before the elections. The fact is that this claim has no veracity about it whatsoever. There was a fallout from the stock market crash and there was, in all of the Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development countries, a more accommodating monetary policy because of the wealth effects which were feared might be larger than those following the stock market crash in 1929. At the time, nobody believed that demand would take off, but as soon as demand looked like taking off I was putting a view that rates should rise. As it is, they rose first in April 1988. So there was a stock market crash fallout, but it occurred two years later, in 1990, as the demand arising from that monetary accommodation went through the Western world. So the whole charge here, this mealy-mouthed charge, is entirely incorrect.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Defence. What work has been completed to date on the submarine project? Is the project on schedule and within budget? How many jobs have been created and what is the project's potential for technology transfer?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Bilney The Hon G.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I know of only one person who takes a greater interest in the submarine project than the present honourable member for Port Adelaide, and that is the former honourable member for Port Adelaide. I am very pleased to be able to tell the House that the new submarine project, which involves the design and structure of six Collins class submarines for the Royal Australian Navy, is progressing extremely well. The construction facility is complete and fully operational. The keel of the first submarine, Collins, was laid in February last year, and the keel of the second submarine, Farncomb, was laid in the presence of the Prime Minister just last week.

ANSWER.PARA: The design of the submarine is well advanced, and the fitting out of the platforms for the first submarine has already commenced. The production of the combat system is also well advanced, and preliminary software testing of the combat system data package has started. The project remains within budget and on schedule for the first submarine to be delivered in January 1995. The estimated total cost of the project is $4,620m at April 1990 prices.

The contract with the Australian Submarine Corporation specifies that work amounting to about $1,951m at June 1986 prices be placed with Australian industry. Ninety-nine per cent of that work has now been committed, and about 65 Australian companies are involved in the project. The Australian Submarine Corporation employs directly over 550 people, and that figure is expected to increase to around 800 as construction peaks. A total of about 2,000 new jobs have been created as a result of the submarine project.

The honourable member asked about the spin-off effects of the transfer of technology. I am very pleased to be able to cite a very significant example of one spin-off to Australian industry and employment in Port Adelaide, and that is the establishment of a facility to construct submarine batteries across the road from the other plant. Pacific Marine Batteries, which is a joint venture company formed by Pacific Dunlop Ltd of Australia and Varta Batterie of Germany, will transfer to Australia the full range of technologies and allied skills needed to make these extremely heavy duty batteries in Australia. From talking to the management, I am certain that it is pursuing both the domestic and the export market for other heavy duty batteries.

The formation of Pacific Marine Batteries and the associated investment in South Australia is a good example of the benefits which flow to Australia from the Government's decision to construct the new submarines here rather than overseas. It is indicative of the confidence that major overseas companies have in South Australia.

Perhaps I should conclude by mentioning one statistic. I know that it is difficult to attract the Opposition's attention to good news, but five or six years ago, of the $2.5 billion spent on capital equipment by the Department of Defence, about 75 per cent was spent overseas and 25 per cent spent in Australia. This year those figures are precisely reversed: three-quarters of our expenditure will be spent in Australia and only one-quarter spent overseas.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: JERVIS BAY: POSSIBLE NUCLEAR POWER STATION

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy. Has the Minister seen reports in the Illawarra Mercury and other papers about the possibility of building a nuclear power station at Jervis Bay? Can the Minister inform the House if there are any such plans?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Kerin The Hon J.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes, I can tell the honourable member for Throsby that I have seen the reports in the Illawarra Mercury attributed to the Illawarra electricity chairman.
—Which report?

—The report by the chairman, Mr Bland. Have you not read it? It is about a possible nuclear power station at Jervis Bay. I can confirm that the Government has absolutely no plans for the construction of a nuclear power station in Australia. This is really just a straight-out, beat-up story, following the recent release of the Industry Commission draft report on energy distribution and generation on which, I might add, no government decision has been taken. DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Discussion of Matter of Public Importance

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Mr SPEAKER

TALK.START.PARA: —I have received a letter from the honourable member for Gilmore (Mr Sharp) proposing that a definite matter of public importance be submitted to the House for discussion, namely:

INTERJECT.PARA: The Government's total failure to achieve reform of Australia's transport infrastructure, disadvantaging exporters and manufacturers and leading to a decline in the economy and employment opportunities.
I call upon those members who approve of the proposed discussion to rise in their places.
More than the number of members required by the Standing Orders having risen in their places-

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sharp Mr J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —As Australia languishes in the worst recession that we have experienced since the end of the Second World War, as our foreign debt increases to $131 billion net from about $20 billion when this Government came to power, as unemployment levels increase dramatically to the point where we look realistically at the prospect of seeing double digit unemployment figures by the end of this year, Australia needs to look to a government which can give it some hope, some fresh direction and some opportunity for the future. We need to have a government that is prepared to implement change, particularly in the micro-economic area.

SPEECH.PARA: It is for that reason that in this matter of public importance discussion the Opposition has decided to talk about the need to reform our transport sector. Our transport sector is a good test of this Government's resolve to implement micro-economic reform to create extra productivity for Australia so that we can trade our way out of the difficulties that we are currently experiencing, many of which have been generated by this Government's economic mismanagement.

If we go beyond the general issue of transport reform to look specifically at the waterfront and use the example of the waterfront as a good means to assess the Government's determination and preparedness to take on the hard issues to create real micro-economic reform, then I think we can get a true picture of what this Government stands for when it talks about creating a new Australia and reconstructing our problems to give us a better future. I can assure you, Mr Deputy Speaker, that within the transport sector there is no greater example of what is wrong with Australia's transport industries than what we see on the waterfront today, because the waterfront houses everything that is wrong with our transport industries. All of the bad work practices, all of the old rorts and all of the trade union militarism is based and housed within the Australian waterfront.

Let us focus our attention on the Australian waterfront and see how this Government is achieving its micro-economic reform in that area. If we look at the importance of the waterfront, we will realise, as the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Kerin) said in a comment he made to the Daily Telegraph a couple of weeks ago, that the major blocking point within the Australian transport sector is the waterfront. If we are going to fix up the transport sector and fix up Australia's economy, we have firstly to address that major blocking point of the waterfront. If we can do that, we will be able to start helping farmers, manufacturers, people in the motor vehicle building industry, people in our textile, clothing and footwear industries and so on, because they are the people who are bearing the costs of the inefficiency right throughout our transport sector, and in particular as a result of the inefficiencies that exist today on the Australian waterfront.

In 1988 some research was done to determine what precisely is the cost of having an inefficient transport sector. Interestingly enough, the cost of that inefficiency came to some $3,240m per year in 1988 figures. That is the cost of having those inefficiencies on our waterfront, in our rail system, on our roads and within our coastal shipping industry. The greatest cost of that is borne by our farmers, but to bring down to a more individual, more personalised basis how much all those inefficiencies mean to us, I can tell honourable members from those figures that the cost of the inefficiencies inherent within our transport infrastructure is $720 per household throughout Australia. Some $720 per household in 1988 figures is a great cost. The cost in today's terms would be even greater.

Let us focus on the waterfront and see how we can start to overcome the huge cost of over $3,000m that is being imposed upon every Australian each and every year. In 1984 the Government talked up big about its desire to reform the waterfront. In September 1984 we had the first of two major inquiries into reforming the waterfront, the first being the Webber inquiry. In 1989 the Government implemented its Waterfront Industry Reform Authority (WIRA), the vehicle by which all of its rhetoric of the previous five years would be turned into action. This would bring us home the bacon of reform on the waterfront. Where are we? We are halfway through the Waterfront Industry Reform Authority's program of reform, and what have we achieved? To date, any objective observer would say that the Government's waterfront reform program is snail-paced: it is totally inadequate and is way behind schedule. That is the view that I hold, that members on this side of the House hold and that most objective observers throughout the industry hold. The Government's reform of the waterfront is snail-paced.

If honourable members do not believe my objective judgment or the judgment of others throughout the industry, we can go to the Government's own targets for waterfront reform set out in its in-principle agreement when WIRA was established in 1989. Where does it tell us we should be with waterfront reform today? The agreement said that, within 12 months of establishing WIRA, 500 waterside workers should be made redundant through the WIRA process by September 1990. Where were we with redundancies on the waterfront by September 1990? Did we get 500; or did we have 400, 300, 200 or even 100 redundancies by September 1990? No, we did not get any of those. We got a big fat zero-zero redundancies-within the first 12 months when the target that the Government set was for 500. Already we are behind schedule. Already we are snail-paced, measured by the Government's own targets that it set itself.

Here we are now at the halfway point. According to the Government's own measurements, that halfway point should have delivered to us 1,000 redundancies on the Australian waterfront by today. How many do we have? Do we have 1,000, 800, 600 or 500? We have not got that at all. If all the redundancies that have been agreed to and that are to take place by the end of March actually happen, we will have 451. That means that we are moving at less than half pace in terms of the Government's own stated targets of reform on the waterfront. We have to balance that against the fact that the Government has employed an extra 213 new workers in the process of getting us those redundancies. Nobody can say that that has been done at a startling pace. None of us would argue with the claim that the reform process of the waterfront is moving at a disgraceful pace and is costing us tremendously.

Here we are at the halfway point, moving at less than half pace. If we extrapolate the experience that we have had from the first half of the WIRA process to the second half of the WIRA process, which starts next month, we will realise that Australia is likely to get up less than half of the targeted reform programs that this Government set for itself over three years. We might say, `Well, maybe the Government had set too high a target and this is why it cannot get anywhere near it'. That would be fair if it had set too high a target. But the reality is that its target of a 30 per cent gain in productivity on the waterfront over three years is absolutely wimpish. It is typical of some of the things we see every day from this Government. It is wimpish because 30 per cent over three years is nothing like that which we need to achieve on the Australian waterfront to keep Australia competitive as a trading nation.

To assist the Government to even get those meagre reforms up and running, it has a $300m redundancy package for retiring waterside workers. If we extrapolate that into direct figures, we will find that for every one per cent of productivity gain on the Australian waterfront these people in the Government are prepared to spend $10m of our money paying off retiring waterside workers. I wonder what small businesses, farmers and other people who are currently suffering would think of that.

We have only a very modest target set by this Government for reform on the waterfront. Meanwhile, what is the rest of the world doing? In 1989-the same year this Government kicked off its WIRA program-the United Kingdom reformed its waterfront. What did it achieve? It achieved a 65 per cent gain in productivity in 12 months. In the same year, New Zealand reformed its waterfront and achieved a 100 per cent gain in productivity on its waterfront. New Zealand did not need to give a $100,000 package on average to each retiring waterside worker. It got its 100 per cent gain in 12 months with a $27,000 average pay-out to its waterside workers. These people in the Government are being very modest in their goals and very generous in their payments to their mates. We are not going to get anywhere near the targets that this Government has set for itself. Yet the Government talks about 30 per cent as if it was something really meaningful and significant.

A very useful exercise is to look at the way this Government measures itself in terms of what it achieves. This Government gets awfully excited about saying, `Goodness, we are going to create a 30 per cent increase in productivity on the waterfront. Isn't that fantastic? Aren't we worldbeaters? Aren't we a great government? Aren't we up there with the leading nations of the world as far as reform is concerned?'. The fact is that we are way behind because the rest of the world is moving faster than us when it comes to waterfront reform. If one looks at some of the figures that the Waterfront Industry Reform Authority itself puts forward, one will see that Australia's productivity levels on the waterfront are hopelessly behind.

If one compares Melbourne with a similar port, such as Yokohama, and looks at the 20-foot containers that each port takes over its waterfront every hour, one will see that, according to the Waterfront Industry Reform Authority, the port of Yokohama can handle thirty 20-foot containers per hour. Currently, Melbourne can move twelve 20-foot containers per hour. If we have a 30 per cent productivity gain over a three-year period, what will we end up with? Melbourne will move sixteen 20-foot containers per hour whilst Yokohama's figure of 30 will have been surpassed because Yokohama is constantly reforming and it will probably have gone to 35. So we will still have only half the level of efficiency that a port such as Yokohama will have.

David White, the Victorian Minister for Industry and Economic Planning, said at a parliamentary committee hearing a couple of weeks ago in Melbourne that if this Federal Government implements fully its reform on the Melbourne waterfront the port of Melbourne will be 20 per cent as efficient as the port of Singapore. How does that stand up to the measurement of how international trade is carried out?

We are not competing against ourselves. Thirty per cent better than what we were is of no significance to anybody. What we have to do is be 30 per cent more efficient than the rest of the world because it is the rest of the world that we trade against, not ourselves. That is why the whole policy of this Government on the waterfront is fatally flawed. As the Leader of the National Party of Australia (Mr Tim Fischer) pointed out to me, how can we have efficiency on the waterfront when every container requires 104 separate pieces of paper to be filled in by somebody before it can be moved through the port? It is a bureaucratic nightmare.

This Government looks inwards, not outwards, and that is why its program of reform will actually leave the Australian waterfront more inefficient-in comparison with our trading partners-than it was at the beginning of the program. By the time we get to the end of this Government's waterfront reform program-if we assume for a moment that we achieve all of the goals-we will still be more inefficient than the rest of the world, but more efficient in comparison with when we started out. That is one of the failings that this Government has forgotten in its process of reform and in its decision to drive through with that reform by pushing the Waterside Workers Federation of Australia and others to the negotiating table.

The whole process of this Government's reform program has been flawed. Even last week when Conaust Pty Ltd got a successful ruling from the Australian Industrial Relations Commission the Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support (Senator Collins) claimed this as a great success on behalf of the Government. Even that reform, whereby Conaust was able to achieve some gains-certainly not all that it would like to get, but some-was achieved, not through the Government's waterfront reform program, as the Government will no doubt try to tell us tomorrow afternoon when the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) gets up, but because Conaust went outside the waterfront reform program driven by this Government. It went outside it because-as Captain Richard Setchell, who runs Conaust, said-the Government was, at very best, neutral in its help in terms of achieving reform on the waterfront. A couple of weeks ago he said, `The lack of purposeful government involvement and support has left the ship foundering'-the ship being waterfront reform.

The gains that this Government has achieved rest wholly and solely with the National Terminals agreement, an agreement which has seen some redundancies take place, but which, according to the peak shippers advisory group-a group which the Government set up just a couple of months ago to advise it-is nothing better than a group of motherhood statements. The Government has not achieved reform on the waterfront. It has not been able to get even halfway towards its own test of success in reform on the waterfront.

Until the Minister for Transport and Communications (Mr Beazley) and his colleagues can achieve significant micro- economic reform, Australia will continue to languish in the recession which we are currently experiencing-a recession brought on by the Government-and which will be continued by the Government because of its lack of courage to take on these hard issues of micro reform.

The honourable member for Gilmore has seen a few criticisms around the place about the waterfront reform process so he walks away from his commitment. I tell the Opposition that, as far as all these areas of micro-economic reform are concerned, nothing happens by declaration or by marching into this place and making a great speech. Everything happens by a process of deliberation or it does not happen at all.

I will go through what the honourable member for Barker had to say about these matters when he appeared at an Australian Chamber of Shipping lunch. He was asked questions by people who actually know about these processes, as opposed to the general public, which can be misinformed from time to time. When one appears at something like the Australian Chamber of Shipping lunch, one appears without alibis and without the opportunity for a quick flick through notes in order to be able to convince the panel that one has a process of reform under way. According to an article in the Australian entitled `Coalition ducks outlining waterfront plan: Trust us, McLachlan urges', this is what the honourable member for Barker had to say:
By the time the election comes there will be a number of important people in this room who will know exactly what the process of reform will be.

That is terrific! That is two years off and yet here he is criticising us for not having a policy or an approach that suits. He comes in here and has nothing to say because he knows nothing. The article in the Australian also attributed this to the honourable member:
`You never know whether anyone's going to be any good at anything until you put him in a position of responsibility and I believe that applies to politics as well,' . . .
The article continued:

Later he told a questioner: ``Your question is `will we have the guts to do it' (reform the waterfront)-I don't know. George Bush said, `read my lips' and he backed down (on United States taxes). I can only say you're going to have to either trust people or keep voting Labor.''
Indeed! The article concluded:
Mr McLachlan said he was sure . . . that there would not be a one-off solution or a short cut to solve industry problems . . .

The honourable member for Barker has not been around long enough to know that performances by Opposition spokesmen in these sorts of areas ought to reflect, from their point of view and for their political protection, a high degree of dishonesty, as we saw from the previous spokesman on waterfront reform. It does not require an honest approach, such as that put forward by the honourable member for Barker, conceding that the Opposition has no policies and that the industry will have to proceed on trust. On the question of having the guts for a confrontation, we have only seen one example of the Opposition in a confrontation and that was in the pilots' dispute last year. Its response involved ducking under the table really quickly.

TALK.START.PARA: —You are all talk, Beazley.

—Indeed. People make great promises in opposition, but when they actually get themselves in a position to do something, then they may well cut and run. Well might honourable members opposite cut and run because they do not come into this debate with clean hands at all. Their hands have been dirtied by their endorsement of the Government process back in 1989 when the Inter-State Commission brought down a report. But even more their hands have been muddied by their performance in government over years and years.

SPEECH.PARA: When this Government came into office, in the transport sector we inherited a road policy that had atrophied, that was not delivering the changes that were required. There had been no reform on the waterfront. For 30 of the last 33 years, through all of those changes in the fifties and sixties which set the current prevailing work practices in place, the Opposition parties had been governing and had no policy in regard to it. In telecommunications, there was a state monopoly operating without any reform to that process at all. There was a two-airline agreement set in concrete-it had been there for 40 years. Qantas was massively protected and there were very few airlines effectively operating to this country.

Now the Opposition comes in here and says we need to take a lesson from it on micro-economic reform, and `What the public ought to do is look at the Opposition's record and trust us. Do not worry about a policy, public-we might have a policy in two years time-but just trust us because we can talk up a storm, if even we can deliver nothing'. The public has a right to be sceptical about that sort of approach, as the honourable member for Barker was happy to concede to the shipping council, and the read-my-lips formula which he applied to George Bush on the subject of taxes. We do not ever really know-and indeed we do not when it comes to the Opposition.

What have we achieved since then? There is no two-airline agreement in place-none. The efficiencies that can come to the tourism industry from competition in the aviation sector are now coming. Why? As the result of a decision that we took. That is the first point. The second point is that Qantas, which had 23 competitors when we came into office, now has 40. In addition to that, there are liberalised international charter arrangements which are seeing charters to parts of the country important to the tourism industry but not well served by international aviation, at least until we put those policies in place.

We have a situation now where seats available under our agreements are running at about twice the level of those which were in existence when we came into office but can only be half filled. In other words, we have a negotiated capacity well beyond the Australian tourism market or any other market to sustain. That leaves, of course, massive room for growth. They are the achievements of this Government after 30 years of atrophy under the Liberal Party of Australia when it was in government.

In the roads sector, we are now 21 per cent up in real terms on the levels of expenditures that the Opposition coalition had when it was in office. So there is improvement there. As far as the rail freight industry is concerned, we are getting in place a national rail freight authority which will deal with some of the inefficiencies that come out of the system that was inherited by us when we came into office. In the telecommunications area, we now have a position where there is going to be competition across the board with networks, a massive liberalisation of the ability of people to operate off leased lines, additional cellular mobile operators and eight competitors in cordless telephones. There has been the introduction of real competition in that area.

The Opposition tries to demonise these achievements with a plethora of nonsense that it has come forward with. The honourable member for Gilmore said of the Conaust Ltd agreement which has just been reached that it was outside the framework of the Waterfront Industry Reform Authority. Unfortunately he would say that only because he has not read the reform process that has been put in place.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have.

—I go to page one of the summary in principle agreement. If the honourable member read it, he did not read it very well. It says that nothing in the agreement shall affect the right of any party under the Industrial Relations Act 1988. We anticipated that in this process there would be occasions when there would be a requirement to resort to the industrial relations system to cement those gains. SPEECH.PARA: Our on-going commitment and belief in the established system has been vindicated by the decisions made by the Commission yesterday. The Commission's direction was based, we believe, on a rational and logical evaluation of the issues put before it for consideration.

—Now he says-he is heckling me-`What about eliminating cabotage?'. What a nonsense position. SPEECH.PARA: So far only one of the OECD nations, to my knowledge, has abandoned cabotage-assuming it is a relevant policy, because of course some of them are land-locked-and that is the United Kingdom. What did they introduce into Parliament a year or so ago-an Act to restore cabotage in the United Kingdom system. So we have been getting on with the job of micro-economic reform, not just yakking about it and ducking our responsibilities to establish a policy. The honourable member for Barker says, `We will have a policy which in two years time you will know all about. Will we implement it? Well, trust us; maybe we won't'. Instead of having what the honourable member for Barker talks about, we have in place the process which in 1989 the Opposition endorsed.

What are we establishing from that? When this Conaust agreement is finalised, there will be a rampant knock-on-as those opposite well know-with a whole series of other agreements affecting Conaust. Dealing with the problem of work practices and manpower levels is only dealing with part of the problem. The fact of the matter is that in this country, unlike New Zealand and the United Kingdom, we do not have a unitary system of government. Our system is broken down between the States. If we look at most of the problems in the micro-economic reform area in the transport sector, they virtually all stem from that fact.

Most micro-economic reforms require substantial infrastructure developments. The Commonwealth owns no ports; it only owns bits and pieces of railways. It does own the civil aviation sector, where we have been able to effect dramatic changes. But unless we have cooperation from the States, unless we have some substantial infrastructure expenditures-because that is where real productivities are gained on the waterfront, and that has been so historically-and changes in technology and the way in which business is done, we are not going to have all the changes we need to put into place.

The Opposition has to understand that. The Opposition also has to understand where it comes from. It comes from the most unclean hands conceivable as far as micro-economic reform is concerned, and it comes from having endorsed our positions and now opportunistically walking away from them. The Prime Minister said that reform should be a priority. That sounds a bit familiar: it was said after the last election. Let me look back to the 1987 election? TALK.START.PARA: —I understand it is the wish of the House to debate this order of the day, the Marine Navigation (Regulatory Functions) Levy Bill, cognately with order of the day No. 2, the Marine Navigation (Regulatory Functions) Levy Collections Bill. There being no objection, it is so ordered.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sharp Mr J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —Later in the debate I will be moving an amendment to the Marine Navigation (Regulatory Functions) Levy Bill which reads:

SPEECH.PARA: That all words after ``That'' be omitted with a view to substituting the following words:

``whilst not declining to give the Bill a second reading, the House condemns the Government for its failure to reduce costs imposed by Government through inefficiencies and inadequate reform in the Australian shipping industry, placing a competitive disadvantage on Australian exporters''.

The Bill relates to the Australian Maritime Safety Authority's philosophy of full cost recovery for the services that it provides to the private sector. In this particular case, AMSA provides a number of navigational services to commercial shipping interests-navigation services such as lighthouses, navigational buoys, markers and so forth, all of which are an essential part of the safe operation of any shipping service and also an essential part of any recreational boating or maritime operation. These are vital services being provided by AMSA through the Federal Government.

The creation of the Australian Maritime Safety Authority was shrouded in considerable controversy. Mr Deputy Speaker, you may well remember that at the time of the introduction of the Bill that created the Australian Maritime Safety Authority, the Opposition opposed the creation of AMSA-not on the basis that we thought putting all of the relevant organisations under the one roof was a bad idea, but because we believed that there was no justification for the creation of AMSA based upon cost savings or operational efficiencies. Indeed, as we looked at the legislation that created AMSA and the way in which it was to operate, we became increasingly alarmed that, rather than cost savings flowing as a result of the creation of this new authority, there would actually be cost increases, increases which would have to be borne by the industry itself and which would further burden the industry in terms of its trying to be competitive, trying to get out and compete against foreign flag vessels and trying to compete on behalf of Australian exporters in the world marketplace.

We were very concerned about the establishment of AMSA and our concern has proved to be correct. This Bill further verifies the concern that we expressed late last year when AMSA was created. At the time we could see that the Australian Maritime Safety Authority was to be sweeping up all of the various Federal Government operations that provided services to the maritime industry, putting them all under the one roof, taking them out of Canberra and, as was the proposal at the time, shifting the entire operation down to Newcastle.

This may at first glance seem to be a sensible arrangement. Bringing all those disparate groups together and putting them under the one roof sounds like it is an efficiency gain and something that we should be applauding. As it actually turned out, this was not to be the case. The Prime Minister (Mr Hawke), in the run-up to the election campaign in 1990, had promised the people of Newcastle that a major Federal Government operation would be brought into Newcastle to create jobs and provide additional income in the region to try to boost that region's economic opportunities. That major Federal Government initiative turned out to be the creation of AMSA, and it was to be shifted to Newcastle.

In the process of creating AMSA, the Government developed the policy, which the Opposition does not argue with, of full cost recovery. I think in any reasonable circumstances full cost recovery for government services provided to the private sector is the way to go. Of course, we must place qualifications on that to ensure full cost recovery does not leave the new authority that has been established to collect these revenues in a position to allow its costs to run rampant, further burdening industry with more and more costs where industry has no control over either the provision or the cost of the services.

That is the background to the legislation today. Our concerns now, as they were when AMSA was established, are justified. They were justified because shortly after the legislation came into this House late last year the Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support (Senator Collins) did one of the few things since he has taken on that portfolio which I think many of us would say was responsible, and decided to stop the move of AMSA from Canberra to Newcastle. He did it for very good reasons, which we outlined at the time. The first was that the costs of shifting to Newcastle were becoming outrageous. It was first estimated that the shift to Newcastle would run to $6m to $7m; maybe a little bit more, maybe a little bit less. But, as it turned out, a little bit more turned out to be a whole lot more. It initially became apparent that the cost had run to something like $15m; it then became apparent that the cost was closer to $20m- just to shift a group of government department functions from Canberra to Newcastle.

Of course, $20m was starting to become alarming. Whilst the Government said, `We will meet the costs of making that move from Canberra to Newcastle', the industry realised that the Government might put up the money initially but the industry would be left with the bill because the Government was expecting a commercial return on its investment in AMSA through full cost recovery processes later down the track. So, whilst the industry would not put up the money initially, it would end up paying for the huge cost of shifting from Canberra to Newcastle.

Why did the Government make the announcement to shift from Canberra to Newcastle? There was no reason other than pork-barrelling. There was no justifiable reason for making that move. This was highlighted by the responsible Minister, Senator Collins, in his decision finally to axe the move due to the alarming increase in the cost. At the time, there was a great deal of concern by local members in Newcastle. That concern will be highlighted not necessarily by the Federal members from Newcastle but by those in the industry itself, because this legislation will further burden them with costs just as the Government's decision to axe AMSA's move from Canberra to Newcastle burdened the four local Australian Labor Party members with a considerable degree of angst, upset, complaint and criticism.

These people-one of whom, the Minister for Land Transport (Mr Brown), sits opposite me today-were seriously embarrassed by the Government's decision not to proceed with the move to Newcastle. Why were they embarrassed? Because during the election campaign they had gone around and trumpeted AMSA's move as one of the good reasons to vote for them-one of the reasons Labor is good for people in Newcastle, one of the reasons people should continue to place their faith in the Labor Party. As it turned out, that was another broken promise by the Government from the last election campaign.

However, returning to the Bill before the House this afternoon, it is quite apparent to see that the industry has justifiable concerns with this cost recovery legislation through the introduction of this levy. Whilst the Government introduces a cost recovery process, the question that everybody in the industry is asking is: just how much control does the industry, which has the ultimate responsibility of paying for the services provided by AMSA, have over, firstly, the type of services that are provided to it and, secondly, the cost of the provision of those services?

In the legislation that is before the House this afternoon the Government has said that there will be an upper limit of 15 per cent placed upon all cost increases over the next three years in order to achieve full cost recovery for the services provided by AMSA. An upper limit of 15 per cent is an unusual figure. Why is the figure 15 per cent? We have looked through the second reading speech of the Minister for Land Transport and the explanatory memorandum that was provided by the Government in relation to this legislation and have asked: where does it explain why 15 per cent is the chosen figure? Does it represent the figure that the Minister who introduced the Bill believes inflation will be each and every year for the next three years? Will inflation be 15 per cent next year; will it be 15 per cent the year after; or is this a combination of both inflation and a catch-up in order to achieve full cost recovery? That question that we had in our minds was not answered in any of the inquiries that we made in reading the second reading speech of the Minister nor the explanatory memorandum.

Fifteen per cent seems to be a rather arbitrary figure. In the process of having a cap of 15 per cent on price increases that AMSA can impose for its services upon the industry, one wonders what sort of pressure that places on the Authority to keep its costs within reasonable bounds. Surely, if we are going to make Australia a more competitive country, we should not cap increases at 15 per cent per annum but at much lower levels, or even negative levels, so that Australia's shipping industry and Australia's exports can be more competitive. That is a matter that I will discuss further when moving the amendment in relation to this legislation at the conclusion of this speech.

We asked the question: why 15 per cent? We got no satisfactory answer. That figure does not place any discipline upon the Authority to keep a close watch on the provision of its services or the cost of those services that it provides. All it does is give the Authority plenty of room to absorb cost increases, inefficiencies and cost blow-outs and pass those on to the industry. On behalf of the Opposition, I state that we do not think that is the right thing to do. We believe that if there are to be cost increases the Government should not pass on the power to just have those cost increases pushed up to 15 per cent each year. If those cost increases are necessary, they should be brought before the Parliament for ratification by the Parliament so that we, the people who represent everybody in Australia and who have interests on behalf of the industry, can view for ourselves precisely why those costs need to be put up. If we are not satisfied, we can say to the Authority, `Sorry, that is not a justifiable reason for putting your costs up; you are going to have to go back and find ways of creating more efficiencies in order to keep your costs down to the industry'.

At the moment the Government is giving the Authority carte blanche to increase its costs to the tune of 15 per cent without having to come back to the Parliament and the people of Australia for their approval. We think that is the wrong way to go. It raises the question which was put by one of my colleagues in our Party meeting the other day: how many other of these Commonwealth authorities have the authority to push their prices up by amounts of 15 per cent or more each year without proper regulation or proper review by the Parliament? I think it is time for us to go through the process of analysing how many of these departments or authorities have been given this power, how many of them are able to increase their costs without parliamentary scrutiny and what burden that then places on industries that have to pay for the cost increases that these people impose without any proper discipline being placed upon them.

Those are some of the concerns that the Opposition has. We want to know why 15 per cent is the arbitrary figure for cost increases. Why is the Government not saying to the Authority, `If you want to put your prices up, bring your arguments to the Parliament and we will either ratify them or not ratify them. At least in the meantime, though, we will have had an opportunity to look at them, to analyse them and to express our views on them. The industry will have a back-up through the Parliament to ensure that its best interests are being represented as well'? I know that the Minister will say, `But industry has an input into these things'. Quite frankly, while industry might have an input, it does not have a sufficient input from my point of view to ensure that that proper discipline is being imposed on this type of authority or other similar authorities which make up the full retinue of the Government's statutory authorities.

The Opposition has no argument with the principle of cost recovery. We simply have an argument as to how we ensure that cost recovery does not get out of control and that the power that is given to the statutory authorities is not abused at the expense of the industry. Our argument is that there has to be some form of public scrutiny of all these authorities to ensure that the most competitive gains can be had for Australia's industries and that industries like Australia's shipping industry are not further burdened with additional costs as a consequence of an authority that has carte blanche virtually to increase its charges to the tune of 15 per cent per annum for the next few years.

Those are a few of the thoughts of the Opposition. We will have an opportunity in a few moments to continue this debate in the committee stage. I now formally move the amendment that I foreshadowed at the commencement of my address this afternoon. I move:
That all words after ``That'' be omitted with a view to substituting the following words:

``whilst not declining to give the Bill a second reading, the House condemns the Government for its failure to reduce costs imposed by Government through inefficiencies and inadequate reform in the Australian shipping industry, placing a competitive disadvantage on Australian exporters''.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the amendment seconded?
—I second the amendment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hollis Mr C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am pleased to speak on this important legislation-the Marine Navigation (Regulatory Functions) Levy Bill and the Marine Navigation (Regulatory Functions) Levy Collection Bill. At the outset, I reject the amendment moved by the honourable member for Gilmore (Mr Sharp). Far be it for me to comment on such things, but if the amendment had been moved in another form it would have been ruled out of order because it has nothing to do with the legislation that is before the House. The amendment talks about the so-called inefficiencies and inadequate reform of the Australian shipping industry.

SPEECH.PARA: As a speaker in the previous debate said, it is a bit of a gall for these people who occupied the Treasury Bench for something like 30 years to come in here and read the riot act to us on shipping reform or transport reform. The gall of the Opposition is almost beyond belief. The Opposition occupied the Treasury Bench for 30 years. In the time that we have been in government, we have put in massive reforms, especially in the shipping industry. I do not know where these people opposite have been for the last few years if they are not aware of these things.

I sympathise with the honourable member for Gilmore. I think he found the going fairly hard, because there was not very much that he could object to in this legislation. He kept going on about the 15 per cent upper limit. Again, it always surprises me when the Opposition talks about these things. The Opposition is constantly telling us that it wants government business enterprises to act in a fully commercial manner. We on this side of the House are committed to acting in a fully commercial manner. But the Opposition is not so committed. Immediately we give any authority the right to act in such a manner, the Opposition says, `No, you can't do this; it's all got to come back to this chamber for this chamber to approve it'. We are either going to run a business or we are not. In very broad terms, the purpose of the legislation is to recover the costs of the maritime and safety regulatory functions of the Australian Maritime Safety Authority (AMSA) by imposing, on a sliding scale-and it is a sliding scale-a levy on certain seagoing ships. These Bills give effect to the Government's decision, announced on 21 August 1990, to recover the costs of maritime safety and regulatory functions from the commercial shipping industry by imposing this levy on certain seagoing ships. The functions were transferred to the new Australian Maritime Safety Authority upon its creation on 1 January 1991. The decision to impose a safety and regulatory levy is consistent with the Government's overall policy for government business enterprises, whereby the full costs of non-community service obligations are recovered by those who benefit from such services, rather than having the taxpayer pay for them.

The Bill introduces a sliding scale of levy under which the rate per tonne reduces as the tonnage increases. The formula adopted in the Bill has been developed in consultation with the industry. I do not know who in the industry the honourable member for Gilmore was talking to, because all the way through there has been full consultation with the industry on this matter. I note that he said it will be a burden on the industry. If it will be a burden on the industry it will be a very minor burden and it is putting onto the industry a fee which it, rather than the taxpayer, will pay.

As I said, the formula has been developed in consultation with industry and it is one that has been used successfully in the Marine Navigation Levy Act 1989. It is well known that this Act is as fair as possible to all sections of the shipping industry. The Marine Navigation Levy Act enables the cost of navigation aids to be recovered. So we are bringing in the safety part of it and it will operate in the same way as the Marine Navigation Levy Act enables the cost of navigation aids to be recovered.

The levy will be phased in over a three-year period, achieving full cost recovery in the 1993-94 financial year. To enable increased costs to be met in future years, the Bill allows for the individual rates of levy to be varied by regulation. The Bill, however, restricts increases introduced after the phase-in period to a maximum of 15 per cent per annum. For the life of me I do not see why the honourable member for Gilmore is making such a fuss about this. It is a maximum of 15 per cent per annum. Perhaps he wants it to be much higher. Maybe he will talk about that at the committee stage and tell us exactly how much above the 15 per cent he wants the increase to go. This will ensure that the regulations are used to provide increased revenue reasonably related to the overall provision of services to the industry.

Currently, the annual cost of AMSA's safety and regulatory activities is estimated at just over $7m. There will be no costs to the Commonwealth arising from this Bill. The levy will apply to all ships, except those exempted by regulation under the Marine Navigation Levy Collection Act, which make a call into an Australian port for the purpose of undertaking a commercial trading voyage. No ship will be levied if it makes an Australian port call for the purpose of repair or refit, to take on provisions, to change crew, or to land a crew member or passenger for medical treatment. I do not think there would be any objection to any of those exceptions.

Ships currently exempted by regulations are: military ships; ships of the Commonwealth, States, or Territories; ships in ballast; ships less than 24 metres long; ships belonging to religious societies; ships laying submarine cables; hospital ships; sailing ships under 500 tonnes; fishing vessels; and pleasure craft. Application of the levy is non-discriminatory. Australian ships will not be advantaged or disadvantaged by introduction of these new levies. The levy is to be paid by all foreign ships visiting Australia in commercial trade, as well as by the Australian fleet.

After the Government's announcement last year of its intention to recover the costs of maritime safety and regulatory functions, consultation took place with the industry on the issue of how the new levy might be applied. The starting point for these consultations was, as I said before, a proposal that the new levy adopt the same formula as that already in place for navigation aids. The Opposition, from memory, opposed this very strenuously, but since it has been in operation there has not been a lot of opposition to it. Interested parties were invited to suggest alternative options. In the event, no constructive suggestions for alternative methods of collection were proposed.

The Government announced on 28 November 1989 that it intended to establish the Australian Maritime Safety Authority. This Authority was to be established to enable the safety services to be provided with greater independence and greater responsiveness to the needs of the maritime industry and community generally than was possible from a department of state. Legislation for the establishment of AMSA from 1 January 1991 received royal assent on 22 October 1990.

From 1 January 1991, AMSA assumed responsibility for most of the maritime operations functions formerly undertaken by the Department of Transport and Communications. These included: marine crewing and qualifications; ship registration; search and rescue; pollution control and response; provision of marine navigational aids in Australian waters; and safety regulation of maritime operations in Australia. The Authority will perform these functions in a manner which is consistent with the obligations of Australia under any convention, treaty or agreement to which Australia is a party.

The maritime accident investigation role is to stay with the Department to ensure that conflicting interests do not arise when there is a need for an objective report on regulatory issues connected with a maritime accident. The separation of the regulatory and investigative function is consistent with practice in other countries.

As is known, and as the honourable member for Gilmore made much of, the AMSA headquarters are situated in Canberra, with three main regional offices located in Brisbane, Melbourne and Perth. The honourable member really spoke a load of nonsense about why the decision was made to not go to Newcastle. I must say that, from a personal point of view, I would have supported the headquarters going to Newcastle and I hope that the Minister for Land Transport, the honourable member for Charlton (Mr Robert Brown), hears me saying that. As Chairman of the Joint Statutory Committee on Public Works, I would have had something to do with that.

TALK.START.PARA: —Certainly no element of pork-barrelling.

—No, there was absolutely no element of pork-barrelling. The Government made the decision that the headquarters should stay in Canberra and, as I say, purely from a personal point of view, I would have preferred to see them go to Newcastle because I think some of these services that we are providing should go into the regional areas. In the area of maritime safety I sometimes find it a little strange that the headquarters should be in Canberra-maybe there are some problems on Lake Burley Griffin. Nevertheless, it was nonsense spoken by the honourable member for Gilmore. The decision was made with regard to various considerations-not least budgetary ones-and the headquarters will remain in Canberra.

SPEECH.PARA: The Authority's initial annual budget is estimated at around $70m, which is to be funded on a cost recovery basis for those services which can be provided for on a commercial basis, and by the Commonwealth for those functions which are considered to involve community service obligations, such as search and rescue services.

The CTAL agreement in Sydney paves the way for the resolution of outstanding issues in a large number of Conaust enterprise agreements in ports around the country, including Sydney, Melbourne, Brisbane, Fremantle, Adelaide and Darwin. This will significantly increase the momentum of the waterfront reform process.

So when the honourable member for Gilmore talks about inefficiencies and inadequate reform in the Australian shipping industry placing a competitive disadvantage on Australian exporters, he is talking about something which can suitably be directed at his own side for its record over 30 years, not against this Government with its shipping and towage industry reforms, its waterfront reforms and the progress of the Conaust companies enterprise agreements.

The legislation really refers to operational functions which will be exercised by the safety and regulatory levy proposed in this Bill. This is extremely important. Just recently, the honourable member for Cowper (Mr Nehl) and I returned from a seven-week tour to Antarctica. There was great danger because of the severity of the storm where the ship was moving to 50 degrees from the vertical each side, time after time. Naturally this imposed huge strains, and of course there had to be smoking bans. The safety of people was paramount. I recall that at one stage during that storm I was floating around the radio room together with the radio operator, the first mate, a typewriter, a photocopier, a number of books and quite a large amount of paper. TALK.START.PARA: —Thank God you are back safely!

SPEECH.PARA: The amendment that the Opposition moved was designed not only to highlight the whole burden that this Government is placing on the users of navigational services that the Australian Maritime Safety Authority (AMSA) provides, but also to broaden the debate out to enable us to cover a range of issues which relate to costs which governments impose upon shippers and upon those people who use shipping services, such as manufacturers, exporters and importers. The amendment dealt with a very wide range of subjects and therefore gave us the opportunity to speak in such a fashion.

I would like to take up a few of the points made by members of the Government in their comments a few moments ago. One of the things that they tend to forget is that one of the huge costs, one of the unforgivable costs which they impose upon Australian shippers, exporters and importers is the cost of cabotage. Cabotage is a tremendous burden on Australia's industries. We have only to look at some of the examples from the motor vehicle industry to understand just how expensive the maintenance of cabotage is. Cabotage, for those uninitiated, is the banning of all foreign flag competition on the Australian coastline. That ban has been extended illegally by the trade unions between Australia and New Zealand on the trans-Tasman route, so no foreign flag vessels may operate along the Australian coastal route or across the Tasman. So cabotage limits competition simply to Australian flags or New Zealand flags.

From the point of view of the motor vehicle industry, the cost of that ban is horrendous. We have examples that people like Ivan Deveson, the Chief Executive Officer of Nissan Australia, can put to us. Those examples indicate that, rather than use the existing and traditional shipping services to export cars from Australia to New Zealand, the industry is now prepared to airlift cars simply because it is more reliable and cheaper to do so.

If it is cheaper to send cars by air and if shipping services are more expensive and less reliable than air services, surely there must be something desperately wrong with Australian shipping services. Surely, with the high cost of operating aircraft and the limited space on board, it would be more expensive to send them by air; but it is not, simply because this Government imposes a burden on shippers, on the people who use shipping services, on exporters, importers, manufacturers and so on. That is called cabotage. Cabotage makes Australian shipping uncompetitive. It makes Australian manufacturers, exporters and traders who trade around Australia that much less competitive.

I have a number of examples of this-cars of course are not the sole example. I have some detailed analysis of sea freight rates for items such as raw sugar. It is interesting that in times past we have heard that Australia's sugar industry is losing sales to Western Australia because shipping rates from source countries such as Mexico and the Philippines to Western Australia are cheaper than shipping rates from Queensland to Western Australia. Why? The answer is cabotage.

The indicative costs of shipping raw sugar from Bundaberg to our domestic refineries are: from the discharge port, Sydney, using Australian flag vessels, $15.40; from Sydney using a foreign flag vessel, $12.80; from Melbourne using an Australian flag vessel, $17.70; from Melbourne using a foreign flag vessel, $14-a difference in that case of $3.70. If we ship raw sugar to New Zealand, the differences become even greater. The cost from the loading port of, say, Mackay in Queensland using an Australian-New Zealand flag vessel is $23. To use a foreign flag vessel, it costs $17 to $19. So we can very quickly see that the costs that this Government imposes on shippers and shipping users are horrendous because this Government will not address the cost of cabotage.

In the case of shipping raw sugar from Australia to New Zealand, the cost can be as much as $5 per tonne extra in imposing Australian or New Zealand flag vessels on that route and banning foreign flag vessels. These are the sorts of examples which are added to further in the industry paper I have. For example, it says:

The steaming time from Australia to New Zealand is five days; from Thailand to New Zealand 15 days. The Queensland sugar industry has only a $4 per tonne competitive advantage over Thailand in supplying the New Zealand market yet it is one-third the distance away from the market.
For comparison, international market freight rates are:
