For example, we must address the cost of privatising our port authorities. I know that, until recently, privatisation was a dirty word for the Labor Government; it has now adopted it as if it invented the word itself. But this is an area that the Government has not addressed. In none of its waterfront reforms has it addressed the high cost that is imposed upon Australia's shippers through inefficient port authorities.

For example, Julian Manser, the former Chief Executive Officer of National Terminals (Australia) Ltd, said that it pays $55 charge per box that goes through Sydney to a State authority that provides no services in return. We must see a government prepared to address the high cost of port authority inefficiencies. The argument put forward by the Minister for Transport and Communications (Mr Beazley) this afternoon that the Government has not been able to persuade its State colleagues is a nonsense. There have been five State Labor governments during the term that the Hawke Government has been in office.

This Government is not about addressing the true costs that are being imposed upon Australia's shipping industries; it is just further adding to them. That is why we propose this 15 per cent cap on the increase in the cost of services provided by AMSA. We want to see AMSA look inwards, reduce its operating costs, become more efficient and reduce the costs that it imposes on Australia's shipping industry.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brown The Hon R.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The honourable member for Gilmore (Mr Sharp) indicated that, apart from the question of inefficient port authorities-which he recognised of course is a responsibility essentially of State governments-his chief concern is the question of cabotage. People need to understand that that means reserving for the Australian flag vessels the movement of freight around Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: We make no apology at all for the fact that we support in general the principle of cabotage, as does ever other member country of the Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development which has coastal shipping. We do not treat coastal shipping in any way differently from any other domestic industry. If the honourable member for Gilmore and the Opposition want to take their position to its logical conclusion, they would have nothing in place which prevents a policy being adopted in the future of bringing in guest companies with work forces made up of guest workers from any other countries of the world. That is really what they are proposing as far as cabotage is concerned.

We have been flexible in our interpretation of the principle of cabotage. Not only did we adopt the single voyage permits before to made it possible under certain circumstances for foreign flag vessels to fulfil the task of moving freight around Australia, but also we have extended permits when certain conditions are satisfied. We will not embrace the position which appears to be embraced by the Opposition. I would like the Opposition to spell out whether it would or would not maintain the principle of cabotage, even if adopted in some type of modified way?

The position that the Opposition has adopted so far is to indicate very clearly to us, to the shippers and to the shipping unions that it will abolish cabotage. The honourable member for Gilmore nods in agreement, so let the record show that the Opposition policy of abolishing cabotage is firm and confirmed. I have indicated the reason why we would maintain the one element of cost to which the Opposition refers.

Some of those particular examples were quite speculative. They were not even based on firm freight charges that may have been imposed. Some of those freight charges to which the honourable member for Gilmore drew attention were part of the freight charges that were being adopted by foreign shippers in promoting the possibility of being involved in the carriage of some of that freight. To base a case on freight charges linked to that kind of argument is most inadequate.

The honourable member also knows that, in general, one of the principal reasons there are those significant differentials in freight charges is the thickness of the trade that is involved. The trade to which the honourable member referred is very thin. It is like trying to compare a major wagon moving bulk minerals from one side of Australia to the other with sending through a few kilograms in a taxi and expecting the cost of the taxi to be competitive on a unit basis.

The coalition understands this because it was faced with essentially the same problem in the past. The honourable member for Gilmore has denied any personal responsibility for it, but I do not think that is adequate because for a greater period of time since Federation the coalition has had the responsibility to do something about Australia being one of the great commercial nations of the world but one of the minor maritime nations. The coalition presided over that-not the honourable member for Gilmore.

The honourable member for Gilmore says that he will accept no personal responsibility for the inadequacies of former coalition governments, but some of his colleagues were here during that time. While he will not accept responsibility, some of those people who sit with him on the front bench and behind him on the back benches were here so they should accept some responsibility. While the honourable member for Gilmore may not have been here then, he is here now because his motivation is as theirs was; he is here because his commitment is as theirs was; he is here because his philosophy is as theirs was. If their motivation, commitment and philosophy were collectively inadequate to satisfactorily address and resolve those problems, I would submit to the honourable member for Gilmore that his are as well.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sharp Mr J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I take this opportunity to respond to a couple of the points made by the Minister for Land Transport (Mr Robert Brown) in his address. Firstly, he claimed that the figures that I quoted from in the report, which indicate the difference in costs of services when provided by Australian flag vessels as opposed to foreign flag vessels, are unsubstantiated. I can assure the Minister that they are not unsubstantiated. They come from people who do not operate shipping lines, who do not have any intention to operate shipping lines, but who try to not only export these products across Australia but also transport them around Australia to other States where they are not grown.

SPEECH.PARA: The point that the Minister made about these figures being unsubstantiated is wrong. Indeed, if the Minister needs any substantiation as to the high costs that cabotage imposes upon Australian shipping users, he need only go to the Industry Commission report that was brought down I think the year before last in which the Commission did an excellent job in highlighting the very high cost that cabotage places upon Australian shipping users. If my memory serves me correctly, the report says that the trans-Tasman route-because of the ban on foreign flag vessels-adds another 25 to 50 per cent to the cost of freighting goods from Australia to New Zealand. This is indisputable. All shipping companies, shippers and New Zealanders will confirm that these figures are mainly correct. So let us not try to right off the argument that cabotage is not a cost by simply saying that these figures which we put forward this afternoon are unsubstantiated.

Everybody understands that cabotage is a cost to Australia. When the Minister asked why we do not make an announcement that we are going to remove cabotage, I nodded my head and said that we are going to. In the 1990 election campaign, the Opposition went to the people with a policy which said that we would remove cabotage over a period of five years and wind it down over that period. I have reiterated this policy at every opportunity along the way. The Minister must remember that we make no bones about it, just as his own Government makes no bones about what it is going to do with the textiles, clothing and footwear industries, the motor vehicle industries and a whole host of other industries which enjoy other forms of protection. What this all boils down to is that cabotage is just another form of industry protection.

Tariffs provide protection for the motor vehicle industry. Cabotage provides protection for the Australian shipping industry. The same arguments that one can use to wind down tariff protection for the motor vehicle industry, for example, can be applied equally to removing cabotage from the Australian shipping industry. The bottom line is that protection for these types of industries does not work. If one looks at Australia's shipping industry over the last 10 years, one finds that the number of berths on Australian flag vessels has dropped by a third. If my memory serves me correctly, it has dropped from somewhere around 3,018 berths in 1980 to about 1,980 berths in 1990. So, despite protection, we have lost jobs in the Australian shipping industry. The same example, of course, applies to the motor vehicle industry. Despite the tremendous protection that the motor vehicle industry has had, jobs are being wound down in that industry.

Let us not kid ourselves; protection does not save jobs. Indeed, it hurts the creation and maintenance of jobs further downstream as the knock-on effect hurts other industries. The coalition looks at the issue of removing cabotage in the same light as we look at the issue of removing industry protection in other sectors of the economy. We see other matters being more important to try to help the industry, other than keeping cabotage in place.

The reason Australia's shipping industry is as inefficient as it is in comparison with international freight rates is the high cost of finance in Australia, the high cost of our taxation system and Australia's industrial relations arrangements. Those three things make Australian shipowners less competitive than their international counterparts. They all buy their ships from the same sources and they cost roughly the same. It is only when one gets down to interest rates, tax rates and industrial relations that one finds a difference between Australian shipowners and international shipowners. If the coalition is prepared to address those three areas of difference when we get into government, we will give Australian shipowners an opportunity to have an industry with viability rather than an industry that depends upon protection which ultimately will be removed.

The Minister pointed out that it was our philosophy-the one that I represent now-that caused these inefficiencies to be generated in the first instance. I would make the point that it is the Government's philosophy which has aided and abetted these inefficiencies right from the outset. The Australian Labor Party stems from the trade union movement, the Labor movement in Australia, which currently makes up 60 per cent of the body that decides the Party's policies. The Government cannot deny that. In fact, it is a cause of a great deal of debate within the Party at present.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are very proud of it, John.

—The honourable member for Hinkler may be very proud of it, but in the process of being proud of it he must remember that if we are guilty-that is, I am guilty as I represent a certain philosophy-of the sins of the past as far as the waterfront is concerned, he also must be prepared to admit that he, as a person who represents a philosophy which is borne from the Labor movement, must bear the responsibility for the inefficiencies that the trade unions have imposed upon our shipping industry, our waterfront and other sectors of the Australian community. If one places blame upon who represents a particular philosophy, the Government's labour movement is very much responsible for the inefficiencies that we have today. So let us not kid ourselves.

SPEECH.PARA: Inefficiencies continue to abound. True it is that the Government has been able to bring down manning levels from the low 30s to the low 20s and, indeed, it will be going below those figures over the next couple of years. This Sunday I will be travelling on an Australian flag vessel from Brisbane to New Zealand-hopefully not to experience the same things that the honourable member for Eden-Monaro (Mr Snow) experienced; I hope it will all be smooth seas and straight sailing. I think, if my memory serves me right, that the manning levels on board that vessel are in the high teens. This is something the Government can claim it has achieved. But, once again, let us not kid ourselves.

Australia is a country that needs to trade with the rest of the world. We cannot compare ourselves with ourselves. Let us not say, `Isn't it whacko that we have been able to bring down our previous manning levels from 30 to 20 or to the high teens?'. What we must do is compare ourselves with the rest of the world because we have to be able to beat international competition and even the goal of working to average Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development levels of manning is insufficient.

Australia, because of its geographic position and because of its dependence upon trade and exports, must be a better maritime nation. In order to be better we must recognise the distances that we have, and therefore we must have the most efficient shipping services being offered to us as are available anywhere in the world. That is why we take the policies that we have to the people. We will continue to take these policies to the next election. I believe that during the next two years that remain between now and when the next election is scheduled people will appreciate that if we are to solve our economic problems we have to reduce our costs. One way to reduce our costs is to have a more efficient shipping industry and a more efficient waterfront. Those are the matters with which we propose to deal.

In relation to my amendment, I would like to conclude by saying these costs being imposed upon Australian shippers and the Australian shipping industry are in fact a great burden to them. Julian Manser, until recently the chief executive of National Terminals (Australia) Ltd, a government owned stevedoring operation, one of the biggest stevedoring operators in Australia today, is the man who negotiated the first and only enterprise based agreement (EBA) through the Waterfront Industry Reform Authority (WIRA) process under this Government's waterfront reform program. About three weeks ago, Julian Manser said in a speech to a conference in Sydney-I forget its name-that despite the existence of the EBA, he could see no cost savings flowing through to the users of the waterfront, and to the shippers and so forth, simply because the costs of implementing the enterprise based agreement would absorb all of the gains to be had by the efficiencies created by it.

So what this all boils down to, what this whole amendment is based upon, is summed up in those words of Julian Manser-that despite the semblance of reform, at the end of the day the users of our waterfront, the users of our shipping industries do not benefit because costs are not likely to decrease. Until we focus our attention on reducing the costs to the users of our shipping industry and to the users of our waterfront, we will get nowhere.
Bill agreed to.

TALK.START.PARA: —This Primary Industries Legislation Amendment Bill 1991 is an omnibus Bill to amend several Acts. Basically it changes the name of the Australian Meat and Livestock Research and Development Corporation and the Australian Dairy Industry Conference to the Australian Dairy Industry Council. It also introduces equal opportunity amendments for the Australian Dairy Corporation in the same manner as was approved for the Australian Wheat Board in past legislation. Other amendments in the Bill allow horticultural research and development to develop a more commercial role in research.

SPEECH.PARA: This Bill also contains minor administrative amendments to the Australian Meat and Livestock Research and Development Corporation Act 1985 and consequential amendments to the Dairy Produce Act 1986, the Dairy Produce Levy (No.1) Act 1986, and the Horticultural Research and Development Corporation Act 1987.

The amendments to the Australian Meat and Livestock Research and Development Corporation Act change the name of the Australian Meat and Livestock Research and Development Corporation to the Meat Research Corporation. The decision to change the name came from the Corporation to prevent its being confused with the Australian Meat and Livestock Corporation. Other amendments will confine the Government's commitment to match industry research funding to 0.5 per cent of the gross value of production. Because of the name changes, 15 other Acts will need to have consequential amendments made to them.
Amendments to the Dairy Produce Act 1986 insert Government equal opportunity clauses. They are exactly the same as those approved for wheat in that there is a merit clause which says that:
Nothing in this Act requires anyone to do anything incompatible with the principle that employment matters should be dealt with on the basis of merit.

Amendments also change the name of the Australian Dairy Industry Conference to the Australian Dairy Industry Council, and its executive council is to be known as its executive. These name changes require consequential amendments to the Dairy Produce Levy (No.1) Act 1986.

The amendments to the Horticultural Research and Development Act 1987 also provide for changes to the commercial role, the administrative control, and the accountability of the Horticultural Research and Development Corporation. They are consistent with those contained in the Primary Industries and Energy Research and Development Act 1989, which sets the framework for all rural research. These amendments will allow the Corporation power to commercialise research and development, and to join in the formation of a company to acquire, hold and dispose of real and personal income. They also provide for any interest or activities relating to any such companies to be included in the Corporation's annual report. Other amendments will allow meetings to be held by electronic means rather than be face to face meetings. The shadow Minister for primary industry, the honourable member for Murray (Mr Lloyd), has held several consultations with appropriate industry bodies and organisations, and they are supportive of these new arrangements.

In its impact, this legislation is not of major significance. However, the circumstances in which it is being debated, the tragic social and economic implications of the rural depression, must be of great concern to this Parliament. Whilst the debate in recent weeks has focused on the free trade and fair trade issues, and on the question of protection and tariffs, the horrendous impact of domestic costs has not received the attention it warrants.

TALK.START.PARA: —It should have.

—It should have indeed, and I will speak about that shortly. I guess this House would expect me today, in a debate on a Bill relating to primary industries, to comment on the wheat statement made today by the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Kerin). I believe that statement was a great snub to one of our great rural industries-an industry that has been affected by the Gulf war, by the sanctions that have been imposed on Iraq and generally by corrupt international trading practices.

SPEECH.PARA: Yet the Government's attitude to this great wheat industry, which has done so much to bolster and to stabilise the Australian economy over the years, is to provide welfare as the only answer for the wheat industry's problems. It has done nothing to come to grips with the promise the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) made in relation to compensation as a result of the Gulf war when he said that no one sector of Australian agriculture or any other industry would be picked out and expected to bear the burden of that war. Yet this is exactly what the wheat industry is being asked to bear.

That statement contained some guarantee for borrowings on past pools. An amount of money in excess of $300m is probably owed to the Australian wheat growers. However, that is what the industry is owed, and it should be paid that money now so that the Australian wheat growing fraternity will have confidence to plant adequate crops this year to meet the markets that we have built up over the years-markets in which we have credibility and which are stable markets for the Australian wheat industry, but which will be lost if we fail to produce an adequate quantity of wheat in the coming season.

My colleague the honourable member for Dawson (Mr Braithwaite) referred to the impact of domestic costs on Australian primary industry. Some 60 per cent of the cause of reduced incomes to rural industries today relates directly to our own internal structures on interest rates, on inflation, on outdated work practices and on the sustained and continuing attack on the productive sector and its assets. I therefore direct my comments on this legislation to just one of those outrageous rorts which are destroying a vital sector of our economy.

I refer to the Government's decision to recover the total cost of export and domestic inspection charges. This has shocked farmers and has further eroded our abattoirs, which in the past have been our most significant value added industry.

The Victorian meat industry is in a state of crisis. We are already suffering from the actions of the Victorian section of the Australasian Meat Industry Employees Union (AMIEU), which has seen this State go from having the largest kill with many abattoirs operating to the worst State in Australia with a loss of 17,000 jobs in this industry. Wally Curran, the Victorian boss of the Union, has now admitted that he has not only seen but in fact has written a critique on the original Victorian Government submission to the Harrison meat inquiries, despite denials that over recent weeks have come out of the Premier's office. It is now known that 11 pages of that submission containing industry statistics showing the poor performance of the Victorian meat processing sector and the high level of disputes were deleted from the final Government submission.

TALK.START.PARA: —Shame!

—Shame indeed! The fact that the meat industry itself has been the cause of a loss of so many thousands of jobs is something that the union members should take their leaders to task about. Thank goodness that the Victorian Minister for Labour, Mr Neil Pope, has had the courage to claim, and is correct in claiming, that the unions are running the Australian Labor Party (ALP) factions as they have obviously run ALP governments. It is now a case that if the AMIEU does not get you, the Commonwealth Meat Inspectors Association will. A Brooklyn abattoir in Victoria has been forced to close down the abattoir twice in a four-week period owing to members of the Meat Inspectors Association walking of the job.

SPEECH.PARA: If abattoir operators are going to have to pay the full cost of meat inspection, surely they should have the right to hire and fire or the Government should at least invoke an essential services Act to keep these important works operating. Members of this union today are holding export abattoirs to ransom and over recent years the number of stock being killed and abattoir employment in Victoria have very seriously declined as farmers are sending their stock interstate to be slaughtered. The Meat Inspectors Association and some public servants in Canberra have been responsible for adding millions of dollars to meat exports costs by frustrating continual attempts to streamline the meat inspection service, and these people who are refusing to work in Victoria and in Queensland may soon have no work to do because the cost of inspection has, as a result of this Government, increased by some 68.37 per cent from last January.

TALK.START.PARA: —Scandalous!

—It is a scandal, and it is a scandal that abattoir operators who had previously been paying $38,420 per year for a meat inspector are now paying $64,686 per year or $300 a day if hired on a casual basis. A veterinarian from the Australian Quarantine and Inspection Service costs $92,428 a year--
—And the farmer pays.

—The farmer and the consumer are paying 100 per cent of the inspection charges instead of the 60 per cent that originally existed under our previous coalition government. Of course, the worst aspect of the Government's increases is that the people paying the bill have absolutely no say and no input into the efficiency of this service. Indeed, many abattoir operators are being blackmailed by underworked inspectors who take turns to have days off.

SPEECH.PARA: Abattoir operators today are too frightened to speak out for fear of having their plants closed down or their meat condemned. Between the meat workers and the meat inspectors is it any wonder that the price of processing meat is so expensive? As an example, the cost of labour for slaughtering and processing beef in the United States of America is 10c a kilo; in Australia it is 45c per kilo. Even if our sheep today are given away, as they have been during the recent difficulties in the wool industry, it still costs about $13 a head to put them through an abattoir. The present inspection fees are so high that many abattoirs are having trouble paying their inspection bills, and this, of course, is being aggravated by the meat workers' strikes.

I have been advised that inspection services will be withdrawn unless these outstanding bills are paid, and this again will have an awful impact on the number of abattoirs. At this time of a crisis in the wool industry it is unbelievable that abattoirs have not been able to slaughter their usual number of sheep, let alone the additional numbers that have been required as a result of flock reduction programs.

The same position with inspection costs exists in many other industries. Inspection costs increased for grain, as an example, by up to 82.35 per cent. These increased costs come at a time when many grain growers are wondering whether their returns would even be enough to pay the planting costs for next season's crops. The cost of inspecting export grain has risen from 17c a tonne to 31c a tonne, and for bagged grain from 47c to 81c a tonne, which is an increase of almost 100 per cent. Containerised grain will cost $5 a tonne. In fact, today in some industries the cost of inspecting a container-load of some agricultural products is more than the value of the product itself in the container.

As an example, the cost of inspecting grain on ships will rise from $24 a half hour to $43 a half hour. In the dried fruit industry-an industry that is very important for the northern sector of my electorate, where we are fighting against cheap imports from Greece and Turkey-the Government is now going to charge $11 instead of $5 per quarter hour for an inspection, which is an increase of 120 per cent, and it will charge $100 per half hour in the field, an increase from $59 per half hour.

These Government increases could not have come at a worse time for the farming community, which is already on its knees. I call on the Government to delay the implementation of these charges to at least allow a more user accountable system to be established and to at least allow time for work practice reforms to take place in many of these industries that are so important to the future not just of rural Australia but also of the Australian economy.

Many inspectors who cost more today than the cost of employing a lawyer or a surgeon work only from Monday to Friday between the hours of 7.30 a.m. and 3.30 p.m., and after that they are on overtime. This is quite a ridiculous situation in regard to export and international trading arrangements today. Some companies would like two shifts a day. This would provide extra jobs for Australians and much needed export income, but because of the cost of inspectors who are on overtime rates this cannot be done. Surely it is time that the shackles were removed so that industry can obtain necessary supervision from reputable private independent companies-I understand for as low as $3.50 a tonne. Why should they be looking at prices of up to $20 per tonne from the Government service?

Export industries are today paying the total bill for the Australian inspection service and have absolutely no say in how it is run. The featherbedding of these services must stop, and they must be reminded that the major job is to help Australian exports and to keep plant and livestock diseases out.

With the national wage case currently under way, we are seeing industrial action again. Again we are seeing industrial action by the meatworkers at several export abattoirs as well as at our domestic plants. Union members have orchestrated several stoppages involving the Gilbertson group in the past fortnight; as well, there has been a stoppage at Wodonga Meats Pty Ltd over superannuation. A domestic abattoir at the country town of Stawell went on strike when employers would not agree to the accord.

While this strike action only further emphasises the poor state of industrial relations in this country, the stakes for our country have never been higher. The tragedy is that, while employers and the unions slug it out, the States and Australia lose valuable export dollars. A spokesman from the Gilbertson group, which handles about 35 per cent of the Victorian kill for export at its abattoirs at Kyle and Brooklyn, estimates that a day's stoppage costs Victoria $1m. In the last 2 1/4 years, the Gilbertson plants have had 124 days of industrial action, creating a total loss of income of about $100m. This has forced many export abattoirs to shut, some in my own electorate, and it has forced farmers to send their export livestock interstate to be slaughtered. The obvious consequences are enormous job losses for Victoria and an enormous impact on the domestic economy and the international economy of Australia.
In light of this serious situation affecting the Australian meat industry and the general economy of the nation, I move:
That all words after ``That'' be omitted with a view to substituting the following words:

``whilst not declining to give the Bill a second reading, the House is of the opinion that the renaming of the Australian Meat and Livestock Research and Development Corporation to the Meat Research Corporation will be of minimal effect unless the Government undertakes:
(1) to remedy the inefficiency and exorbitant costs associated with the current meat inspection system; and
(2) to ensure that industrial action by meat workers does not continue to cause serious disruption to the operation of abattoirs''.

TALK.START.PARA: -Is the amendment seconded?
—I second the amendment and reserve my right to speak.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Snow Mr J.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —Once again the Opposition has moved an amendment which is not appropriate to the legislation that we are talking about. On this occasion, when we are debating the Primary Industries Legislation Amendment Bill, the Opposition has attacked the Government for not taking action where the Opposition itself failed to take action over 30 years of government. Here in the meat industry we see a situation where the Opposition is condemning the Government for the inefficiency and exorbitant costs associated with the current meat inspection system and trying to ensure that industrial action by meatworkers does not continue to cause serious disruption to the operation of abattoirs.

SPEECH.PARA: As in the case of waterfront industry, which we spoke about in a previous debate today, once again this Government has taken decisive action. The Australian Quarantine and Inspection Service (AQIS) has taken over the role of inspection, a role which was carried out by the States, and it has been able to reduce staffing by 500 positions. AQIS is currently reviewing positions and procedures. Once again the Opposition is condemning the Government for actions which are being taken by this Government and which were not taken by the previous conservative administration.

The Government and the States have recognised the fact that it has been extremely costly to have a system operating with both Federal and State governments involved in a range of services, not least in the meat industry. There is a major review of the domestic meat industry under way. The honourable member for Mallee (Mr Peter Fisher) has not acknowledged that, and it is certainly not acknowledged in the amendment that he has moved. In addition, the Australian Quarantine and Inspection Service has taken a range of actions which will ensure that there is much more efficiency within the industry.

The second part of the amendment moved by the Opposition refers to the need to ensure that industrial action by meatworkers does not continue to cause serious disruption to the operation of abattoirs, once again failing to recognise the fact that an inquiry has been set up by the Australian Industrial Relations Commission under Commissioner Harrison to look at industrial relations in the meat industry. The people involved in that inquiry are looking at a range of issues, particularly the tally system, so important work is being done to reduce the costs that are occurring in the meat industry.

The reforms which have been undertaken were not fostered by the conservative parties. I appreciate the point that has been made by the honourable member for Mallee that costs can be reduced; that is why AQIS is having a major review of domestic meat inspection and that is why in the area of industrial relations action is being taken under the Harrison inquiry into the meat industry. I acknowledge also what the honourable member for Mallee has said about the difficulties in the areas that are mentioned under the legislation-the meat and livestock research and development area and the areas of dairy farming and horticulture. Government economic policies are not the only answer to the problems that exist in each of these areas. Profound changes have occurred throughout the world. But there is hope. Since the beginning of 1990, official interest rates have dropped about 6 per cent. This is gradually being reflected in general interest rates. A number of micro-economic reforms initiated by the Government will be of assistance to people in the country, including farmers. Reforms in train to see average crew sizes on Australian trading ships reduced substantially-down 36 per cent under this Government-will make an enormous difference to the viability of farming, because it will decrease export costs. Reforms in train in the towage industry will result in a 25 per cent reduction in the towage labour force and cost savings approaching $20m a year.

As a result of the National Terminals (Australia) Ltd agreement, 300 surplus NTAL employees in Melbourne and Sydney have recently left the industry. The union agreement, which I understand will give rise to a further 60 early retirements, is currently being examined by the Waterfront Industry Reform Authority to confirm that it meets the Government's guidelines for productivity and efficiency improvements.

I believe that the Opposition has been opportunistic, knowing full well that the Government is proceeding with these inquiries and reviews and taking actions which ought to have been taken many years ago. SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cowan Mr D.B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to join in this debate because I feel the Primary Industries Legislation Amendment Bill is rather important. I certainly want to support the amendment moved by the honourable member for Mallee (Mr Peter Fisher). At the same time, I congratulate him on many of the facts that he, as the acting opposition spokesman for primary industry, has brought forward. When we look at the amendment and the facts that were brought out, we fully appreciate that there are many problems within the primary industries today. I want to deal with a few of these because I think they are most important.

SPEECH.PARA: The Bill deals briefly with the changing of names in connection with research of the Australian Meat and Livestock Research and Development Corporation, the Dairy Produce Act and also the Horticultural Research and Development Corporation Act. These are minor matters so far as we are concerned, but they are important. Hidden behind these changes is the economic situation that confronts Australia today and the fact that our primary industries are the important industries that can get our economy back on track. I believe that the honourable member for Mallee has exposed only some of the problems that government can attend to in order to help overcome both our present economic difficulties and the world situation.

Part of the Bill before the House refers to equal opportunity for females within these corporate bodies. I do not think we oppose that in any way. It falls into line with legislation relating to other statutory authorities. But I take the opportunity to pay a tribute to those women who work within the primary industries. I think this gives us the opportunity to do that. I am speaking of the family farm that is basically the backbone of agriculture today in Australia, and I trust will be over many years ahead. If one goes on the farm today, one finds that the wife of the farmer-and even the children, the daughters and the sons, of the farmer-shares the responsibility of running and working a property.

I have been closely related to the dairy industry and the grazing industry. In my electorate, these are most important industries. If one goes onto a dairy farm today, one finds in most cases that the wife is in the bales in the morning and assisting with milking the cows in the afternoon. We often find her out getting the cows in, cultivating the ground, driving the tractor and doing all the jobs that are associated with the running of a farm. I pay tribute to the wives of the farmers of Australia who are playing an unnoticed but most important part in primary industries within this country.

Research programs are very important to the future of Australia. They are very important in relation to obtaining better quality commodities that are produced from our soil. I say `better commodities' simply because many of the products are marketed here domestically within Australia. Our people are always increasing their demands for better quality fruit and vegetables, grain, dairy products, beef and the like. Research assists us here at home, but also assists us in our export of the products. That is why I believe that research is so very important.

It is disappointing for me to see that for 15 years or so the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation (CSIRO) has devoted less funding to research into primary industries, particularly matters affecting the farm. This is of concern to the industries themselves. I ask the Government to have a look at the next Budget to see whether its funds can be increased. The CSIRO is a very important research group within Australia. It studies various matters relating to noxious weeds, animals and the production per acre on the farm. We cannot at any time overlook the contribution that is made by private industry into research. I think that there is a responsibility on the Government to increase the funding of CSIRO and for us to support what it actually does.

Let me turn to horticulture for a moment. I went to Russia about 18 months ago. We went to a research farm which grew 1,000 different species of grapes, 450 of these species being seedless grapes. They grew about 400 different types of plums. Great research in some of these countries is being undertaken into production, not only to get extra quantity but also to improve the quality of the various types of plums both that housewives use for cooking purposes and that people eat, about which we are very concerned. Australia may be up with this type of research, but I do not believe that we are. We are an agricultural nation that is so very dependent on what we turn out of the soil.

I reiterate that primary industry is not fully recognised as it should be in this country. What support does government basically give to primary industry outside of research? As the honourable member for Mallee mentioned this afternoon, the Government has withdrawn the inspection fees on export beef at a period when producers in this country are at a worldwide disadvantage. There is no use us sending a delegation of Ministers, or even the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke), overseas to talk to the United States of America or the European Economic Community when we have a situation where those countries have no intention in the long term to reduce support for their producers and consumers. This is the important fact to remember. We know that we are efficient upon the farm, but if there is a problem, as there is in the wheat industry at present-we are going through a crisis also in the wool industry-we are saying grudgingly that the Government has to come to its support; and it is in most of cases. The Opposition strongly supports this.

I do not want to belong to any political party-my own Party included-unless we are prepared to go out on a limb to support the various forms of primary industry that we have in Australia. It is very important to this economy and to our soil, which is what we live on-it is the lifeblood of our land. When we talk about research in relation to these Bills, only 0.05 per cent of research funding goes into the Bill about which we are talking. That is the maximum that the Government will contribute.

Let us look at the other support that the Government gives to primary industry in this country. We get a rebate on diesel fuel, certainly, and there are other little forms of assistance. I hope that the wheat industry will receive a large form of assistance. But we should compare what is given in Australia with what is given in other countries which our farmers have to compete against. This is the important fact: our farmer is working his family farm and has his money tied up in the capital of that property-in his stock and plant-and he has to compete with other countries. So we had better be a little more open-minded than we are today with regard to the needs of our farmer and the important role that he plays so far as our national economy is concerned.

When I say that I know that the leading farm organisations within Australia are saying, `We want to stand upon our own feet'. Can farmers stand upon their own feet when we go overseas and find that other countries are dumping and are supporting their farmers so much financially? I look across the floor at a couple of Government members-one has only just been to Washington-and I am sure that we all think alike on this matter. I am sure that we appreciate the importance of primary industry in Australia.

The farmer does not want a handout, but he wants to know that he has friends in government and opposition who are prepared to come to his aid if needs be. This is important. When I say `if needs be', I mean in comparison with other assistance which is granted throughout the world. If we are going to compete fairly, assistance has to be there for farmers. Many farmers today have bank mortgages, averaging, I think, about $220,000 each, and this has grown enormously in the last few years.

Our seasons have not been too bad recently; we have had a few good years. But what happens if this situation reverses? That is what we have to think about. We are not spending money on water resources within Australia in the way that we should because of the environmentalists around the place who are saying, `You must not disturb the ducks and the waterhens and all of these types of things which we see running around the property'. I have dams on my farm and I have plenty of ducks and waterhens. The ducks are eating the pasture but I will not shoot them and I do not want anybody else to shoot them. I protect them. But we have to look at our water resources program which is so tied to this legislation which we are discussing today. Between the Commonwealth and the States, the program amounts to virtually nil. What are we doing to assist a farmer to go in for water resource conservation on his own property? What taxation concessions are we giving farmers? I do not think we are giving them very much, if anything at all.

Farmers want to write off their costs over a period of years. We should allow farmers to say, `I want to write it off over one, two, three or five years'-whatever is of benefit to them. All of these factors could lead one to talk, I am sure, for hours about the need that we have today to support the farmer. As I have said, we do not disagree with the Bills before the House, but we take the opportunity to point out to the Government that there is a need to support the primary producer. There is a principle that is very closely involved with this need. Many farmers are in a desperate plight at present and if we can help them to produce extra, better quality commodities from each hectare of land, I believe that we will be achieving something. Undoubtedly, the people who are involved with primary industry in this land know where they are going. I do not think any of us in this House would deny that. I am pleased to support the amendment and I am pleased to support the legislation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Courtice Mr B.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Primary Industries Legislation Amendment Bill contains a number of minor administrative amendments to existing legislation. Firstly, the amendments to the Australian Meat and Livestock Research and Development Corporation Act 1985 will change the name of the AMLRDC to the Meat Research Corporation. This Bill also brings the AMLRDC into line with other rural research and development bodies by confining the Government's commitment to match industry funding for the Corporation to 0.5 per cent of gross value of production.

SPEECH.PARA: We are all aware of the great work done by the various research and development corporations. Work in an abattoir has always been messy, hard and dangerous. But things are about to change. The AMLRDC, as the funding body, has launched Fututech, an Australian semi-automated slaughtering system, which offers a more humane process for animals, better conditions for workers and savings of up to 30 per cent for the Australian meat industry.

Slaughtering technology has remained basically unchanged for 50 years. However, Fututech is expected to revolutionise the process completely. By reducing the amount of arduous, dirty work for the abattoir workers, Fututech will also contribute to savings in health and safety costs which amount to about $330m a year in the meat industry. Fututech has evolved from the research and development carried out by Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation staff at the CSIRO Meat Research Laboratory. It is a uniquely Australian invention and a good example of the way in which a research organisation and a funding body can pool their resources and attract considerable commercial interest. The Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) says that we need a clever country. Fututech shows what can be done with Australian research and funding in an industry which is not one of the trendy industries that we hear so much about but which has done more than its share over the years to assist the Australian economy.

With the first phase of the liberalisation of the Japanese beef industry about to commence shortly, we need to have an efficient beef industry. Every piece of research and development that can give us that little competitive edge will help us get more beef into the Japanese market. For almost 20 years Japan has been Australia's second largest beef export market. During this period, Australian exporters have serviced a market which has been controlled by the Japanese Government. Australia's export performance to Japan over the last three years has been very encouraging and we are now well-placed and in a good position to take advantage of the opportunities that will arise in a more liberalised market.

While I concede that the tariff will phase down slowly over a period of time and that it is not as liberalised as we would like, it will still give consumers an opportunity to purchase Australian beef. I believe that, as more and more people take up that opportunity, pressure will be applied-through the consumer movement in countries such as Japan-to governments to liberalise more of their markets. Obviously, we stand to be beneficiaries if that is the case.

There is no doubt that liberalisation of the Japanese market, the termination of the tender system and the departure of the Japanese Livestock Industry Promotion Corporation as the central buying authority will bring about fundamental changes in marketing and distribution and consumption of beef in Japan. Future prospects depend very much upon the way in which suppliers in Australia and the trade in Japan work together to adjust quickly to the changing circumstances and capitalise on the growth prospects.

I would also like to touch briefly on the amendment to the Dairy Produce Act 1986. This amendment will include equal employment opportunity provisions in the Act and bring the Australian Dairy Corporation into line with existing Government policy on equal employment opportunity.

I strongly concur with the introduction of equal employment opportunity. I have four ladies working in my electorate offices. Unfortunately, members of the National Party of Australia in my electorate are not so open minded. The Leader of the National Party in Monto, Jeff Seeney, recently attacked my press secretary in a number of rural newspapers calling her my `minder'. They will probably attack my cat and dog next. The Government is implementing its commitment to improve the status of women by paying attention to their needs and rights in its broader programs and by implementing specific initiatives for women. The International Labour Organisation Convention No. 111 binds the Australian Government to seek to eliminate discrimination on seven grounds-race, colour, sex, religion, political opinion, national extraction and social origin-in the areas of employment and occupation.

This Bill further requires amendments to the Dairy Produce Act 1986 and to the Dairy Produce Levy (No. 1) Act 1986. The Australian Dairy Industry Conference Inc. has decided to change its name to the Australian Dairy Industry Council Incorporated. It has also decided that its executive council will in future be known as its executive.

The amendments to the Horticultural Research and Development Corporation Act 1987 provide for minor changes to the commercial role, administrative controls and accountability of the Horticultural Research and Development Corporation (HRDC). The Corporation's functions and powers are amended to include the commercialisation and dissemination of research and development and the power to join in the formation of a company. Its ability to acquire, hold, and dispose of real and personal property is also extended. The objects of the HRDC include: to improve the efficiency and competitiveness of Australian horticultural industries; to develop awareness by these industries of the contribution that can be made by research and development; and to make more effective use of resources available for research and development.

The honourable member for Eden-Monaro (Mr Snow) very competently covered the reasons why the Government does not support the amendment moved by the Deputy Leader of the National Party, the honourable member for Murray (Mr Lloyd). Basically, my view is that the amendment is irrelevant to the changing of the name.

I would like to make a few other points. By paying the 100 per cent and having a greater say in input, I believe that the industry will be able to better work towards more efficiency. This year there has been a discount of $27m with regard to meat inspection. With regard to the concern over industrial action in the meatworks, it is true that none of us want to see industrial action. That is why we have the accord and the Australian Industrial Relations Commission. In fact, as the honourable member for Eden-Monaro said, the Industrial Relations Commission is looking at the meat industry specifically to see whether there are ways in which we can reduce the amount of industrial disputation.

There is no doubt that we have to try at all times to get our costs down, providing that it is done on a fair basis. One of the previous speakers mentioned the difference in slaughter costs between the United States and Australia. While I mentioned earlier that the breakthrough in research and development in the slaughtering process will be not only innovative but also cost saving, I would like to make one point with regard to the difference in the costs of slaughter in the United States. In a lot of those meatworks in that country cheap and, in some instances, illegal Mexican labour is used. People are entitled to a sell their labour at a decent price. We have a civilised system in Australia through the accord and the Industrial Relations Commission whereby people do get a reasonable wage. On the same basis, people should be responsible when it comes to industrial disputation. As I have said, the Industrial Relations Commission is looking at ways of improving that. Consequently, I think that that is a positive step.

One of the big cost saving measures in the long haul-something which has not been tackled in the past because it has been too hard but which this Government is tackling-is waterfront reform, including shipping reform and an integrated transport system in cooperation with the six States. That is not something which will happen overnight or by waving a magic wand. If that were the case, it would have been achieved 10 or 20 years ago. Somebody would have just woken up one morning and said, `I have a great idea: let us fix the transport system in this country', and it would have been done. But that is not the case. It will take a long, hard slog to achieve it and we will achieve it only if we work together.

In the long term there will be massive savings-something like $4 billion-in a better integrated transport system in this country. It will mean massive savings for farmers in getting better efficiency from farm gate to market-whether it be domestic or overseas-by virtue of a better and more efficient waterfront and shipping industry. But it will be done only in consultation; it will not be achieved by belting someone over the head with a hammer.

With regard to irrigation and better water, like the honourable member for Lyons (Mr Burr), I, as a farmer, understand some of the vagaries of drought and the consequences that it has for us. Just before I came into this House, I received word of some good news with regard to this issue. In my own area, a grant of $30,000 has been approved to improve the quality of the water supply at Mulgildie in the Monto shire. The money is provided under the Federal country towns water supply improvement program, COWSIP. The project is estimated to cost some $90,000. Mulgildie has suffered from a poor water supply for many years. Since 1985-86, the COWSIP program in Queensland has funded 11 projects valued at more than $22m with a total Commonwealth contribution of almost $8m. These projects have provided improved water supplies for more than 15,000 people.

I do concede that that is not what the honourable member for Lyons was talking about, but it is part of the whole program of supplying water for domestic use. It is a part of the whole process, but it is slightly different from what the honourable member for Lyons mentioned. I concede that in the driest continent on earth we do need to conserve and make optimum use of our water.

One of the great breakthroughs in the horticultural industry has been through the use of trickle irrigation which cuts down the amount of water needed by about a third. I am sure that in the electorate of the honourable member for Mallee (Mr Peter Fisher), who is at the table, drip irrigation is now being used, resulting in a massive conservation of water. It puts water into the right place. Instead of weeds being watered, only the plant is watered. With research and development these are ways in which we can overcome many of those problems.

In conclusion, I would like to mention something that has been topical recently-the visit of the Australian delegation to Washington, led by the Minister for Trade and Overseas Development (Dr Blewett). Also in the delegation were the shadow Minister for trade and trade negotiations, the honourable member for Mayo (Mr Downer); the shadow Minister for primary industry, the honourable member for Murray; Mr John Allwright, the President of the National Farmers Federation; and I. Last Thursday and Friday we met with representatives of the United States Congress, the Senate and members of the Bush administration. I was very pleased with the bipartisan approach that was undertaken and the response and respect that we were shown.

While we recognised that the export enhancement program (EEP) will continue while the Europeans have their corrupted markets, we tried to convince Congress not to increase the cap. It is looking at another $475m. If there is an increase, either up to the full amount or part thereof, the EEP does not directly impact against our markets. We were all very pleased that Carla Hills, who is the ambassador and principal adviser to the President on international trade, gave an undertaking that all efforts will be made to ensure that EEP does not impact on our traditional markets. The Middle East in particular was one of those areas of concern. In the long haul, what is important and is recognised by all of us and the United States is that we need to have a successful conclusion to the Uruguay Round so that we can start to break down those trade barriers that are affecting us through the European Community. No matter what we do in this country, the actions of overseas countries in dumping and subsidies will impact on our agriculture. Having such a small population, having to rely so heavily on export markets for our large major primary industries, we are always vulnerable to the vagaries of world markets. That is why we have been so forceful in the Cairns Group in efforts to get some commonsense into the trade sphere.

In the longer haul, I believe we will get some common sense into the trade sphere, but it is going to be hard work. Again, like the integrated transport system, it is not something that is going to happen overnight and it will only happen with a lot of goodwill. As I said, I was very pleased with the bipartisan approach and, of course, the very genuine approach of John Allwright, which enabled us to get that concession. Whilst it was not everything that some people may have wished for, I think it is a concession that farmers will be pleased with. But we recognise the serious effect that this trade war is having on our farmers. We made that very clear to Senator Richard Lugar and the seven or eight members of Congress we met with in that brief time, plus representatives of the United States State Department and members of the Bush administration.

However, I believe that by working together we can achieve a successful round in Brussels and, if we do, of course it is going to be beneficial in the long term. Nevertheless, we do recognise the impact that this is having now on our primary producers. In conclusion, I do oppose the amendment moved by the National Party and support the Government.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will very briefly refer to some of the comments made by previous speakers in this debate. The honourable member for Eden-Monaro (Mr Snow) referred to the fact that the coalition did not acknowledge the inquiries that were taking place in the meat industry. SPEECH.PARA: I say to the honourable member for Hinkler that it is not true that by paying 100 per cent of inspection charges the industry will have a greater say. I welcome the comments that were made by the honourable member for Lyne (Mr Cowan) about the equal opportunity provisions in this Bill. He also referred to the horrendous burden many women are carrying at this particular time of crisis in many parts of the rural sector.

There are certain radical groups who see the current phenomenon of an increasing number of women in the work force as important. I would like to put a slightly different view, that in agriculture this is not a success story but an indication of the failure of our social and economic system where women who have been a partner in farming activities and who have formed a very valuable part of agricultural pursuits are working not to achieve some new career aim but because the chosen career that they took up with their partners is being destroyed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Howard The Hon J.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, I seek your indulgence to make a personal explanation.
-Does the honourable member claim to have been misrepresented?
—Yes, I do.
—The honourable member may proceed.

—My claim of misrepresentation arises out of an article written by John O'Neill which appeared in various forms today in the Sydney Morning Herald and the Melbourne Age regarding the media ownership issue in Australia and, in particular, the ownership concentration accruing to Mr Murdoch's News Ltd.

SPEECH.PARA: My concern relates to certain remarks attributed in the article to the former Prime Minister, Mr Fraser, regarding my handling of amendments to the Trade Practices Act which he alleges were material to the later concentration of media ownership in Mr Murdoch's hands. In particular, Mr Fraser alleged that I had, in effect, misled his Cabinet in 1977 in proposing amendments to the merger provisions of the Act which undeniably watered down those provisions.

I reject that allegation attributed to Mr Fraser in the articles to which I have referred. I specifically reject his charge that the advice for which I had responsibility was inept, to use the word that has been quoted. I make the point that what I put to the Cabinet at that time and what was self-evident was that we were changing the merger provision to take out a requirement that the provision be triggered if there was a lessening of competition and replacing it with a requirement, which I think survives until today, that the provision is only triggered if a company is in a position analogous to a monopoly position, that is, in a position to control or dominate the market.
In amplification of my denial, I point out to the House that when the decision was taken I put out a release, as Minister for Business and Consumer Affairs, dated 5 April 1977 which read:
Mr Howard said that the amendment bill would significantly alter the merger provision of the Act.

In future, the only mergers which would be covered by the Trade Practices Act would be those which involved a company already in a monopoly position-as defined by the Act-or would as a result of the merger be in that position.

I simply observe that it would pass strange that somebody would tell a Cabinet that there would be no material change, yet that very afternoon release a press statement acknowledging that it amounted to a significant change. The allegation that I misled that Cabinet is wrong and I deny it.

TALK.START.PARA: -I understand that it is the wish of the House to debate concurrently the annual report of the Department of Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs with orders of the day Nos 5 and 6, the first report of the Joint Standing Committee on Migration Regulations and the ministerial statement on the migration legislation review. DEBATE.TITLE: DEPARTMENT OF IMMIGRATION, LOCAL GOVERNMENT AND ETHNIC AFFAIRS

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ruddock Mr P.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The House is debating cognately, with the annual report of the Department of Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs, the first report of the Joint Standing Committee on Migration Regulations and the Government response, and the ministerial statement on the Migration Legislation Review, which is essentially a statement of the Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs (Mr Hand) dated 9 May 1990. Obviously, this will be a wide ranging debate on matters relating to immigration. While I may constrain my own comments particularly to the review of migration legislation, honourable members may well range widely in this discussion. It seems to me there would be no proper basis to constrain such discussion, given the wide range of issues that are addressed in the Department's annual report.

SPEECH.PARA: I want to use this opportunity, some 10 months after the Minister made his statement to this House, to review the document. When one looks at a document of this sort some 10 months later and when one is led to believe that it was to be a major statement on behalf of the Government, one sees how amazingly deficient the Government has been in consider- ation of the issues then raised.

Mr Deputy Speaker, you may recall that the Government, with the assistance of the Opposition, saw passed in June 1989 amendments to the Migration Act, and subsequently regulations were introduced and operated from 19 December 1989 in order to give effect to that new legislative schema. What occurred was a rushed legislative outcome and one which was severely defective. When I have addressed this topic in the past I have said that, in my view, the Minister having said that it would be a trial and error approach, we have ended up with an approach more of error than trial. We had Minister Hand's apologia on behalf of the Government when he in fact said that the Government had decided to act upon a number of criticisms and voiced concerns and that he intended to make some changes to regulations immediately. Minister Hand, after the election, acknowledged that the program of law reform was severely flawed.

When I examine in detail the Minister's statement, which starts at page 136 of Hansard, I see that he gave a number of excuses. He said that the body of law under the amended legislation was `much compressed' in time. He also said:
This resulted in a lack of clarity, and, in a number of cases, unintended consequences.
If one was looking for a lexicon of excuses for legislative failure, this speech contained it. He then went on to say that as Senator Robert Ray, his predecessor, had said:
. . . it would be necessary continually to monitor the regulations and amend them as problems emerged.

He went on to add that the Government had basic objectives and that they were being met, particularly the objective of keeping a non-discriminatory migration program in place. He also commented on maintaining an appropriate balance, introducing certainty into the law but also ensuring that adequate discretion was maintained to enable the Government `to respond sensitively and with compassion when individual cases arise that require special consideration'.

If one reads this speech, as I have done, one will come to the view that the matter upon which I addressed this Parliament at considerable length-and that was that a schema be put in place that ensured some continued capacity to deal with matters by way of discretion-was being addressed. One will be very surprised to note, as I have been, that there has in the intervening period been only one occasion upon which the Minister has, pursuant to section 137 of the Migration Act, tabled in this Parliament a statement wherein he exercised his power.

I do not intend to canvass at length the particular circumstances in which the Minister did exercise that power. I have reviewed the report that he gave to the Parliament. What is so interesting is that this was the first and only case in which I am aware of the Minister having actually exercised discretion under the Act. He tabled that statement in the Parliament in the last sitting weeks.

The fact is that the Minister foreshadowed in his ministerial statement that he intended to make a number of significant changes. He said that they would be undertaken in three phases. If we look at those three phases, we find in relation to the first phase that he said that there would be immediate changes including a number of technical changes which have minor policy and procedural implications. He also said that he would reinstate the Immigration Review Tribunal, and those decisions have been largely taken.

But when we go on we find that the Minister foreshadowed a Bill to ensure that his discretion to make a decision after the first tier could be exercised only at the request of the applicant and he outlined specific legislative changes; yet we have not seen those proposals. He went on to say that he intended to:
. . . report to Parliament every six months on any intervention at any decision-making stage in respect of applications for visas and entry permits.
He added:
My reporting will cover an analysis and cataloguing of cases determined by me and will contain my conclusions about possible needs to amend existing regulations or make new regulations.
As I have indicated, the Minister has brought forward one case in all that time where he has exercised such discretion. He went on to say:
My reporting will also include Immigration Review Tribunal comments about the impact of the regulations in the light of the cases that come before them.

There was one matter in which the Immigration Review Tribunal over a period has indicated that the legislative process was flawed, and that was in relation to concessional migrant entry cases wherein the spouse of any applicant was always assessed against the points score in order to determine whether a case would be successful or otherwise and that, in many cases, would be an important factor.

It was a longstanding policy of both this Government and former governments to deal with those matters in that way. When these regulations were introduced, that schema was not put in place. So the Tribunal said that, where these cases arose, it considered that the Department of Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs could not consider them on the basis of considering both parties to a marriage when looking at the points score because it would be illegal to do so. There was no report on that matter to the Parliament by the Minister. The Minister merely implemented regulations for change-and yet he promised on 9 May that he would be making such regular reports to this House. The Minister went on:
. . . I will reduce the complexity of the application procedures by collapsing the current 97 entry permit classes down to a possible seven . . .

He would not have done that without advice that it was possible, yet we have not seen that statement implemented by the Minister. The Minister then went on to talk about the second and third phases. I suggest that, if the current timetable is being followed, there is little expectation that the second and third phases, which would involve a general redrafting of the regulations, are likely to be implemented at all quickly-and that is a matter of very considerable concern.

The Minister also indicated that he would be dealing promptly with refugee and humanitarian cases. To date, we have not seen any legislative changes; nor have we seen from this Minister any statement as to the way in which the Government intends to deal in a comprehensive way with this difficult and ongoing situation. We have a backlog of 7,000 applications, yet to date there have been no new regulations introduced to deal with the consideration of refugee issues and humanitarian issues which the Minister has foreshadowed in subsequent statements.

There are a large number of grants of resident status after entry applications. It is possible that these cases and the refugee cases will significantly distort the program for migration entry. There are news reports appearing daily in which expectations are being built up about the way that the refugee program will be dealt with, and yet we have not seen any announcement from this Minister as to how these problems are likely to be addressed.

Last Friday in the Sydney Morning Herald there was the report: `Govt to let in up to 14,000 refugees from Gulf War'. In that article, by-lined by Mr Col Allison, certain statements were sourced to an official of the Department of Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs, Jenny Hoskin. I do not know the young lady, but it is recorded that, about refugees, she said:
. . . there were thousands of them in camps in Jordan, Saudi Arabia and Kuwait.
``There are others still on the move and in due course those in fear of their lives, if forced to return to Iraq, will be processed by the UN High Commissioner for Refugees . . .
She went on to say:
However, we are already geared up for immigration emergencies and have allocated extra places, 12,000 to 14,000 of them, for Middle Eastern people as a result of the Gulf War.

That statement caused considerable alarm in Sydney with the matter being raised frequently on talkback radio last weekend. Yet there has been no clarification by the Minister as to the portent of that statement. It seems to me that it is probably a flawed statement that has been made in this instance.

I cannot imagine that the Government, without any formal announcement, would be doubling the number of refugee cases that we are likely to have to take. Australia had some 11,000 places dealt with in the Government's announced statement last year, and in the material given to the parliamentary committee the program composition was broken down further. Some 4,100 were to be Indo-Chinese; 1,800 were to be Latin-American; from eastern Europe there were to be 300; from the Middle East-taking out the Afghan people and the Lebanese concession-a total of 300; from Africa, 200; and there was also a global unallocated program amongst it. So effectively from some 300 places for refugees from the Middle East we have this speculation that the Government has already allocated an extra 12,000 to 14,000 places for Middle Eastern people as a result of the Gulf war. A matter of that sort is of very considerable moment.

I issued a statement last week seeking clarification from the Minister on this matter, but no clarification has been forthcoming. We have this difficult ongoing situation with this Government and this Minister wherein important decisions remain unannounced. We have the Government's statement on what progress it intended to make in the area of regulatory reform and on that matter it has failed to follow its own program. These are important issues of ministerial performance. They warrant a full and detailed statement to this House by the Minister. I certainly hope that at an appropriate time in the context of this debate the Minister will intervene and endeavour to ensure that the House is informed of these matters and that a full and complete statement will fully clarify the issue of any large expansion of Middle Eastern refugee places.

If there is a proper case to be made out the Opposition would, of course, regard it as being an appropriate response. But the people of Australia are entitled to know the basis upon which the Government comes to such a view, if that is what it has done. To date we have not heard any announcement, or been acquainted with any reasons, as to why the Government should have made such a decision.
