SPEECH.SPEAKER: Theophanous Dr A.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker, we have been discussing three documents here-the review of the Department of Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs, the report of the Joint Standing Committee on Migration Regulations, Illegal entrants in Australia: Balancing control and compassion, and the statement on review of migration legislation of the Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs (Mr Hand).

SPEECH.PARA: Before the dinner break we heard from the honourable member for Dundas (Mr Ruddock), the shadow Minister for immigration and ethnic affairs, about these three major documents. All we got from the shadow Minister were nitpicking little points which really had very little to do with anything at all, when I must say I thought that a large number of issues on immigration could have been raised. I am really surprised that such an opportunity was allowed to slip by the shadow Minister.

On one of the points he raised he was factually wrong. He said that the Minister had not done his duty because he had only presented one case to the Parliament in relation to his powers under the new Act. But he did not bother to check how many cases the Minister had had or had dealt with under the new Act. The fact is that very few cases have gone through the whole process under the new Act, and-surprise, surprise-only one case has gone to the Minister and been decided upon. Therefore it was ludicrous to claim that the Minister was not doing his duty because he had only reported on one case in relation to the Act.

Rather than waste the time of the Parliament with this nitpicking as the shadow Minister did, I intend to bring to the attention of honourable members the way in which a number of issues have been dealt with, in my view in a very commendable way, by the Minister through the processes of these reports, and to indicate the way forward in terms of migration legislation.

In terms of the report of the Joint Standing Committee on Migration Regulations, the first thing that need to be said is this: although the report was criticised at the time as having a number of points of view-which occasionally happens in parliamentary committees, this being a democracy-the fact is that the Minister adopted most, although not all, of the recommendations of the majority view. Where he differed from the majority view he made it perfectly clear. The outcome in terms of illegal entrants has been what the report was trying to achieve in the first place-a balance of control and compassion. The new regulations on illegal entrants have achieved that result; there is now a balance between control and compassion in relation to the way in which illegal entrants are treated in this country.

The Minister has made it clear that those people who think that they can cheat and get round the system have another think coming. More resources have been put into control and under this Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs we are taking control seriously. At the same time the genuine cases, the compassionate cases, are able to go to the Minister, through various mechanisms, to be dealt with. So we have achieved a positive result in what was a complex and difficult issue.

I believe that the processes-firstly, the parliamentary Committee, followed by the Minister's discussions with the Caucus committee, and the decisions that finally resulted-were the proper processes, and ones of which we can be reasonably proud in terms of dealing with this area. An index of how successful this has been is the way in which these provisions have been widely accepted, not only in the broad community, but also within ethnic communities, which have recognised that we have to do something about control, whilst at the same time recognising that we have put into place mechanisms to deal with the need for compassion. So it is important that we recognise that this is what has taken place in this particular area.

The parliamentary Committee did not stop there. Because the Minister requested it, it went on to make a set of interim recommendations in relation to the question of marriage. The full report on marriage will be presented to this Parliament shortly. The Committee put forward recommendations in relation to marriage and change of status on the basis of marriage. Again, this is one of the most difficult areas in immigration. People have a right to marry and stay in Australia if in fact the marriage is genuine-even when they are visitors.

One simple solution that was given to us was the idea that everyone should be forced to go back overseas and reapply, even when he or she had married an Australian. We did not think that was in accordance with principles of social justice, so we put into place a recommendation which has been adjusted from the recommendations of the Committee. We suggested a two-year rule for de factos, and that has now been extended to marriages as well. Thus we have now introduced two-year conditional entry.

Whilst referring to this, I have to say that I am concerned about the fact that this matter has not been sufficiently publicised by the media. There are still insufficient numbers of people in the community aware of the fact that we have introduced the two-year rule. There are still visitors coming to Australia who believe that by marrying an Australian they will automatically get permanent residence. This is not the case.

The situation is as follows: if a person comes to Australia on a visitor's visa and marries an Australian, that person will be able to apply for a change of status. However, in the first instance the status that will be granted to that person will be conditional entry for two years. Then two criteria must be met. Only if the marriage lasts for those two years, and if, in the intervening period, the Department of Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs has made a judgment that the marriage is a genuine marriage, will that person be able to stay in Australia permanently, and apply for permanent residence after the two years has elapsed.

It is important that the community knows more about this, because visitors to Australia still go to the offices of members of Parliament and say, `I have married an Australian, and I want to stay here permanently'. We have to make it clear to them that that is no longer an automatic path, that they must meet those two provisions-that of genuineness, and that of the two-year requirement. This matter ought to be more widely disseminated in the community so that people do not believe that the situation which existed before, namely, permanent residency through sham marriages, will continue in the future. This whole process has been put into place to ensure that these sham marriages will not continue to be used. I hope that we will be able to publicise this matter more widely.

I believe that the determinations that were made on the basis of consultations between the Minister, the Joint Committee on Migration Regulations and the Caucus committee, have resulted in what is a fair system. Of significance is the fact that a category of conditional entry has been introduced into the system, something I have been talking about for some time. Conditional entry is a very important category because we may be able to use it to solve some other, more difficult problems in the area of immigration. It is a common category in other countries, but it had not existed in our immigration system until these arrangements were put into place.

The shadow Minister has talked about how the Minister promised legislation, yet was not able to bring forward that legislation. There are problems with legislative timetables. The honourable member for Dundas would not be aware of that problem. There are other problems associated with legislation.

The fact is that there has been no hold-up in implementing any of the programs. All of the programs announced by the Minister have been implemented, notwithstanding that the necessary legislation has not yet been passed. The shadow Minister should be pleased to know that shortly the Government will introduce legislation aimed at meeting the requirements he outlined. I hope the shadow Minister will actually debate the questions when that legislation is introduced rather than continue with the quibbles he gave during his contribution to the debate earlier today.

I want to bring to the attention of the House some of the problems which the Department has had to face on the introduction of the new regulations. The Department has had to come to grips with a tremendous number of changes in the past 15 months. I cite as examples the introduction of new regulations, new ways of processing applications, changes to the regulations, and new ways of dealing with applications. All of these processes are difficult.

While there are individuals in some sections of the Department who may not have treated people as well as they ought to have done, in general, given the enormous number of changes that have occurred in the administration of immigration in this country in the past 15 months, the Department has done a good job. The shadow Minister should have at least acknowledged the excellent job most officers of the Department have done under those difficult pressures.

TALK.START.PARA: —I never blame a department where I can blame a Minister.
—Order! The honourable member for Dundas will cease interjecting.

—The honourable member for Dundas never blames a department when he can blame a Minister. I am suggesting that some of the blame he has thrown on the Minister is really quite unfair and unjustified. SPEECH.PARA: We should examine how the Opposition, the Government and the Australian Democrats in the other place ought to work to ensure the continuation of the immigration program against the attacks mounted in the current atmosphere. It was an excellent conference that brought together academics, politicians, ethnic community leaders and many other people involved in the immigration processes. They all got together and discussed and debated whether, for example, immigration presents problems for the environment, the economy and social cohesion or because of our multicultural policies.

Clearly, that conference was a success in a number of ways. The academic research illustrates that many of the arguments presented by people either speaking to a public audience or writing in newspapers against immigration are fallacious. That does not mean that those arguments do not continue. One still hears people say, `We do not want immigrants because they take our jobs' and make other such false claims. Parliament should ensure unity between the Government, the Opposition and the Australian Democrats to convince those sectors of the community that have doubts about immigration that immigration is important because of the contribution it can make towards the development of this country.

Therefore, I am happy to have been speaking in support of these reports. I congratulate the Department upon what has been a difficult year and for the way in which it has handled it. TALK.START.PARA: —If I might pay the honourable member for Calwell (Dr Theophanous) a compliment, I must say that at least he could never be excused of understating his case.

SPEECH.PARA: The whole question of immigration is a very important one to the Australian people. In fact, research suggests that it is not too far behind the economy in terms of the level of public concern about the Government's handling of the issue. The concern most often expressed is that the level of migration is either too high or is biased towards one particular ethnic group or another. As the honourable member for Calwell pointed out, it is hard to dispute or refute the economic arguments put forward in support of the contention that Australia is currently underpopulated. The vast majority of economists take the view that Australia needs a significant immigration program to have a growth in population, which will contribute positively towards future living standards. Most economists also note in this context the effect that the ageing population is having as well. So there is, quite rightly, considerable support for a continuing high level of immigration.

It is pertinent to note that Australia currently has the highest immigration intake per capita in the world. In 1988-89 our immigration intake was 145,316 people, which is a rate of 8.7 per thousand. This rate dropped a little to 7.1 in 1989-90. The United States of America, which has a very high aggregate intake, has a per capita intake significantly below that of Australia. The rate per thousand in the United States of America in 1988 was just 2.1, which is only about one quarter of the level of migration to Australia.

The Opposition's policy reflects the fact that Australia's population needs to grow in order to positively enhance living standards. Assuming that environmental concerns about sustainable development can be met, most Australians agree that the population does need to grow. The extent to which it needs to grow is a matter of considerable conjecture. Perhaps when the honourable member for Adelaide (Dr Catley) speaks after me, he will espouse publicly some of the theories on population growth that he and I have discussed privately on other occasions. I will not put him too much on the spot, but I challenge him to give us his impressions on the sort of population that Australia should have.

Ultimately, if we were to have a choice most Australians would come down in favour of population growth coming from the expansion of existing Australian families. Recently I spoke on this in the House, when I said that there were many positive disincentives to families to have children today, which was most unfortunate; that we should be looking at encouraging families to have more children; and that our economic policies should be aimed at doing that. The plain fact is that in the current economic climate it is very difficult for people to choose to have more families when there is strong pressure exerted on both the husband and wife to actually go out and work just to maintain the lifestyles to which they are accustomed.

The item that I want to concentrate on tonight is the 1989-90 annual report of the Department of Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs. It is called Review '90. I enjoyed reading this report. Since I became a member of parliament, I have had extensive dealings with the Department on a local level. Almost 12 months ago now it established a branch office in Southport, on the Gold Coast. We enjoy a very good working relationship with that office and I would like to compliment particularly the manager of that office, Mr John Cameron, for the cooperation we receive from him when we ask for it. I also want to say publicly that I have found the Queensland manager, Mr Dario Castello, to be very helpful on the occasions we have been in contact with him, and I congratulate him on his relocation to Canberra.

The honourable member for Dundas (Mr Ruddock) was interjecting when the honourable member for Calwell was speaking. We do not have a problem with the Department. On balance, in my dealings with the Department so far, I would have to say it is probably one of the more efficient Federal bureaucracies. But, as the honourable member for Dundas was saying, we do have some problems with the Government's handling of this matter, and particularly with the handling of the portfolio by the Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs (Mr Hand).

Because of the effect that it has on my electorate, I was particularly interested in the report's dealings with what it calls `overstayers'. It is rather like the reference in the report to `innocent illegals', which the honourable member for Calwell was talking about. I take `overstayers' to be some sort of euphemism for illegal immigrants. By virtue of my electorate's nature-it is an attractive environment and tourist area, with a very fluid population-it has more than its share of these so-called overstayers. These illegal immigrants take jobs, and jobs are pretty scarce in most places around Australia at the moment, and I suspect that very few of these illegal immigrants actually pay taxes.

The report estimates that at 30 April 1990 there were 90,000 overstayers, or illegals, which represents a very substantial increase-50 per cent-over the July 1989 estimate. But some estimates have gone even beyond this. A suggestion is being floated around that the number of illegal immigrants may now be closer to 150,000. It is rather staggering to think that in the eight months between July 1989 and April 1990 the number of student overstayers increased by 78 per cent, temporary residents by 40 per cent and visitors by 32 per cent. Some 68 per cent of those people had been overstaying for more than six months. The main countries of citizenship for the overstayer population were the United Kingdom, Malaysia, Fiji, Indonesia, the United States, the Philippines, China, Korea and Thailand.

The Immigration Department has made considerable efforts to detect these illegal immigrants, but in a big country like Australia it is pretty hard to find them most of the time. I have often felt that the Immigration Department was running around trying to plug leaks, only to find that each time it managed to plug a leak in one spot a leak sprang up in another spot. We need a concerted effort on the part of the Government in this area. I do not entirely accept the assurances of the honourable member for Calwell that we have yet reached anything like the optimum in terms of an effort to overcome this problem in that most of the evidence points to the fact that the number of illegals or overstayers is still growing.

In the Government's response to the report of the Joint Standing Committee on Migration Regulations entitled Illegal entrants in Australia: Balancing control and compassion, which the honourable member for Calwell spoke about, the Government has acknowledged that the increased number of illegal immigrants is a serious problem which must be met with firm and resolute action. We in the Opposition entirely agree with that, and agree further with the response when it states:

The challenge is not to reach or maintain a balance. Illegal entrants have broken Australia's immigration law; most have done so deliberately in the ill-advised expectation that at the end of the day they will be permitted to stay. Any perception that such a prize will continue as a reward for law-breaking and that chances of being able to remain improve with length of overstay is misplaced.

This is one of our concerns about the temporary entry visas which have been given to the People's Republic of China students. There is a very real chance that they will be given some indication that, given time and over time, they will have a greater chance of being able to stay. Our position on this is very clear: come the end of another three years, unless on a case by case basis they can put forward reasons why they ought to be able to stay or if in the meantime they have not qualified, they will have to go back. There is no sense, at least from our point of view, that the length of time that they are being given here is the thin edge of the wedge. That needs to be made perfectly clear.

The Committee's proposals that illegal entrants whose applications to stay are unsuccessful should not face any period of exclusion from Australia are also, as far as I am concerned, quite unacceptable. That cannot be allowed to happen. I believe that the honourable member for Dundas was quite instrumental in the fact that five of the nine active members of the Committee dissented from aspects of its report, and this is also a telling factor to be kept in mind when reviewing its recommendations.

In the meantime, we have to deal with the problem of stopping illegal immigrants from working here. This has been a real concern of mine for some time, because it is a particular problem for the tourism sector with which my electorate is concerned. I said in this place last year that there are several methods that I believe we can use to stop illegals working in Australia if we are really serious about it.

The first thing that we should be doing is denying illegal immigrants access to a tax file number. It is fairly obvious to anyone who looks into it that people can in fact access tax file numbers without a great deal of difficulty. The problem, it seems to me, is with the actual application form, which has several deficiencies. The documents that one has to present when one applies for a tax file number are easy to obtain. That is a problem that I believe needs to be addressed seriously by the Government.

Another factor that I raised was that the Commonwealth Employment Service (CES) procedures could be tightened up to make sure that those using the facilities are legal residents or Australian citizens. But to my knowledge there has been no serious attempt by the staff at the CES to ascertain that the people using their services are in those categories. Another thing that illegals can get easy access to, and which opens all sorts of other doors, is a driver's licence. I believe-and Queensland is going down this track-licences should be issued only to those who are legal residents or citizens or are entitled to have them.

It is vital that simple measures be taken to ensure that illegal immigrants cannot find employment easily. When I spoke on the tabling of the report of the Joint Select Committee on Migration Regulations, I went into this matter in detail. I wrote to the Minister and he has responded positively in some respects.

I believe another thing that we should be doing in this matter is launching a public awareness campaign aimed at pointing out to the community the problem that we have with illegal immigrants and making people aware of the implications of harbouring or aiding and abetting these people. That should be extended to employers, who should be made perfectly aware of the fact that, while it is not obligatory to ask whether an employee is working legally, they are in effect aiding an illegal act by employing them. Whether this public awareness campaign takes the form of a television campaign or some other form, we need to tell people at large about the seriousness of the situation that is created by overstayers and raise the public's awareness of the issue.

I could go on at some length about the Government's performance of the handling of immigration. I would have gone on to cite Imam Sheikh Hilaly's situation as an example of the bad handling of this particular matter, but I will not be able to because I will run out of time. I mention finally that the annual report deals with the immigration records and information system, IRIS, a computerised visa processing facility, and the travel immigration processing system, TRIPS, which is a new entry control system for airports.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Catley Dr R.

TALK.START.PARA: —It gives me great pleasure to speak on the 1989-90 annual report of the Department of Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs. I worked as a consultant to the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs from 1985 to 1987. During that time the Government adopted two changes to its general policy which are reflected in this annual report. First, it determined that the previous policy of cutting immigration intake when the Australian economy entered a cyclical downturn was inappropriate. In the past, such cuts had been made to the program in the belief that migrants took jobs and made unemployment worse. The cuts made to migration programs during the cyclical downturns in 1961, 1974 and 1982 may have made these downturns even worse. In any case, it was felt that a buoyant migration program, comprising people who are on average younger and better skilled than the domestic population, was good for the economic development of a country which is still sparsely populated and requires a larger infrastructure to be developed-which is my quick response to the question of the honourable member for McPherson (Mr Bradford).

SPEECH.PARA: Secondly, it was felt that the political method of ministerial discretion that was applied to all migration cases-at least in theory-was not suitable for such a large program as was to develop that now involves up to 140,000 people each year. As a result, moves were initiated to codify migration policy. This came to fruition under a subsequent Minister in December 1989 and produced a vast body of regulations and the Joint Standing Committee on Migration Regulations, the first of whose reports we are debating cognately tonight.

Five years later, we find a migration program which is larger than-almost double-that of the mid-1980s and one which is governed not by ministerial fiat but by a regulatory regime similar to that operating in, say, the Department of Social Security. The program volume is no longer influenced by the cyclical motion of the Australian economy and the Minister no longer carries an extraordinary volume of paperwork, which in the case of the Minister that I worked for actually reached 13 briefcases at its peak and which he carried everywhere with him.

It has recently been shown in a study by the Bureau of Immigration Research that, during the last 15 years of incorporating these changes to policy, immigration has had a favourable impact on Australia's aggregate and per capita standard of living. It seems that a decent rate of population growth, to which immigration contributes substantially in the case of Australia, stimulates the level of economic activity and reduces the level of unemployment which would have otherwise prevailed. The resultant faster rate of growth in total output also causes a faster rate of adoption of new technology, bringing further benefits in the form of higher productivity.

The report also states that if the population grows much above 1 1/2 or 1 3/4 per cent per annum, the advantages of economic output tend to recede with an overcommitment to infrastructure and some crowding in urban facilities. All that sounds a bit dry, but I thought it was worth getting on the record. It means, in short, that immigration at the level we are presently running it accounts for an improvement in living standards for those who are still here and those who come in.

There are other ways in which the immigration program benefits our well-being. The current program being biased in favour of applicants who are relatively young and well qualified makes a strong contribution to economic development. The injection of youth also slows down to some degree the ageing of the population and the consequent drain on welfare and the tax bill that future generations of Australians will face.

The selection of skilled applicants also carries other benefits. Immigration can be used as a tool for filling limited term shortages in specific sectors of the work force, thereby reducing damaging distortions and wage fluctuations, or it can be used as a general method of building the aggregate level of skills available to the economy as a whole. Some of these skills may be new ones which were previously unavailable to us. We have tried to build up the business migration program to incorporate business skills, particularly the availability to make economic connections with the region to our north, which is the fastest growing section of the world economy.

Some questions have been raised, some of them this evening, about the character of the business migration program. Many of these I will leave unanswered since one of our parliamentary committees is presently undertaking a review of the business migration program that should produce answers to these questions. I note in passing that the business migration program has produced an inflow of capital into the Australian economy. The last figures I was able to get were for the same year as the Immigration Department's annual review of 1989-90. It stated that the inflow of capital associated with this program amounted to $1.7 billion. Even if there are other distortions involved in the program, we should recall that there is a substantial inflow of money which goes along with it.

Another aspect of the immigration program which appeals to me personally very much is the multicultural society which has resulted from the program. We are now a much more cosmopolitan society than we were even 20 years ago, and the inflow of migrants in the contemporary immigration program over the last six or seven years has contributed to an even further diversity, particularly as this intake has involved more people from the Asian-Pacific region. We are all familiar with the delights this has produced for Australian cuisine. It is not just the cuisine; it is the capacity to trade with and realise the market potential for our products in the Asia-Pacific region, much of which is quite different to the culture which we have imported from Europe. I have had occasion to mention before persons exporting exotic foodstuffs, that is, exotic by our standards but quite standard fair in the Asian market.

The result has been that my seat of Adelaide is now very much a multicultural seat with quite diverse ethnic communities who have quite different problems to those of the Anglo-Celtic majority and who require different kinds of resolutions to their problems. For example, I have an Islamic community in Adelaide which worships at the oldest mosque in the country. Immediately tensions built up in the Gulf they contacted me and asked what the chances were of greater discrimination against Islamic people resulting from the United Nation's operation in the Gulf. I ensured that some extra measures were undertaken with respect to both their residences and their place of worship. As is well-known, the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) wrote them a letter on the subject. As it turned out, these safeguards seemed to be unnecessary, but I am sure they were greatly comforted by them at the time.

On the other hand, we also have a very vibrant Jewish community in the seat of Adelaide which over the last few years has come to see itself as something of an ethnic community contributing to multicultural society which, in the first instance, was not its natural tendency. There is a flourishing liberal synagogue in the middle of my seat. I am going to visit it very shortly to attend a function which they have organised.

On the other hand, our older ethnic communities need to be remembered. Only yesterday I had the pleasure of turning the first sod, as they say, at a hostel for part of our ethnic specific aged care program involving Polish-speaking Australians who came here in the 1940s and 1950s and who have contributed greatly to the development of Australia and find that they want to use Polish in their older years in their place of residence, which in this case is going to be a 40-bed hostel.

Our newer communities contribute in rather different ways. The Vietnamese Christian community, which has grown very rapidly in Adelaide, as in other parts of the country, has recently blessed the ground that it will use for its own ethnic community centre which is going to incorporate not only tennis courts but also a stadium for soccer, which sport they are very keen on playing.

Another of our recent communities is the Chinese who, legend has it, are only interested in commerce and restaurants. This is totally untrue. The Chairman of the migrant resource centre in Adelaide is Ron Tan, a Singaporean Chinese. A Hong Kong Chinese person is on the Ethnic Affairs Commission. Only yesterday I had the privilege of watching the dragon boat races at the ethnic fair at Elder Park when one of the Chinese dragon boats sank, to everyone's great delight.

Immigration is an issue which occasions about 50 per cent of visits to my electorate office in Sefton Park. A whole variety of people seek the assistance of myself, as the local member. Since the codification of the migration regulations, to which I have already referred, the amount of assistance that a local member of parliament can actually offer to constituents tends to be rather more limited than might have been the case previously. Ministerial representations are no longer as effective since the Minister himself is rather tied up by the regulations which have been designed to restrict the areas of ministerial discretion. There is an expanded review process now in place which is, again, going to be subject to investigation by the Migration Regulations Committee. Later this year I hope we will be able to debate how effective the review process is in overseeing the way in which the code is applied.

This evening I would like to mention a few cases that have come to my attention which seem to me to be problematic in so far as the codification of migration regulations is concerned. The ones that have occasioned most problems are those involving change of status because it seems that, all too frequently, people who visit Australia and intend to return to their country of origin change their mind because they are offered permanent employment or because they fall in love with an Australian and want to stay. A number of instances have come to my attention which I have had to deal with, some of which seem to have been resolved by the code in perhaps, if not the wrong way, at least an unnecessarily round-about way.

One young couple were engaged to be married. She was told that she would have to return to England in order to apply for permanent residency in Australia. However, if they had been in a de facto relationship-in which their religious beliefs did not permit them to be, which is most unusual in this day and age as I am sure you would realise, even from your illustrious position, Mr Deputy Speaker-he would have been invited to sponsor her, as his de facto wife, to remain in Australia permanently. It seemed odd that these factors could not be taken into account, or the fact that she was in permanent employment in a position where her services were greatly valued and not easily replaced; that they were both taxpayers; and that the chances of her application for permanent residency-when made from England, to which she had returned at great cost-being refused, since she was the fiancee of an Australian citizen, were negligible. So we were all put to great trouble, expense and disruption in order for this lady to comply with the code, which is very difficult to get around because there is so little discretion built into it.

I understand that this requirement is in place to prevent rorting and queue jumping. I have come across the odd case of people trying to rort and queue jump but, nonetheless, I have come across many more cases of people who want to settle legitimately in this country and who find it difficult to get around the code, particularly when it relates to change of status when in Australia.

I have also met with distressed relatives of people who wish to visit Australia temporarily-say for a wedding or a funeral-and who come from countries to which there is supposed to be a great risk of them not returning. They have had their applications rejected. In most instances, I or my staff have been able to go to officials and get the situation reversed so that they are able to come here and attend a wedding or a funeral and leave. It seems to me unfortunate that the code should be too rigid in that respect and I think we need to pay careful attention to the review of the review process which the Committee will undertake in a couple of months.

I would also like to mention the case-because it has a happy ending-of a Ukrainian family. An Australian Ukrainian had been trying to get some of his family out of the Ukraine for years. His first application 15 years ago was successful as far as Australia was concerned, but it was rejected by the Soviet Government, which refused the family an exit visa. So they were forced to remain in Kiev. Last year the Soviet Government finally granted the family an exit visa but then it looked as though, under the codified rules that we had, they could not get an import visa to come to Australia. So for years they had been unable to leave the Soviet Union, although we would have them, but when the Soviet Union said that they could leave we would not let them in because we had changed our rules. There is a happy ending to this story as it was determined that the family constituted a special circumstance. The family is on its way to Australia and I look forward to a slivovitz-or whatever the Ukrainians in Adelaide drink-when the family reaches Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —What special circumstances?
—What's the special circumstance?

—Honourable members opposite are asking me what the special circumstances were. I am afraid that I will have to tell them that on an another occasion. My notes do not seem to incorporate it and I am running out of time.

SPEECH.PARA: I will return to the two instances that I started talking about. In general, the two changes that have been made and, I believe, incorporated into policy over the last five years have been, firstly, the expansion of the program. The expansion of the program has been a great success and recognition of this is the fact that it is now supported by the Opposition, which had periodically made various criticisms of it. The odd wrinkle occurs-which the shadow Minister for immigration and ethnic affairs, the honourable member for Dundas (Mr Ruddock), chose to criticise very strongly-and it is incumbent upon us, as legislators, to iron these out. So far that has been accomplished successfully.

The other facet of the change involves codification of the rules. I have already expressed some reservations about the way in which this has been incorporated. My own taste would have been for a retention of a higher degree of ministerial discretion. But, in the absence of that, it is very important that we get the review process correct and I look forward very much to the Migration Regulations Committee undertaking a review of the review process later this year.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sullivan Mrs K.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am fascinated by the speech of the honourable member for Adelaide (Dr Catley) and I freely admit to having been one of the Opposition members who interjected. The reason I interjected was that I was quite startled by something that the honourable member had said. He referred to a very difficult immigration case that he had encountered concerning a family trying to emigrate from Russia. The family was eligible to come here and finally got its exit visa from Russia only to find that our rules had changed and it could not come in. He then said that under a special circumstance the family was allowed to come in. I must know the special circumstance and every member of this House must know the special circumstance.
— Yes, he is misleading the House.
— This is something we need to know for all of our special cases.
—Order! The honourable member for Gippsland will withdraw.
—I withdraw.

—I am sorry, Mr Deputy Speaker; I was so carried away that I did not realise that the honourable member for Gippsland was out of order. This is something which we all need to know because we all have special circumstance cases, but the present rigid circumstances do not allow any special circumstance. We all know of quite horrendous cases under these new regulations about which we are told, no matter how far we take them, that nothing can be done-there are no special circumstances. The only special circumstance that I know of applies under section 64U of the Migration Legislation Amendment Act, to which the Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs (Mr Hand) refers in the ministerial statement which we are debating. Under that section he can, in cases of an extreme compassionate nature, make a decision contrary to the regulations. He has to report the decision, and the details of the case, to Parliament. He has done it once since this Act has been in effect.

SPEECH.PARA: I want to know about the special circumstance to which the honourable member for Adelaide refers. I think we all need to know about it. We need to know the basis for us to make our cases to the Minister. Perhaps this is a case which the Minister means to report to Parliament next week or later this week. I want to know about it. I do not put down the case to which the honourable member refers-I am sure it is a very special circumstance. But the problem with the regulations and the regime, and the problem which the Minister has promised to address but has not addressed since he has put down his statement, is those special circumstances. I want to talk about two types of cases tonight. The first type is the special circumstance which is not allowed for now. Terrible cases have come before me as a result of it. I have managed to resolve some with success, but others I have not. The other type of special circumstance is when the Department of Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs messes it up for the applicant.

I think it is very appropriate that we are having this debate tonight. I was a member of the Joint Committee on Migration Regulations that looked at the first lot of migration regulations. I was part of the Parliament that put a condition into the Migration Legislation Amendment Act and refused to give carte blanche to the then Minister with his migration regulations. I was part of the Parliament which put a time limit on the Act and required regulations to be finalised and put before the Parliament for scrutiny by a certain time. I have to say that the outcome was quite unsatisfactory as far as I was concerned.

I do understand why the new regime came into effect and I do understand why it was necessary to look at a codification. I cannot understand why the Government insisted on following the timetable it did in a quite bloody-minded fashion. I was there every step of the way and saw it, including in the Migration Regulations Committee. I do not understand how Minister Hand could make his statement in May 1990 about things that had to happen back then, and for them still not to have happened. In this country the matter of immigration is a bipartisan one. We have a basic agreement about the objectives of our migration policies and our migration program, but every opposition must always have the right to point out the flaws to government.

In referring to the Minister's May 1990 statement, I find his statement very intriguing. This, of course, is not the Minister who brought in the Act-that was the honourable Mick Young-nor the Minister who brought in the regulations-that was Senator Robert Ray-but the present Minister, the Hon. Gerry Hand. Thus we have three different Ministers involved. I say just this in order to point out that the Minister who currently has carriage of this matter is not the man who was responsible for either the Act or the regulations. But he is the man responsible for looking at how they have both worked. He says in this statement:
The introduction of so large a body of Regulations under the amended legislation-
amended by the Parliament-
in a much compressed time frame compared to what was originally intended-
and I put a very big question mark over that-
was required by the Migration Legislation Amendment Act. This resulted in a lack of clarity, and, in a number of cases, unintended consequences.

The Government came to the Parliament asking for carte blanche on its regulations. It came in and said, `We are going to change the immigration system totally and we are no longer going to do it by the previous code of practice. We are going to do it under regulations. The regulations are mentioned in this Act, but we are not going to tell you what is in them'. We said, `No. We are not going to accept a total rewriting of Australia's migration system without knowing what is happening'. So a time limit was put on the Act. Those regulations had to be introduced by a certain time or the Act was inoperative. I therefore do not understand what the Minister means by a `much compressed time frame'.

We kept on being promised the regulations. We saw draft after draft of them, every one incomplete. The time was compressed in the end because the Government was months behind its own timetable for the delivery of those regulations to Parliament. So when it says the time frame was much compressed compared with what was originally intended, it should realise that that compression was not imposed on the Government but was a compression that it brought on itself. When that situation arose, the Opposition said to the Government, `We will agree to an extension of the deadline for the regulations. Get them right. It is terribly important because it is such a fundamental change. We will agree to an extension'.

The deadline was 19 November 1989. We were due to have an election by July 1990. As it happened, we had one in early March 1990 and Parliament did not sit in 1990 prior to the election. I believe that the reason the Government would not agree to an extension of the deadline until closer to when the election was due was that it wanted to keep its options open for an early election-if that was what it chose-and it simply could not determine what would be an appropriate extension date. In the event of an election prior to the Act coming into effect there was always a chance that the Government would lose, in which case a very different situation would have arisen. The Minister was bound and determined to have his regime in place before the end of 1989.

TALK.START.PARA: —That's right.
—The shadow Minister says, `That's right', and that is exactly the way it was. It was totally political.
—It was to be his monument.

—This new system was to be his monument. It was totally political and totally self-oriented with a much compressed time frame compared with what was originally intended because of political and administrative considerations, not for any reason other than that. The Government had an offer of total cooperation from the Opposition to get the regulations right.

SPEECH.PARA: Another problem with that haste-and one that was pointed out with deep and real concern by members who were interested in this-was the haste of the introduction of those regulations. One very big question mark and concern that was raised over them was the difficulty that the staff of the Department would have in administering them-staff both within Australia and overseas. The Migration Regulations Committee sought information about the training that would be given to staff, both in Australia and overseas, so that the staff could properly advise people applying to migrate here. The answer we got, whilst I am sure it was very well intentioned, was pathetic. It was very clear that it was not possible to give proper training in the time available. I state that because one of the great concerns that I want to raise tonight is the incorrect advice that is being given even now to people who seek advice on their status, either within the country whilst holding one form of visa, or overseas when they are applying to get a visa. Warnings of this possibility were given to the Government. In the Minister's statement he says:
Codification means that policies are clearly specified in criteria and people are clear on their entitlements and obligations.

I raise the question: clear to whom? It is not clear to many departmental officers, it is not clear to many departmental applicants and, frankly, it is anything but clear to virtually every member of Parliament.

Having been a member of the Migration Regulations Committee and in the privileged position of having seen all the draft regulations well before they were tabled, and being able to study them with departmental officers, I went back to my electorate office and said to my staff, `When these new regulations come into effect you will not give anyone any advice about immigration, because you will not be able to understand them-they are too complex. Also, you will not take verbal advice from the Department. The only advice we will pass on to any constituent is advice we get in writing from the Department'. How right I was! With the best will in the world Department of immigration officers are giving advice to people which is wrong. They believe it to be right when they give it, the recipient believes it to be right, the recipient proceeds on it, and, in every case that has come before me where this has happened, by the time the person comes to me he or she is illegal and about to be deported. Yet that person has done what the Department told him or her to do.

One case involved an American in Australia on a visitor's visa. He had no reason to try to be illegal-he had special skills, he could have migrated if he wanted to. He came here just to see Australia, but met an Australian woman and fell in love. They wanted to marry, but did not do so before contacting the Department. He informed the Department's officers as to when his visitor's visa would expire-which was some six weeks after the contact-and was told that provided he applied by a certain date for permanent residency he would be all right. This man followed the Department's advice to the letter. He went into the Department on that date and asked for the form he had to fill in, but he was illegal when he walked into that office because he had been given incorrect advice. He had married by then. When this man produced his visa and gave his story, the reply was, `You're illegal. Get out of the country, buster'.

He went off to his solicitor, who contacted the Department and said, `We need time to look at this. Please give us a couple of weeks'. The Department set the date for his departure as 23 December 1990. The couple contacted me the week before. The solicitor had looked at the case. Clearly under the regulations the fellow was illegal. The fact that he followed departmental advice was neither here nor there-the regulations do not allow for that. He had no reason to do the wrong thing; if he had followed the right procedure he would have got permanent residency. He said, `I will go', because if it got to the point of a deportation order, it would be years before he could apply to come back. If the applicant left the country, he could apply to come back in six months. He was newly married-it was wonderful stuff!

When I contacted the Department and said, `Why is it 23 December?', I was told, `Because that is the date'. I said, `But why 23 December? Why not the 26th? Why cannot he have Christmas with his wife?' I was told, `Because that is the date'. I asked, `Is there any reason it cannot be another date?' And the answer was, `That is the date'. So I telephoned Canberra, and he got Christmas with his wife. That little Hitler in the office up in Brisbane was sitting there saying to me, `That is the date'. There was no justification for that at all. But that is what he told the applicant and, by God, he was not going to let that applicant get another day. That is the situation that these regulations have brought on us.

I only have a couple of minutes left. The Minister refers to two categories of people that must be distinguished-those people who become illegal quite innocently and unintentionally through ignorance of proper procedures, and those who have explored every loophole of the regulations. I have no sympathy with the second group and neither has the Opposition. But there is a third category-it is those who become innocently and unintentionally illegal through following the Department's directions. I have cited one instance here tonight and there have been others. This situation has to be urgently addressed. The Minister foreshadowed a Bill in May 1990, but it has not happened yet. He cannot just say, `I am going to bring in some legislation'. He has to move with some urgency to find the loosening up of the system that is essential. In the meantime, I look forward with great interest to receiving information as to how I can help the sort of people I have referred to tonight.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Holding The Hon A.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have listened with some interest to the contributions made by honourable members to this debate. There are a number of things that need to be said about immigration in general and some things that need to be said about it in particular. In general, it is easy for honourable members opposite to point to mistakes made in connection with problems of administration. Indeed, if we look at the problem that bedevils the Department of Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs, we will see that this financial year it will have well over a million applications of various sorts from people wanting to immigrate to Australia or come to Australia. As to those who want to immigrate, it will be saying no to nine out of 10 of those who apply. Given the range, the diversity and the number of applications, it is inevitable that, in that process, mistakes will be made. That was inevitable even before Parliament effectively abolished the concept of ministerial discretion and moved to the adoption of the code.

SPEECH.PARA: I suppose that at that stage it would have been possible for the Department of Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs-if it had followed the sorts of views of my colleague the honourable member for Moncrieff (Mrs Sullivan)-to have said, `Well, we'll put everything on hold until we get it right'. But that would be a position which would be supported by the honourable member or anybody else.

We have an Opposition which continually berates the Government for not cutting back in areas of the Public Service. Day after day, we hear the Leader of the Opposition (Dr Hewson) and the shadow Treasurer, the honourable member for Flinders (Mr Reith), saying to the people of Australia, `This Government must make further cutbacks in the public sector'. It is all right for the shadow Minister for immigration and ethnic affairs, the honourable member for Dundas (Mr Ruddock), to smile, but if he is supporting his colleagues he ought to get up and tell us in which areas of this Department he would be cutting back in terms of day to day administration and where he believes that will make the system more effective.

TALK.START.PARA: —Case by case determination of Chinese students' claims, as you know.

—I am not happy about some of the aspects. There is no way one can be satisfied with all aspects of our immigration administration. But by and large, if we are being honest, I would prefer the position that this Government has taken over a period of time on the question of immigration of Chinese to some of the positions which, to his credit, the shadow Minister crossed the floor on when those positions were being put by the Opposition. So I would suggest to the honourable gentleman that the last thing he should be berating this Government about is its position on Asian immigration. While his own track record is first rate, the track record of some of his colleagues leaves a lot to be desired.
—What did the honourable member for Gippsland do?
—Order! The Minister will cease interjecting.

—I must say for myself that I still believe that, until such time as we bring back a much greater extent of ministerial discretion, many of these problems will continue to bedevil us. Given the nature and variety of the problems that the Department has to deal with, we cannot have a situation in which we have a department virtually geared to saying no nine times out of 10 without getting considerable areas of injustice within the framework of that situation.

SPEECH.PARA: We have heard of the sort of instant case that the honourable member for Moncrieff has mentioned. Every honourable member is aware of cases where the simple answer to that situation is an exercise in ministerial discretion. While I was Minister for immigration, I had a large number of applications from honourable members on both sides of the House, and let me say this: in all of those applications, I never found an honourable member who was out to rort or abuse the system.

TALK.START.PARA: —That isn't the system now?

—The Parliament decided that. I personally believe that one of the answers that ought to be adopted at this stage is to go back to a greater degree of ministerial discretion, because we cannot implement a code and expect that, in the great variety of human circumstances which are dealt with throughout the whole area of immigration, it will cover that situation. By their very nature, the legal processes and the checks and balances which the Government has endeavoured to put in place will take some time to sort out and, in the course of that, it will be inevitable that injustices will occur. I have been there when injustices do occur.

SPEECH.PARA: I get a little tired of being part of the minority which started off to make up a majority report about the standards that we apply towards illegal immigrants. I do not support illegal immigrants. We know that many of them are able to survive in the community by virtue of the fact that they are working for below-award wages, often in situations of great exploitation. Many honourable members of this Parliament are fully aware of situations in their own electorates where that is occurring. But when has there been an occasion when an employer taking advantage of that situation, knowing that he is employing someone who is an illegal immigrant, is charged in respect of that act?

One of the things that the majority of the committee on immigration regulations recommended was, of course, that those provisions be strengthened. We cannot have it both ways. All the concentration in terms of illegal immigrants, when we are talking about the non-innocent illegals, tends to be directed against illegals per se. But the great majority of those illegals on the records of the Department can survive in Australia only because they are employed, and in the great majority of cases they are employed by people who know they are illegal and are prepared to employ them because they can do so knowing that, whatever conditions apply, whatever wages they pay, they will not be subject to any kind of challenge. One of the quick ways of dealing with that problem is, of course, to make it perfectly clear that employers in that situation who adopt that attitude are not going to be ignored.

The other area that I believe ought to be looked at by this Government and by the Parliament is in respect of Australia's very commendable record in terms of its treatment of refugee applications. But we are in a situation in which I believe there are many refugees who ought to be deserving of the sympathy and the response of this Government but who find themselves in a situation in which their applications cannot be easily processed.

Let me give an example of three groups whose situation almost on a daily basis is in peril. Whether or not the individual applicant meets the criteria of refugee status would be a matter for subsequent determination, but I believe there are groups or communities which are at risk. Take for example those Afghans who have left Afghanistan, many of whom are highly educated and many of whom are at the moment simply living under very difficult conditions in places like Pakistan, who have relatives in Australia and who would make very suitable immigrants to Australia. They cannot go back to Afghanistan because there is still virtually a civil war going on and many of the mines that were laid during the Soviet occupation are still there. They cannot go back because their lives would be in peril. Yet, because they are in Pakistan, living under difficult or impossible situations, their applications for refugee status are not being processed, in my view, in the way in which they should be.

The other obvious group is, of course, the Lebanese. One only has to talk about the situation in Beirut. There really has to be a process which, in my view, enables those people there who are on a daily basis at risk-not for any particular political or religious philosophy they have got-to be considered in a special category as being potential refugees.

Equally, I think, we ought to be looking at the current situation of Russian Jewry. There has been a long tradition of anti-semitic attitudes in Russia. During the period of a fairly tough communist regime, it was possible for a centralised state with an adequate police force to keep those kinds of traditional attitudes at bay. But in this new situation, as the Soviet Government wrestles with its own future, many of those old attitudes and traditional sentiments are coming to the fore, so that in particular parts of the Soviet Union-not necessarily generally, but in certain towns and in certain areas-the Jewish community and individual Jews, for no other reason than that they are Jews, are at risk and are in peril.

I believe it is necessary and desirable that the Australian immigration process have due regard to those sorts of problems. It is not just a question of waiting until we have an imposing number of dead to say, `This is the group that we are going to treat as refugees'.

I believe that if one looks at the history of immigration into Australia, with all the difficulties and all the faults, the system under all governments has been one which, in terms of its ultimate achievement at the end of the day, all members of this Parliament can feel proud about because of the kind of multicultural society that we have produced. However, we have to be vigilant and continue to see that this process operates to produce justice in individual cases, and that individual problems and the range and diversity of the human condition which create those situations are dealt with sympathetically.

I believe the category of ministerial discretion is far too narrow. It is absurd to say that a Minister who exercises his discretion has to report back to the Parliament. I believe that the quick and easy way of dealing with a number of problems that are brought to the Minister's attention enables him to exercise that discretion properly and effectively without feeling that somehow or other he is taking this great codified model and putting it at threat. Sure, we can have the judicial tribunal; sure, we can have these other processes-but there are situations which come to mind where Ministers ought to exercise their discretion.

I remember one very simple case when I was Minister. A family from Lebanon had been approved to come to Australia. They had to have their medical tests. They had five children and the smallest child, then aged about three, had a very mild case of Down's syndrome. What was the departmental response? Straight down the line: `The adults and the others can come and you can leave this child behind in Beirut'. Frankly, if any parents were prepared to leave their child in that sort of situation in Beirut, we would not want them. That case was a simple exercise of ministerial discretion. If the same situation arises today, why should the Minister not have the same capacity to exercise that discretion without having to report it to this Parliament as if it were a major event? This Parliament has more than enough processes to deal with any abuse at any level going on within the immigration system.

It is interesting to note that, during the time of a variety of Ministers from all political parties, a serious challenge has never been mounted on that basis. I believe that the approach taken, of trying to codify the situation and abolish ministerial discretion, means that we are going to have many more administrative problems than we need have. I believe that in any review one does not have to abolish some of the structures that have been created which make for effective due processing, but I believe that there is such a variety of problems that we ought to, as a Parliament, be looking seriously at the reintroduction of ministerial discretion without the nonsense of saying that Ministers can exercise discretion at every level in this Parliament and they are answerable to this Parliament. Where a Minister says, `I am going to exercise ministerial discretion on the basis of information put before me'-and it does not matter if it comes from another member of this House or where it comes from-if he believes it is appropriate, then he is answerable, in the final analysis, to this Parliament for any abuse or any mistake that he makes.

That being the case, in looking at this whole question of how we make the system more effective we ought to look at that aspect. But by and large, I believe the immigration portfolio and the Ministers involved in it have made it work. Australia can be part of the system, but there are actions there that need to be rectified.

DEBATE.TITLE: INDUSTRY, TECHNOLOGY AND COMMERCE LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL 1991

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 7 March, on motion by Mr Crean:
