SPEECH.SPEAKER: McGauran Mr P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —At the outset of my contribution on the Industry, Technology and Commerce Legislation Amendment Bill of 1991, I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That all words after ``That'' be omitted with a view to substituting the following words:
``whilst not declining to give the Bill a second reading, the House:

(1) is of the opinion that the very existence of the Discretionary Grants Scheme and the Generic Technologies Scheme, administered by the Industry Research and Development Board, attests to the Government's failure to carry out necessary economic reforms which has resulted in:
(a) the incapacity of Australia's economy to derive the full benefits of technological innovation;
(b) the high cost of capital and general economic conditions which have compromised industry investment, especially in technology-related business strategies; and
(c) the inability of small start-up companies to gain access to suitable private capital backing or industry support at the early stages of product development; and
(2) notes that the extension of these schemes until 1994, which the Bill proposes, is further evidence of the Government's failure in this regard''.

The Bill before the House bears on a number of matters, including: the extension of the Government's industry related research and development programs-the discretionary grants scheme and the generic technology scheme; the provision of legislative backing for the national procurement and development program, as well as adding certain prescriptions to its granting authority; and other changes to the Science and Industry Research Act which affect the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation's ability to accept donations up to a threshold of $1m without seeking ministerial approval.

More technical matters dealt with in the Bill provide for low level drafting related alterations to the National Measurement Act 1960, the Export Market Development Grants Act, the Patents Act and the Industry, Technology and Commerce Amendment Act. In summary, leaving aside many of the technical aspects of the legislation, the Bill fundamentally affects the two research and development initiatives which are conducted by the Industry Research and Development Board (IRDB).

Consequently, this evening my comments will necessarily focus upon the Government's request contained in the legislation to extend these two research and development initiatives. The discretionary grants scheme and the generic technology scheme are adjuncts of the Government's industry policy. Both have as their objective the provision of assistance for the creation of potentially commercially significant technologies. They are targeted to the provision of assistance to small companies, often start-up companies, which do not possess a taxation liability and therefore are unable to claim under the 150 per cent research and development taxation incentive scheme. Such small companies, for instance, might well be those whose profit stream has been drained owing to investment outlays prior to product development.

The difference between the schemes is that one, the discretionary grants scheme, is untargeted in respect of the field of applicants; the other, the generic technologies grants scheme, seeks applicants from prespecified, defined priority technology areas. The former scheme is also more demanding than the latter on its applicants in respect of its commercial expectations. The discretionary grants scheme requires a more commercially driven technology development strategy than the generic grants scheme-that is, it focuses on company product development; emphasises the creation of proprietary knowledge; requires, therefore, relatively firm commercialisation strategies; and demands of applicants that they fund 50 per cent of project costs or more.

The generic technology grants scheme, ostensibly at least, is more orientated to the creation of non-proprietary knowledge-that is, it is directed more towards the support of precompetitive research. The scheme is designed to target significant research opportunities as defined by administrative selection procedures in predetermined priority research areas, the priority areas being biotechnology, waste management, information technologies, communications technology and new materials.

Waste management was inserted by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) during the last election campaign. No additional funding was granted to support it. It just made the scheme split its grants five ways instead of four. It is for this reason that the generic technology project costs on average around 80 to 90 per cent of scheme funds.

The Opposition reluctantly supports legislation to extend the life of these schemes. It does not do so on the basis of the integrity of the efforts of the Industry Research and Development Board in operating the schemes. I consider the responsibility given to the board to allocate resources in matters such as to be a profoundly onerous one. The coalition's reservations stem, rather, from its belief that resource allocation activities such as this cannot be effectively carried by administrative mechanisms. Ideally, this is not a process I would like to see government involved in at all.

The recent publicity given to the potential problem of conflicts of interest arising from the operation of the scheme indicate the sorts of difficulties into which administrative decision-making processes of this kind can stray. Mr Deputy Speaker, you have been especially active in this arena, and I know that you have expressed certain concerns publicly regarding the administration of the schemes by the Industry Research and Development Board. I hope, however, that the forthcoming responses by the Minister to questions on notice that I have recently submitted will put beyond doubt the conduct of the operation of the IRDB's various schemes. On the basis of current information, I have no reason to doubt the integrity of the efforts made by the IRDB board and its various committees in respect of grant allocations.

I can understand the sorts of tensions that the IRDB's judgments on the appropriateness of certain grant applications could give rise to. Notwithstanding this, I do anticipate a speedy and comprehensive response by the Minister to the further questions I have directed to him regarding the operation of the conflict of interest guidelines applying to the board. I know that you, Mr Deputy Speaker, especially amongst all members of this House, will be particularly anxious to know of the Minister's answers to the questions I have placed on notice which, in turn, follow your particular questions to the Minister of recent days.

I also add that the very existence of the schemes conducted by the IRDB attest to the deeper weaknesses in the economy which mitigate against a self-sustaining innovation process. Essentially, the schemes operate to provide support for innovative technologies which are unable to obtain sufficient capital backing from either manufacturers or other sources of investment finance. Regrettably, I accept the necessity in the current economic circumstances for such government-based initiatives to exist. The schemes conducted by the IRDB reveal the inadequate development of Australia's manufacturing sector and the virtual absence of venture capital in the country.

In the course of debate on science and technology matters, the Minister for Science and Technology (Mr Crean) has often accused the coalition of placing too great an emphasis on market conditions in regard to science and technology policy. This accusation reveals the Minister's naive perspective on the nature of the technological innovation process and its relationship to other forces at work in the economy. The Minister would like to present himself to the Australian Labor Party factions as one of the new breed of interventionists. His perspective on the portfolio for which he has responsibility is, regrettably, driven by his personal political agenda.

TALK.START.PARA: —Outrageous!
—The Treasurer (Mr Keating) no doubt would agree with this analysis of the Minister's conduct of his portfolio, even if the Minister for Resources does not or pretends not to.

SPEECH.PARA: The Minister's handling of the portfolio is not informed by an objective analysis of the interconnections between his portfolio and others. It is not informed by an appreciation of the linkages which must exist between research and development and other forces which should be operating in the economy if technology is to be effectively commercialised.

The Minister for Science and Technology frequently talks about the commitment of the Government to commercialising research; talk is cheap and talk itself will not bring about commercialisation. It is not just a question of talking in some rhetorical manner about technology transfer and its potential to reshape the industrial sector and boost competitiveness. We had enough of this science and technology hype from the former Minister for science, the honourable member for Lalor (Mr Barry Jones).

Many will recall the vision of an industrial landscape dotted by a profusion of sunrise industries that was offered up in the past. The capacity of an economy to mobilise its technological resources is tightly bound to its efficiency of performance; the level of industrial and manufacturing activity; the extent to which companies have developed technology strategies and have embarked on a technology acquisition investment program; the capabilities of management; and the confidence in the investment market.

Australia needs to retain and build upon its scientific and technological skill base; it needs to invigorate the various research processes at work in the public sector research community; and it needs to ensure that the structure and the physical resources which underpin those resources are adequate to the task. But the other hard policy work must also be carried out.

In respect of commercialisation issues, it is necessary to ensure that the market processes which are at the heart of effective technology transfer strategies are in place. Sadly, under this government, science and technology rhetoric headed off in one direction and economic policy in the other. It has been the inability to intertwine the two, to allow the technological transfer processes to feed off economic activity, which explains the need to extend the schemes that the House is currently debating.

In recent years much has been said of the importance for this country's future of building a more knowledge intensive, high value-added industrial manufacturing base; but the Government, through its own economic practices, has denied itself the very opportunity to realise that future. Generally, the existence of specific programs of the type included in this Bill-namely, the discretionary grants scheme and the generic technologies grant scheme-attest to governmental failure to address adequately key structural economic concerns. These concerns impede industry's capacity to respond rationally to market signals emanating from either public or private sector research and development activities.

As a passing example of the very real impact of these issues, take the case of ICI Australia Ltd, a high technology company. In an address to the Sydney Institute on 20 February this year, the company's Chief Executive, Michael Deeley, made clear the impact of broader economic issues on the capital-intensive, technology-intensive, high value-added industrial base of Australia-and ICI is certainly a high-tech industry. It was pushing into the internationally traded sector in areas such as advanced ceramics, scientific instruments and diagnostics. But added costs, brought about by the Government's failure to act on an array of interlocking micro-reform issues, have crippled its potential to continue the development of its high technology, traded goods production capabilities.

I would commend Mr Deeley's speech to the House. It is a timely and salient reminder of the interconnection between a country's broad economic performance and its capacity to build value-added knowledge-intensive industries. If we cannot get the economic signals right for established industries, one can well appreciate the problems facing small high-tech start-up companies or other innovators trying to gain a footing in the marketplace. Regardless of this important observation, however, as the current economic environment becomes less hostile to the development of technology-related business strategies, it will be necessary to give some reserved, tacit support for programs such as the discretionary grants and generic technology grants schemes. It is a situation the nation would rather not be in at all.

Australia's technology transfer processes have been gravely inactive by comparison with overseas economies. As such, potentially innovative product developments have been lost to foreign companies under licence or, at best, developed by way of joint ventures. The persistent failure of manufacturers to commercialise intellectual property emerging from our nation's research effort is a function of a variety of concerns. Change in the rates of technology transfer will not be significantly altered until overall economic conditions are conducive to promoting conventional, competitively driven sources of change. That is the simple, inescapable truth that seems lost on too many members of the Government.

The schemes under discussion tonight will have only marginal impact on rates of research and development take-up in relation to these other sources of market driven change. But, given the economic circumstances the Government has engineered, a marginal impact is better than no impact at all. Given this, the schemes must be seen for what they are; that is, compensatory measures to mask the hostile effects of the Government's own economic policies on the commercialisation process.

It should be understood that the creation of intellectual property in itself is a vastly less expensive process than is its further product development and marketing stages. These latter stages of research and development are therefore directly influenced concerns arising from the cost and availability of capital; rates of capital stock replacement within the manufacturing sector; cash flow; company size and managerial expertise; input costs in production processes; barriers to entry to markets; and the relative efficiencies of supply and transport networks. To be more specific, the wholesale taxation system impacts disproportionately upon emerging high technology manufacturers.

Other prevailing macro- and micro-economic policy settings present profound obstacles to further investment and militate against innovative product development strategies. A more suitable investment climate, for instance, in hand with the abolition of the capital gains tax, would create a larger pool of venture capital for investment in high technology start-up companies than has been achieved by way of the contrived, failed schemes of the past, such as the management and investment companies scheme.

It is, then, no use promoting policy initiatives in regard to technology transfer issues in the absence of an appreciation of, firstly, the general complexity of the invasion process itself and, secondly, the critical need to ensure interaction between product development strategies and the marketplace. Anyone with any exposure to small technology-intensive companies will realise their sensitivity to matters such as those I have mentioned previously.

The critical stage of their development is as they try to size up their product and/or move up the pace of production in order to seize a greater share of the market. This is the stage at which they need to access equity involvement from other manufacturers, source new capital, meet enhanced distribution costs and so forth. This can be the most vulnerable period in a firm's life and this is the point at which economy problems bear down heavily on the technology transfer process.

In other economies overseas, the mature venture capital industry provides support, both indirect financial support and other investment infrastructure-management, distribution advice and so on-or else this is the time when larger manufacturers suck up the innovation within their own product development strategies. What happens in Australia? Cash flow problems at this stage in product development often drive companies to the wall, or else overseas industries move in and capture the benefits of Australia's intellectual property. Innovation is not just about the creation of more technology with potential commercial application; it is a much longer process than this. It is a process which is profoundly determined by the nation's economic circumstances and its manufacturing capabilities.

Increasingly, then, the debate over the commercial potential of Australia's scientific and technological capabilities is focusing on the mainstream economic issues. On their own, Australia's scientists and engineers cannot bring about the wider circumstances required to build an internationally oriented, competitive, knowledge-intensive industrial future. They can provide us with the raw skills and the necessary technologies; they can make greater efforts to tailor their research to viable areas of commercial application-and I will say more on this shortly-but they cannot work the wider economic transformation necessary to restructure the economy. That is the great responsibility of government.

Notwithstanding this, if governments, by virtue of the prevailing economic circumstances, are forced to actively encourage industry-related research and development to some small degree, they must do so with considerable care. I have tried to explain in my earlier comments the complexity of the innovation process which leads to product development. In this context, I would express my concern with the direction of the generic technology grants scheme as an effective structure for capturing the commercial benefits of technological developments.

If Australia is to make a fist of commercialisation, it will need to work towards building a much more commercially oriented technological development program as well as addressing the economic concerns I have highlighted. The public research sector is coming to realise this simple truth. If the Government's intention is to encourage industrial research and development which is internationally competitive and has significant commercial application, I am curious as to how this is achievable under the current structure of the generic technology scheme. A prioritised, strategic research and development grants scheme, while admirable for its social role, tends to lack the hard-nosed commercial orientation for a scheme masquerading under an industry-related research and development program.

I mentioned earlier that the generic technology scheme was ostensibly geared to support for pre-competitive research. Yet a reading of the press releases emanating from the Department of Industry, Technology and Commerce concerning the current round of grant offers is characterised by a rhetorically strong market driven approach to assessing grant applicants. Moreover, I find that the latest inclusion of waste management in the list of priority areas has broken with the funding position of the other priority areas. It will fund projects up to 50 per cent alone. This priority area is therefore seeking to require applicants to design solid commercial linkages prior to approaching the IRDB. It is taking the direction of the discretionary grants scheme.

Is it going to be a pacesetter for the rest of the generic technologies schemes? There is good reason to suspect that there is some internal confusion within the Government's ranks as to precisely the role and function of the generic technologies grants schemes. Is it to be market-driven or technology-driven? Is it about the creation of socially useful knowledge? Or is it meant to be an instrument of industry policy and an exercise in the creation of proprietary which has commercial application?

If the generic technologies scheme is intended to function so as to provide a lead in industry development role, it should perhaps take a lead from the discretionary grants scheme and become more of a general purpose scheme. Better still, it should be absorbed within that scheme. Such a program could then send stronger signals to the research sector, both private and public, of the urgency of building up business strategies about technology development programs.

Technology development processes must integrate business principles at the earliest stages of planning if they are to succeed in the commercial world. This is a lesson which innovators and researchers seeking entry into commercial markets must learn. In order to support the development of these commercial strategies, I would envisage more effective use being made of the National Industry Extension Service. This industry extension service has in its network the means of providing small companies and innovators with sound managerial and commercial advice in respect of their innovative product developments.

It is this perspective which will drive the coalition's policy development in respect of these schemes. Generally, the coalition finds itself in the invidious position this evening of being forced to support a scheme, the existence of which demonstrates the very weaknesses which currently characterise the national economy. I would hope that the economic circumstances which make the scheme necessary are only short-lived-as short-lived, one might hope, as the life of the current Government.

—I second the amendment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: O'Keefe Mr N.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to support the Industry, Technology and Commerce Legislation Amendment Bill 1991. Until his very last observation, until the blemish of that last remark, which was very disappointing, the honourable member for Gippsland (Mr McGauran) gave a very thoughtful and considered presentation on this matter. I appreciate the spirit in which he did that. In spite of the fact that he is proposing an amendment with a view to substituting alternatives, in effect what he had to say was in support of both the legislation and the Government's position.

SPEECH.PARA: To a large extent I think we all recognise that we are embarking upon a new era where, on both sides of the Parliament, there is a general recognition that Australia has not been a mature country in respect of research and development or in its attitude towards education and all that flows from applying the intellect. Australia has been a country which has, for one reason or another, developed tremendous innovative skills. The old saying, `She'll be right, Jack', stems from the fact that no matter what the problem, in some way or other our people would come up with an answer to it.

As has been demonstrated in any number of international forums, we have been a successful country intellectually. There is a list as long as your arm of good ideas which have been thought up in Australia. What we have not been good at is taking our ideas and transforming them into commercial applications from which we could derive wealth. We have not invested further in that process of taking ideas by turning them into products that the world wants to buy. We have been one of the poorer performers by the standards of the Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development (OECD) in educating ourselves for so many years. Australia was very near the bottom of the OECD table in terms of commitment to education. The application of research funding was left totally-and I think the word `totally' is just about right-to the government sector in the form of organisations such as the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation (CSIRO), universities, and other academic institutions.

One of the very disappointing aspects was that the commercial sector and business management in Australia had no real understanding of the potential of applying investment in the field of research and development. We have had a very short term investment strategy at most. I saw an interesting series of articles published in the Australian Financial Review just before Christmas where the writer, and I forget who it was, drew the conclusion that one of the key strengths in the Japanese economy was that the industrial operations in particular were owned by management and investment companies on behalf of shareholders, which, in some ways, were similar to our own superannuation funds-investment operations which were prepared to take a long term view and make judgments about managerial performance in the long term. In Australia we have had the attitude whereby every quarter the company reports come out, the stock market responds, and people look over management's shoulders. Our management has been totally short term in its thinking, and has not been prepared to apply funding in this direction.

I remember that within the Government just two or three years ago there was quite a strong internal debate about whether we should apply more funds for public sector research, or whether we should in fact encourage further private sector research with the 150 per cent tax deduction. We have continued to maintain the 150 per cent incentive. Fortunately now there seems to be some response, but not without the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) having to take this issue to the top of his own agenda in his policy speech in March last year when he referred to the need for Australia to become the clever country. At the same time he announced a very substantial increase in government commitment to research and development funding through the centres of excellence and the rest of the program. Of course, that is extended in this legislation which is aimed more at the commercialisation of good ideas.

I said at the start of my contribution that this is virtually a `start again' position. It is true to say that apart from organisations such as the CSIRO, the universities, and some of those directed institutions in the public field, there has been very little success. It is not an accident that we quite proudly wander around the world proclaiming our farmers as the world's most efficient and advanced. When one looks at the application of CSIRO research funds over the last 20 years, one sees that the CSIRO has given a particularly strong commitment to research in the agriculture sphere. It is one of the areas where in fact we have had a continuing program of long term investment in research.

As a result of that research in agriculture there have been advances in soil and plant productivity, product development, marketing and all of those sorts of aspects. Farmers have been committed, through their marketing authorities, to the spending of money on research and development in their own industries. Yet this has not been a general practice across the economy. That is not only cause for disappointment but it is also reason for some confidence that the country is starting to wake up to itself. It is starting to demand of government that if the private sector is not prepared to do something-it should be, but if it is not-it ought to be done in joint venture with the public sector.

The honourable member for Gippsland said that there is an evolutionary stage, especially in the field of new technology and small businesses trying to develop an idea. The honourable member correctly referred to a small business, having developed an idea, having proved there is a market for the product, and perhaps even having produced working prototypes that create a demand, finding that it then faces the need for capital to expand and someone in the operation with the necessary skill to give advice on the application of the venture capital. The honourable member referred to the National Industry Extension Service as such a body for that kind of advice. I do not take issue with that.

I make the point, which I am sure the honourable member would have done if he had had time, that the Australian Industry Development Corporation (AIDC) has been one of the few banking institutions in Australia to have a progressive attitude towards investment in that kind of venture capital. A browse through the annual report of the AIDC shows considerable success in sunrise technologies, but it is nowhere near enough.

The banking sector has much to answer for on the appalling state of the commercialisation of Australian ideas. I am not indulging now in kicking the banks because of the actions of the cowboys in recent years. The honourable member for Gippsland is right when he says that in many growing businesses the necessary expertise does not exist in banking finance, market development and those sorts of activities. The expertise lies in the development of ideas and their application.

Many small businesses do not know where to go to obtain such expertise. The first place they go is down to the bank and the first person whom they talk to is generally the local bank manager. However, that person has never been trained by the banks to have any interest or expertise in encouraging equity partners and forward and broad thinking. So the very institutions which over many decades ought to have been able to take a long term view and which ought to have had a commitment to training their own advisory staff on these sorts of profitable prospects do not possess the necessary expertise.

The banking sector is now wising up to this. The banking sector now understands that the commercial lending market is pretty tight and that it can no longer go down the entrepreneurial road. So the only place it can really go for long term profitability is quality investment in quality ideas and in quality people who can carry those ideas through. So while the superannuation investment companies and the banks turn their minds more to this kind of innovation, stimulated by these kinds of activities on the part of the Government and the attraction of the 150 per cent tax deduction, there will be a broader and more enlightened approach towards these principles of returns from R and D.

TALK.START.PARA: —I can't see that at all.
—Mr McGauran interjects that he cannot see that happening.
—Order! The honourable member should ignore interjections, and he should also beware of standing order No. 80 and refer to the honourable member for Gippsland by the title of his electorate.
—I accept that interjection from you, Mr Deputy Speaker.
—`Instruction' would be a better word.

—I accept that instruction and I will adhere to it. If I respond again to the honourable member for Gippsland, I will refer to him appropriately. Having said that, I do not share his negative approach.
—Pessimism.

—Or his pessimism, about the fact that the commercial market might be waking up to this. My feedback is that it is happening now. Contrary to the popular view purveyed by the Opposition that somehow industry is looking for the free market to make all these decisions for it, I was heartened to read a recent report by the Centre for International Research on Communication and Information Technologies (CIRCIT), which showed that Australian business management is looking for direction from government and the opportunity to participate in joint venture activities with government.

SPEECH.PARA: One of the strong leads that have been shown-and it came up during Question Time today-has been the decision by the Government to use its purchasing power to inject more confidence into the Australian product and the Australian capital base and development process. I use as an example the decision taken two or three years ago to supply the Royal Australian Navy with new submarines and then subsequently with frigates and the process that the Government undertook to decide who should get the contract.

The Government told the international community that if it wanted to win a Government contract worth $4 billion or $5 billion, we would no longer be interested in buying it off the shelf as an overseas purchase, which was the practice which prevailed prior to the Hawke Government's coming into office. The Government said that it wanted the project undertaken in Australia with maximum Australian content, technology transfer and participation in the global network.

Rather than the sort of response that one might have expected, we had a tremendously positive response. Earlier during Question Time today, the Minister for Defence Science and Personnel (Mr Bilney) referred to the submarine contract, the Australian content of which is 75 per cent. We asked only for 65 per cent when we originally called for tenders for the project. However, through the process of demanding input and involvement we have seen information technology transfers and we are now participating at the strong end of the process.

That lead by the Government will continue in future contracts in fields such as telecommunications, broadcasting infrastructure and transport infrastructure. As we move into new fields of technology and performance equipment, Australia will pick up more of this base. Australia has now turned the corner.

We do have a balance of payments problem, which essentially is the washout of decades of neglect in education and research and development. However, we are now determined to be a clever country. We are now determined to ensure that an appropriate share of the national savings pool goes into investment in the future. We are now coming to grips with the fact that we are part of the international community. We are no longer a country with fences around its borders. If we are to relate to the world, we have to do so on its terms. We are determined to no longer be at the bottom of the Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development (OECD) table of comparisons on education and research and development.

Contrary to the pessimism of the honourable member for Gippsland, I think even in these quite difficult times there is a lot of scope for optimism about where these issues are going now. Business management is taking the lead. We are seeing the responses to these initiatives and the interaction between the development of ideas and the commercialisation of the product in the marketplace. In other words, we are getting smarter about it. That is a long process. We will not change that situation overnight, but we have to pound away.

I want to finish my contribution with one little bouquet, and that is for the former Minister for Science, the honourable member for Lalor (Mr Barry Jones), because I think in his last six months or so as a Minister in the previous Hawke Government he devoted an enormous amount of time and energy and did a lot of lobbying to convince the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) and senior economic Ministers that Australia did have to get serious about research and development and that, if industry was not going to do it, we had to go back to public sector leadership. As I said, the direct result of that was the announcement by the Prime Minister in his policy speech of the decision that Australia would become the clever country one way or the other, and the substantial increase in funding for research and development has come from that. I believe that the honourable member for Lalor was responsible for that turning point. In many years' time, he may look back upon his contribution to parliamentary life and decide that that was his biggest win. I give him that little bouquet by way of a passing contribution. I support the Bill before the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Nugent Mr P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —When introducing the Industry, Technology and Commerce Legislation Amendment Bill, the Government said:

SPEECH.PARA: This continuing support demonstrates to the business community the Government's determination to encourage innovation in industry as a basis for enhanced competitiveness and strength.
The Government also said:
These schemes have been under way since the mid-1980s and have contributed to a marked increase in our industry research and development.

What is indisputable is that this Bill will cost the taxpayer money. Therefore let us look at just how effective the measures which have been in effect since the mid-1980s have really been. Let us look at the history of innovation or, to use another phrase, technology take-up, in Australia. Let us look at how we compare with our overseas competitors, look at the results of the specific exercise of the Government picking winners, look at some of the real reasons that technology take-up in this country has been so bad-and there is a lot of evidence to demonstrate that it is bad-and look at what measures ought to be taken to provide meaningful encouragement to industry to assist it in innovation, enhanced competitiveness and greater strength.

If we look at the worldwide experience, we see that historically productivity growth, innovation and technology have been most important in modern times. But the world's most successful exporters show little similarity in their domestic market conditions. Some have quite low taxation regimes; some have quite high taxation regimes. Some have a small population and some have a large population. There is very little similarity in those sorts of profiles. What is needed-and it is apparent in all of them-is a management culture that intuitively looks at the domestic market as part of a potential world market.

Unfortunately, in 1989 Australia ranked twentieth out of 23 in the Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development (OECD) in terms of `outward orientation'. This was caused by protection, an anti-competitive environment and, unfortunately, many monopolies. The key problems are management attitudes and our general economic environment, which during the last eight years has been structured very substantially by the current Treasurer (Mr Keating).

Let us look at some of the lessons of the 1980s. We are faced with a long process of transformation. We start from a long way behind. We need to restructure our economy quite dramatically and we have to understand that we are a small economy on the edge of the world amidst rapid global change in trade patterns. The cost of new technology is astronomical. I have cited in this place before the case of a company called Texas Instruments which went into manufacturing personal computers and after a matter of months got out of the business having lost $180m.

Overseas countries have heavy government support for research and development, but in this country government support for research and development is actually declining. Some industries and technologies are, of course, of particular strategic importance. By this I mean, for example, the areas of design and process control. But in the last two years this Government has all but killed off many of our core industries and in the last six months we have seen many unique companies in this country go to the wall. International cooperative relationships are vital for knowledge. Unfortunately, a lack of consistency of government decision making and therefore a lack of confidence in Australian business has scared off many potential collaborators. Our market share, in Asia in particular and for technology or innovation intensive products in general, is declining.

Unlike that in other small OECD countries, Australian industry has not developed strength in specialised areas of high value added industry. The cost of export market entry places severe demands on the resources of small firms and there is a high risk factor. We have many small firms in this country. When we look at how we need to build structural competitiveness, we realise that our national system of innovation infrastructure is weak. We have few strong industry clusters and very poor networks. We have had some outstanding technical developments and successes in Australia, as the honourable member for Burke (Mr O'Keefe) mentioned, but there is a limit to how much innovation push can achieve on its own. Overall it has not worked here, so perhaps we need to look at adopting major technology more, but certainly we must keep up the funding.

The economic benefits of innovation arise from the diffusion of that innovation and new technology throughout the economy rather than isolated innovation, and that is why we should not be picking winners. There are unlikely to be high returns from publicly supported research and development unless there is a strong and dispersed demand for improved performance in general from the commercial sector. In new technology in particular, the pull from that commercial sector needs to be very strong.

We must acknowledge, of course, the changing trends around us. Quality and low costs were always important in manufacture, but now we need to add to those flexibility. In addition to that, of course, not only do we face that low cost equation but also we are looking at a shorter product cycle and we are looking not just at the economies of scale but at economies of scope. Grants or other direct government handouts are not the answer to our urgent need for innovation and technology take-up.

There is a poor history of take-up by Australian business of these critical activities. We have been dogged by short term views. We see only a domestic market, and financial institutions' short term profit need has become overwhelming. Inflation, interest rates, government regulation, lack of competition and inconsistent government policy have become almost institutionalised under the Hawke-Keating regime. We have developed a culture of speculative investment and not direct investment, and that has to change.

If we can tackle some of these problems, we will do much more good than just distributing a few million dollars in handouts under schemes such as those proposed in this Bill. A survey in 1988 showed that of 6,000 firms in Australia only 33 per cent-a third-had acquired or planned to acquire technology. That was primarily for expansion of their capacity. There was very little planning for replacement of existing equipment. Therefore, what we are building in this country is a very hard core of ageing equipment. Over 60 per cent of those companies were not investing nor planning to invest in new technology. Anecdotal evidence would suggest that that situation has got a heck of a lot worse in the last 18 months, particularly in the last six months.

If we compare ourselves with overseas, Australia has only half of the investment rate in technology of the United States of America-and we wonder why we do badly. We are significantly behind Canada, a country that in many ways is comparable to this country. We are appallingly poor versus Japan or Europe. We have that special problem of large numbers of small firms. There are many obstacles blocking our way to implementing innovation and new technology in Australia. Government handouts perpetuate many of the problems, but they do not actually fix them. For example, our problems include lack of skilled personnel and the interrelated economic difficulties that I have already mentioned. There is a lack of commitment to training from the schools sector upwards.

Entrenched organisational and management problems and attitudes are endemic in all but a few of our companies. Australia's geographical, cultural and commercial isolation from the manufacturing heartland is a problem. Canada has a big manufacturing heartland right next door in America. If it wants some support it is just a short stone's throw away. Here, we are very isolated. Those sorts of problems are not overcome by the financial drop in the bucket provided under this Bill.

Our poor industrial relations practices mean a low return on any investment in technology. We can only work it for a part of the day and we find that we still have to man up to the sorts of levels that we had before we installed the technology anyway. Our accounting techniques and investment strategies, even the way we handle the books, are all outdated. We all know the saying, `Smoking is hazardous to your health'. I suggest that there is a view held by many in the commercial community that `Australian accounting practices are hazardous to your wealth'.

Playing with numbers and shuffling bits of paper does not resolve the core problems. Australian industry is underinvesting relative to its competitors. Of course, we have some unique problems, but so do most other countries. We also have some unique advantages here.

Innovation and technology are part of a total scenario. It is that larger canvas that needs to be addressed. I am sorry to say that this Bill that we are looking at tonight is but a mere sideshow: it just does not address the substantive issues that we have troubling us in this country. I believe that the measures proposed in the Bill are but a drop in the ocean compared with what really needs to be done to stimulate the economy of Australia.

Instead of literally trying to pick winning ideas from amongst the firms asking for handouts under the grants for industry research and development scheme and various other schemes, why is the Government not providing that greater and more meaningful help? For example, we should be looking to reduce tax on the inputs going into our export industries. We should be reducing overall rates of tax for companies so that they do not have to hand away their profits and can reinvest in research and development. We should be reducing personal rates of tax to return some incentive to all Australians to work harder and to save more. TALK.START.PARA: —Recently the Leader of the Opposition (Dr Hewson) was incorrectly reported with regard to some remarks he made about the future of company tax. Notwithstanding a published correction, the Australian Labor Party went into a frenzy of accusations-most of which were erroneous-regarding the outcome of any reduction in company tax. In fact, it wanted to paint companies as being groups of people who make huge profits and therefore hurt other people.

SPEECH.PARA: I have long held the view that, with few exceptions, company tax has never been a tax upon the institution of a company, but a tax upon the consumers of the goods or services such a company provides. I have consequently always corresponded with those who urged the increase of company tax to inform them of this fact. My reasoning is based on a simple, much publicised fact which is simply that companies declare profit or dividend after tax. Because they must end up with sufficient surplus to pay dividends to their shareholders, companies simply factor income tax into their cost structure and pass it on to consumers of their goods or services.

If the company is an exporter, then the consumer, who then has a discretion as to where he buys his goods around the world, sometimes refuses to pay the resulting price, thus denying that company and Australia valuable exports and the resulting jobs-which is hardly a desirable outcome.
In last Thursday's Australian Financial Review this principle was further proved when a correspondent discussed the tax regime on fuel products. He said:
The Australian Petroleum Institute, and the Prices Surveillance Authority, State and Federal, say taxes are 39.7c a litre.
Oil companies concede that company taxes added makes the overall figure 70c in the dollar at the pump.

That clearly indicates that the oil companies see their company taxes as being passed on to consumers. However, I have now been joined in my position by the eminent economist and columnist Padraic, otherwise known as Paddy McGuinness, who has written an article entitled `This tax business is poor company' in the 30 November issue of the Australian. I would like to quote some of the things he had to say. First, he said:

Research into the incidence of taxation in Australia is not as yet highly developed. But it is a fact that the greater part of company taxes is not paid by companies at all, but by the purchasers of the goods and services produced by companies. To a greater or lesser degree, company income tax is passed on to other companies and, directly or indirectly, to consumers.
In a later part of the article he said:

Like sales taxes, tariffs and excise taxes, company taxes are therefore really taxes on consumers-and, as such, they hit the poorest members of the community hardest. To the extent that they do not, they hit small business (always facing a highly competitive market) and exporters. Why then do we insist on the levying of company taxes?
In another part he said:

But it means that it is totally senseless, in the name of hitting the rich and helping the poor, to increase rates of company tax. Moreover, such is the complexity of the company tax system and deductions for costs incurred (borrowings, depreciation on capital investments, etc) that enormous resources are devoted to minimising the total tax burdens on companies so that they do not have to share the advantages of their market power with the Tax Office.
Of course he is simply pointing out there the cost and the waste that goes with trying to avoid a tax that may be better not applied. He went to say:

So the question has to be asked, why bother to tax companies at all? If we had a comprehensive goods and services tax, together with an effective scale of personal income taxes, it is quite clear that no one would be able to avoid paying their share of taxation.
In another part of the article he said:
As Professor John Fairbairn pointed out in a paper published already last week by the Economic Planning Advisory Council-
the Government's own body-
the existing tax system produces a bias against investment in business, fixed assets and stocks, especially in inflationary circumstances.
He goes on with a lot of other remarks.

I just point out that it is time that the Parliament, the Government and the Leader of the Opposition further progressed this situation. If the Government's present imputation system were reversed, and instead of taxing companies and passing the tax benefit to shareholders, it did not tax the companies but taxed any distribution of profit made in any way, it would be the investor who got the profit-the shareholder is the profit taker, not the company, because the company only sees tax as part of its cost of production-and we would have a system where the business community could get on with developing and creating jobs and when it paid a profit, the profit would be taxed.

TALK.START.PARA: —I bring to the attention of this House the plight of the people of the southern Sudan, which has been substantially overlooked with the world preoccupied with other events. I have been shaken from my own relative ignorance on the subject by two constituents in Adelaide, Ben Yengi and Mariano Ngor, both of whom are from the Sudan and who are working to improve knowledge of the sufferings of their people.

SPEECH.PARA: Since winning independence from Britain in 1956, the Sudan has been wracked by internal conflict for all but 11 years between 1972 and 1983. This is perhaps hardly surprising in a country that is so diverse and that had been previously ruled by a colonial power that had used divide-and-conquer tactics.

The current bout of turmoil stems from the abrogation in 1983 of the Addis Ababa accords, which in 1972 had laid the basis for an uneasy truce between the north and south of the country. The north is populated predominantly by Arabs and adherents of Islam, and the south by African people who are either Christian or of more traditional faiths.

The abrogation of the 1972 accords, coupled with the imposition by the national government of Islamic law, has introduced a very difficult situation for the peoples of the southern Sudan. Non-Muslims have become virtual non-citizens and, despite their adherence to alternative faiths, have become subject to the full force of a religion-based legal system which, as we know, prescribes rather severe penalties which range from amputation for petty theft to stoning for adultery. If non-Muslims managed not to stray from the path of righteousness, they were nonetheless vulnerable to enslavement, state-sanctioned violence and persecution.

There has also been a rather ferocious crack-down on the intelligentsia in Khartoum. Its prisons appear to be full of trade unionists, politicians, doctors, lawyers and academics. Understandably, these developments have led to the development of political instability and the formation of the Sudan People's Liberation Movement (SPLM), which is not intent on seeking secession for the southern Sudan, but for a more democratic and representative form of government in Khartoum. Unfortunately, there has been extensive fighting between the Government and the SPLM since 1983.

It is true that Khartoum has waged a particularly vigorous war against the southerners, and I suppose we might expect that from a government which has been armed by Saddam Hussein and Muammar Gadaffi and which sprang to the support of Baghdad when it invaded Kuwait. Here, of course, it was in particularly bad company with the Palestine Liberation Organisation, Yemen, North Korea and eventually King Hussein of Jordan.

There have been fairly well documented cases of quite savage repression waged against the people of the southern Sudan, notably in March 1987 when the Government attempted to undermine support for the SPLM by orchestrating what appears to have been a deliberate massacre of the Dinka ethnic group by rival Arabic ethnic groups. It is reported that more than 1,000 people were murdered in the town of Dhein, situated in the central warring position between the north and the south. The Government, currently headed by Lieutenant-General Omer Hassan al Bashir, has also appeared to be resisting any efforts to provide emergency relief for those people in the southern part of the Sudan who are subject to this repression. There have been reports in the European press of bombing to disrupt the provision of emergency relief.

The substantial population disruption that has occurred as a result has led to large exoduses of people from the southern part of the Sudan to Ethiopia, Kenya, Zaire, Uganda and even elsewhere within the Sudan. It is a measure of the disaster that has been befallen these poor people that they have had to flee to areas which are also economic bread basket cases. They flee war and persecution as well as the famines which have been produced by droughts that have gone alongside these disruptions. Between 1988-89 as many as half a million people may have starved to death in a very extensive famine which, unlike that which occurred in Ethiopia a few years earlier, has not really attracted the attention of the world or of pop concerts.

I mention this issue as a tribute to my friends and constituents in Adelaide who have raised the matter with me, and I ask honourable members that they might note in the list of very sad cases, which I am afraid is very long, the cause of the people of the southern Sudan.

TALK.START.PARA: —Tonight I want to pay tribute to a fine Australian who died in Mackay about two weeks ago. I say `a fine Australian' because he had a heritage which stemmed from the Solomon Islands, being one of the group of people we call Kanakas. His heritage goes right back to the early days of the blackbirding of 1873 when his grandfather was kidnapped and brought to Australia to work in the cane lands, it being the understanding at that time that only black people were worthy to work the cane and the white man could not do it. So from that humble origin, we have a class of people who are the ex-Solomon Islanders, called Kanakas, who have greatly enriched the heritage and traditions of Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: The person to whom I am paying tribute tonight, Noel Fatnowna, whose grandfather came to Mackay in 1873, not only served the community of Mackay but also served his fellow countrymen in such a way that he was held to be one of the community leaders of Mackay. I hold here a book which was written by him, Fragments of a Lost Heritage. It goes right through the history of the blackbirding to the repatriation of these people in the late 1800s, and it then relates how some of them came back voluntarily into the same areas as their parents had worked and settled in that region. These people never regarded themselves as second-class citizens; they always regarded themselves as being products of a very fine tradition, a very fine heritage that had been built up over the hundreds of years in the Solomon Islands. Today there would be thousands of these people within the Dawson electorate itself, let alone those other cane areas that they settled in at that time.

Noel Fatnowna was indeed a fine man. In fact, he was so enriched with his own culture that in 1973, just 100 years after his grandfather had come to Australia after being blackbirded, he went back to the Solomon Islands to try to find his own roots. In actual fact, this book, Fragments of a Lost Heritage, is very similar to the book Roots, in which the American African went back to try to find his beginnings. But it is such a pity that Noel, who was struck off in life at the early age of 61, was not allowed to fulfil his dreams and be given the retirement in Mackay that he would have dreamt of, because he had in mind writing a follow-up book to Fragments of a Lost Heritage.

I wish to pay tribute to Noel Fatnowna's community service. I have mentioned that he was so interested in his culture, that he went back to the Solomon Islands in 1973. At the time of his death he was still working with the ambulance service in Mackay, with the community and within the church that he loved. It is a mark of the respect in which he was held not only by the ambulance service but also by the whole community that for his funeral service over 700 people turned up at the church; it was overfilled and people were spread out right through the hall next door. People who were there paying tribute to him were not only the community leaders who thought so much of him but also present, for instance, were the whole ambulance service, the police, the fire services and the church members with whom he was associated. All those attendant groups and individuals at his funeral paid tribute to a fine chap.

In fact, it was only about five weeks ago that Noel saw me in the company of others in a bid to try to retain the ambulance services in Queensland in the manner in which they had been operating. In other words, the Mackay region was an independent service not associated with others, and was held together by 26,000 subscribers. Incidentally, one of the reasons Noel was so well known was that he was the collector of funds so often for this service. He was trying to keep the ambulance service as it has been instead of its passing to a central authority. In respect of the work that this man did for the ambulance service, I would like to think that the Queensland Premier and also the Minister responsible would look at this issue very carefully before implementing any change.

I just wish to pay this tribute and I think it is fitting that we should do it from the Parliament House of Australia because he was a man so deeply associated with it. I would also like to pay my respects by mentioning his wife, Minnie, and pass on honourable members' sad regrets at his passing to his children and also grandchildren. He was a fine Australian; he enriched Australian culture in the manner in which he became associated with it; and I pay those respects to him.

This Irish point is a valid one because we did have His Excellency the Ambassador attend the ceremony and also Professor Patrick O'Farrell, who gave a very interesting address to all those assembled for the commemoration of the Irish uprising on that day. He pointed out some of the difficulties that were experienced in the early colony. It was particularly interesting for many of us whose ancestors were Irish. As Professor O'Farrell said on this occasion, they were really made an offer they could not in all conscience refuse-an invitation to visit Australia-in those early days.

Those ceremonies are significant for a number of reasons, but in particular tonight I refer to the fact that where the ceremony was held on Constitution Hill in Toongabbie is probably one of the highest points in the whole of the Sydney metropolitan area. It is a very steep hill and from there one gets a panoramic view of the whole of the city of Sydney, right back to the bridge and the harbour.

I mention these things because at the moment this particular land is leased from the Water Board as public recreation space. That particular lease has only a couple of years to run and there is a lot of concern in the local community that the land might be sold off and public use denied at the end of the lease the Water Board has entered into.

I think the history of the site at Constitution Hill along with Vinegar Hill in the western part of Sydney represent important landmarks in Australia's colonial history. They should be permanently retained as publicly available, publicly dedicated parkland. The land should be properly treated as the significant heritage item it is and it should be ensured that it retains its public ownership. The people of the Toongabbie-Wentworthville area can then have the opportunity to enjoy this land not only on the occasion of the ceremony they hold each year to mark this particular anniversary, but at other times as well.

I know this issue is of concern to the people who organise the Irish uprising ceremony on that day. The chairman of the committee, Peter Whiteoak; the secretary, Alderman Elaine Evans; and the many other people who turn up are determined to ensure that the New South Wales Government, as requested, takes a proper stance so that when this lease arrangement that the Water Board has over this heritage site comes up for reconsideration, the site will be made available to the people of the local community for their enjoyment.

I say in passing that these things are important because later this year Toongabbie celebrates a unique event. It is the third-oldest settlement in the original colony of New South Wales. In October, another special event to commemorate that is being held. A special weekend of activities is planned by the same committee and I think it would be a fitting gesture for the future of the site to be identified at that time.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Scholes The Hon G.G.D.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Treasurer, upon notice, on 22 August 1990:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Does the Reserve Bank receive regular reports or statements from non-bank financial institutions; if so, (a) what information is required to be included, (b) who is responsible for the provision of these returns and (c) is there a minimum size for institutions required to report.
(2) Is his Department notified of any changes in the liquidity or viability of non-bank financial institutions.

(3) Does the Reserve Bank report to his Department on matters relating to the viability of bank and non-bank operations and any other developments which could result in damage to public confidence or potentially affect the safety of depositors' funds.

(4) Does the Reserve Bank report to the Reserve Bank Board on developments affecting the bank and non-bank sectors of the finance industry; if so, is information included which relates to the operations of (a) industry sectors, (b) groups of organisations in a single group or (c) individual entities.

(5) Did the Reserve Bank receive reports or financial statements from the (a) Farrow Corporation, (b) Pyramid Building Society, (c) Geelong Building Society, (d) Country Wide Building Society, (e) Commercial Credit Union, and (f) Building Society Group (i) as individual entities or (ii) in any other combination.
(6) Did the Reserve Bank at any time express concern about the operations and financial viability of any or all of the Farrow Group of building societies.

(7) Does the Reserve Bank report to him on the state of the finance industry on a regular basis; if so, do these reports include information or comment on problems of sections of, or individual elements of, the finance industry.
(8) Are regular discussions held between Reserve Bank officers and him or his personal staff.
(9) Was the Reserve Bank aware of the possible failure of the Farrow Group of building societies; if so, when did it become aware.
(10) Was he, or his office, informed that there was a risk of the Farrow Group of building societies failing; if so, when.

(11) Did he have any discussion with, or communication from, the Victorian Government at any level about the imminent failure of the Farrow Group; if so, what was the date of the first communication or discussion.
(12) Was he advised of rumours that the Farrow Group was in trouble; if so, (a) when and (b) by whom.

(13) Were discussions held between Victorian Government officials and the Reserve Bank in January or February 1990 regarding the need for a line of credit for the Farrow Group; if so, (a) on what dates, (b) why were these discussions held and (c) who initiated them.
(14) Was an agreement reached in February to provide a line of credit to the Farrow Group; if so, was this with Reserve Bank support.
(15) If the Reserve Bank supported the provision of a line of credit, did it subsequently withdraw its support; if so, (a) when and (b) why.

(16) Was a meeting held between the Reserve Bank and the Victorian Government in late March or early April 1990; if so, (a) did he participate, (b) who represented the Reserve Bank, (c) was the Victorian Treasurer present, (d) who represented the Victorian Government and (e) did the Reserve Bank advise the Victorian Government representatives that the Farrow Group (i) could not recover or return to being a viable financial institution and (ii) should be sold in the interests of the depositors.

(17) If the advice referred to in sub-part 16(e) was given, (a) what was the basis of the advice, (b) was the Reserve Bank Board aware of the advice and the Bank's concern and (c) was he told of the advice before it was conveyed to the Victorian Government; if so, (i) when and (ii) to what level of detail.

(18) Did the Reserve Bank examine (a) the audit report by the Farrow Group auditors Day, Neilson, Jenkins and Johns, on which the Victorian Treasurer and Attorney-General made a statement of public support before becoming party to the February-March 1990 agreement on liquidity funds for the Farrow Corporation and (b) the audit statement prepared for the Farrow Corporation by Price Waterhouse before the meeting with Victorian Ministers and officials in March-April.
(19) Why did the Reserve Bank reject the findings of both the documents referred to in part (18) in its advice to the Victorian Government.

(20) Does the Reserve Bank have (a) power to intervene in the operations or management of non-bank financial institutions and (b) the ability to provide funds to non-bank State registered building societies to cover liquidity problems.

(21) Did the Farrow Corporation apply to the Reserve Bank to become a licensed bank or have discussions with the Reserve Bank on the matter; if so, was the Corporation advised that (a) its equity level was too low, (b) its accounts did not properly reflect its financial position and (c) its management arrangements were not appropriate.
(22) Has Part IV of the Financial Corporations Act 1974 been proclaimed; if not, (a) why not and (b) are there any legal or functional reasons for its not being proclaimed.
(23) Did the Farrow Group meet the requirements of the Financial Corporations Act 1974.
(24) Are depositors' funds held by licensed banks guaranteed by the Commonwealth against loss.
(25) Is there any form of deposit insurance covering bank deposits.
(26) Which forms of deposit investment are covered by a Commonwealth guarantee.

(27) Has he taken part in discussions about the state of Victorian building societies; if so, (a) on how many occasions, (b) who was involved, (c) who was responsible for briefing him and (d) was he advised that (i) the public perception of the Farrow Corporation created by its annual reports and its public relations firm, International Public Relations, was inaccurate (ii) the Farrow Corporation was in serious danger of failure and (iii) the only problems faced by the Farrow Corporation were rumours started by a bank.
(28) Did he receive any requests for a meeting or any other communication from the Farrow Corporation during 1990; if so, what was the purpose of the communication or proposed meeting.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Keating The Hon P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: 1. Part III of the Financial Corporations Act 1974 gives the Reserve Bank the power to collect statistics from corporations subject to the Act.

(a) The information collected under the Financial Corporations (Statistics) Regulations dated 18 May 1984 varies for the different categories of corporations. For building societies it includes aggregated statistics on lending and borrowing, selected liabilities, assets, interest rates and selected maturity dissection of borrowings.
(b) The Act requires that statistics prepared by corporations under Part III be verified by a statutory declaration made by a senior officer of the corporation.

(c) The Act relates to financial corporations which engage in the borrowing and lending of money in a major way and whose assets exceed $1 million. Certain classes of corporations are exempt from the legislation, including public authorities, authorised banks, terminating building societies, friendly or benefit societies, medical benefits organisations, life and general insurance companies and trustee companies.

2 &3. My Department is not informed about the liquidity or viability of financial corporations as a matter of course. There is, however, a close working relationship between the Treasury and the Reserve Bank and the Bank keeps it informed of developments relevant to the stability of the financial system. Moreover, the Secretary to the Treasury, as a member of the Reserve Bank Board, receives such information as is provided to other Board members arising from the Bank's surveillance of the financial system.

4. I am informed that the Reserve Board receives regular reports on developments affecting the bank and non-bank sectors of the finance industry, and that the information relates to the operations of industry sectors, groups of organisations in a single group and individual entities.
(d) Yes, as an individual entity but from a corporation entitled Countrywide Building Society.
(e) Yes, as an individual entity but from a corporation entitled Commercial Credit Co-operative Limited.
(f) Yes, but predominantly building societies in the Group (there are other financial intermediaries).

6. I am informed that the Reserve Bank had some discussions about the operations of the Farrow Group with the responsible State authorities. (See responses to parts 9 and 10). These discussions arose from concerns evident in sections of the market.

7. The Governor of the Reserve Bank and I regularly discuss economic and financial developments. These discussions may include problems in particular parts of the financial system if the Governor or I believe that to be appropriate.
8. The Governor and I discuss the state of the economy on a regular basis and we talk face to face or by telephone whenever particular matters warrant it.

9. The Bank has told me that it had been generally aware for some time that the Farrow Group of building societies was exposed to a higher-than-normal operating risk because of its high rate of growth, its exposures to the commercial property sector, and its interest rate policy. Such information as was available to the Reserve Bank, however, was not an adequate basis on which to make considered judgements about the societies' viability.

10, 11, 12. I did not know of the financial difficulties of the Farrow group of building societies prior to the release of a statement by the Victorian Treasurer on 13 February 1990 concerning Pyramid Building Society.

The only advice received by my office prior to 13 February 1990 was a minute dated 12 February which referred to an article on Pyramid that had appeared in the Sunday Herald on 11 February which stated that there had been small net withdrawals from the Society.
That advice could not be considered knowledge of Pyramid's difficulties. In the event the minute was not drawn to my attention as it was not considered such a serious issue at the time.
13. The Reserve Bank has informed me that it had discussions with Victorian Government officials on a number of occasions:

- on 12 and 13 February 1990-talks initiated by Victorian Office of Management and Budget in relation to its concerns about the risk of a run on Pyramid Building Society and its inquiry about the RBA's policy on liquidity support for building societies.
- On 15 and 20 February 1990-talks with Victorian Registrar of Co-operative Financial Institutions, initiated by RBA, to inquire about Farrow's efforts to arrange additional lines of support.
- On 21 February 1990-talks initiated by Victorian Office of Management and Budget to mention Farrow's liquidity difficulties and problems of securing support from banks.

14. I understand the Farrow Group had discussions with various financial institutions about possible lines of credit. The Reserve Bank has told me it was not party to any such discussions but it made known to banks and to the Victorian Government its longstanding and on-going policy of willingness to provide necessary liquidity support to banks which choose to lend to well-managed and viable non-bank financial institutions.
15. Not applicable; as indicated in the response to part 14, the Reserve Bank did not give its support to the provision of a line of credit to the Farrow Group.

16. The Reserve Bank informs me it did not meet with the Victorian Government in late March or early April 1990. There were, however, numerous discussions between various representatives of the Bank and the Victorian Government during the period from February to June 1990. These were primarily to keep the Bank informed of events as they developed; the Bank did not offer the advice mentioned in the question. I did not participate in any of the Reserve Bank's discussions.
17. Not applicable (refer to the response to part 16).

18. The Reserve Bank has informed me it did not receive a copy of an audit report by Day, Neilson, Jenkins and Johns; it did receive a copy of Price Waterhouse's summary of its review of the Farrow Corporation Limited group.
19. The question is based on an incorrect premise. The Reserve Bank did not see the first document referred to. It neither accepted nor rejected the latter.

20. The Reserve Bank does not have the power to intervene in the operations or management of non-bank financial institutions. Its long-standing policy is not to provide financial support to financial institutions it does not supervise.

21. I am informed that Farrow Corporation did not make application to become a bank. However, in January 1990, Farrow Corporation indicated to the Reserve Bank an intention to seek a banking licence in the medium term (3-5 years) if certain State legislative restrictions on its activities were not removed. The Bank offered no advice on its equity level, accounts or management arrangements. On 11 May 1990, an officer of Farrow Corporation arranged for Mr Farrow to meet with the Chief of Financial System Division of the Bank on 24 May, purportedly to discuss the possibility of a banking authority. The appointment was cancelled by Mr Farrow on 23 May.

22. No. Part IV was seen as providing reserve powers over financial corporations to be used, if necessary, for monetary policy, rather than prudential supervision, purposes. The powers were broadly equivalent to those applicable to banks covered in the Banking Act. Monetary policy no longer relies on these powers in the Banking Act but is exercised through open market operations. Recourse to Part IV of the Financial Corporations Act is not, therefore, relevant.

I would add that Part IV powers, even if involved, would be deficient for prudential supervision purposes. The Part does not contain provisions relating to the financial stability of corporations, or the protection of depositors; nor does it contain requirements for ensuring standards of financial soundness and the prudent operations of non-bank financial institutions.
24. Except for deposits with the Commonwealth Bank, depositors' funds held by authorised banks are not guaranteed by the Commonwealth against loss.
25. No. The Banking Act imposes on the Reserve Bank certain responsibilities in relation to the protection of bank depositors.

26. Apart from financial securities which the Commonwealth itself has on issue (eg Government bonds, Treasury notes), the Commonwealth does not guarantee ``forms of deposit investment''. Commonwealth guarantees do, however, apply to the liabilities and/or borrowings of some specific entities. Of these, only the Commonwealth Bank and the Australian Industry Development Corporation (AIDC) accept at call deposits from the public. Other entities whose liabilities or borrowings are underwritten to varying degrees by the Government include AUSTRADE, the Australian Wheat Board and the Australian Wool Corporation. Individual borrowings by some other statutory authorities and government owned bodies may also be guaranteed by the Commonwealth. Such borrowings could involve the issue of financial securities in which the public may invest.

27. I have regular discussions about economic and financial developments with both the Reserve Bank Governor and the Secretary to the Treasury. There have however been no particular discussions concerning the state of Victorian building societies.
28. I receive many requests for meetings during the course of a year, but there is no record of any such contact with the Farrow Corporation in 1990.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Taylor Mr W.L.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade, upon notice, on 14 November 1990:

QUESTION.PARA: Is it a fact that during Mr Mandela's recent visit to Australia a gift of $15 million from the Government to the African National Congress was announced; if so, (a) will the Government make similar donations to other South African political parties and (b) what provisos (i) were placed on the gift and (ii) will be placed on similar gifts in the future.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Blewett The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

ANSWER.PARA: No, it is not a fact.
