(a) The Australian Government has long accepted the practical reality that the ANC is foremost amongst the authentic black leadership of South Africa. We have refrained, however, from recognising the ANC as the sole and legitimate representative of the black majority as, despite the support that is obviously commanded by the ANC, other groups such as the Pan Africanist Congress (PAC) and Inkatha have a claim to represent elements of black opinion in South Africa.

Other groups have in the past benefited from Australian Government assistance under the SAPSA program and will continue to do so depending on compliance with SAPSA guidelines and the availability of funds. $2 million has already been set aside over the next three years for this purpose.

(b) (i) Provisos on the assistance fall within the existing SAPSA program guidelines, copies of which are available in the Parliamentary Library or from the Australian International Development Assistance Bureau.
(ii) Any other conditions to apply to possible future financial support for development and humanitarian activities under SAPSA would need to be determined at the time any future decision is made.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Small Business and Customs, upon notice, on 21 January 1991:

(2) Is he able to say whether the synthetic fur fabric produced by Australian manufacturers is of similar quality to that available on overseas markets.

(3) If Australian manufacturers cannot produce fabric of a similar quality to that produced overseas, can a tariff classification exemption be issued in respect of the imported fabric; if not why not.

(4) Does imported synthetic fur fabric attract a tariff rate of more than double that placed on a finished stuffed toy made of the same synthetic fur; if so, (a) why and (b) is any action being taken to correct this anomaly.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Beddall The Hon D.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) There are at least three manufacturers of synthetic fur fabric in Australia. In addition there are numerous manufacturers of knitted pile fabric which is considered a close substitute to synthetic fur fabric.
(2) I am unable to give a definitive answer as quality is a characteristic which requires subjective judgement.

(3) Tariff Concession Orders are granted where Customs is satisfied that goods serving similar functions are not produced or are not capable of being produced in Australia in the normal course of business.
Locally produced goods are considered to serve similar functions to imported goods if they compete or have the potential to compete in the market place.

It is the degree of competition, not the quality of the products, which determines whether a Tariff Concession Order is granted. The onus is on the applicant to show there is no competition with locally produced goods.

Given that there is local manufacture of competitive goods, it is unlikely that a Tariff Concession Order would be granted on these goods. QUESTION.SPEAKER: Langmore Mr J.V.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade, upon notice, on 22 January 1991:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What are the procedures and expected timing of national subscriptions to Unesco.
(2) When are subscriptions expected to be paid in each financial year.
(3) What sums did Australia pay to Unesco in 1990 and what are the payments expected to be in 1991.
(4) What sum has Australia paid so far in 1991.
(5) Is Australia in arrears; if so, by what sum.
(6) Are any of the ten largest contributors currently in arrears; if so, by what sums.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Blewett The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) UNESCO Financial Regulations require that once the General Conference has adopted the budget, the Director-General shall ask member states to remit one half of their contributions for the two-year financial period. At the end of the first calender year of the two-year financial period the Director-General asks member states to remit the other half of their contributions for the financial period. Contributions are due in full within 30 days of the receipt of the Director-General's request for payment or on the first day of the year to which they relate, whichever is the later. As of 1 January of the following year the unpaid balance of contributions is considered one year in arrears.

(3) Australia's contribution to UNESCO in 1990 was $5,451,006. Allowing for currency fluctuations and a small overpayment in 1990 (credited to the 1991 payment), a similar contribution will be made in 1991.
(4) In past years Australia has paid its contribution in January of the year in which it is due. However, for domestic budgetary reasons the 1991 contribution has been delayed until July 1991.
(5) No. See (1) above for an explanation of financial procedures. As Australia's 1991 contribution will be paid in July 1991 it will not be in arrears.

(6) Of the ten major contributors Japan (assessed contribution for 1990 US$29,280,898) and Brazil (US$3,721,928) are the only member states that have not paid their contributions for 1990 and are therefore in arrears. As at 31 August 1990, the date of the last consolidated report on the status of collection of contributions, Brazil owed US$3,142,907 in contributions due before 1990.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Woods Dr R.L.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Aged, Family and Health Services, upon notice, on 12 February 1991:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is it a fact that as a result of two New Zealand studies, Berotec, a drug used for the treatment of asthma, has been delisted from the Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme (PBS); if so, why, while his department advises that Berotec has been delisted because of its inherently dangerous properties, is it still available without prescription from both community and hospital based pharmacies if patients are prepared to pay for it themselves.
(2) Is it also a fact that Berotec has similar properties to two drugs remaining on the PBS, Ventolin and Bricanyle.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Staples The Hon P.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The drug fenoterol hydrobromide (Berotec is the brand name) was deleted from the Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme as a result of a recommendation to that effect by the Pharmaceutical Benefits Advisory Committee (PBAC).
The data which the PBAC considered prior to making its recommendation did include the results of two New Zealand studies which indicated an increase in mortality associated with the use of fenoterol.

In relation to its continued availability on the market, the Australian Drug Evaluation Committee (which makes recommendations in relation to marketing approval) did not recommend withdrawal but, instead, that use of fenoterol should be limited to patients with mild to moderate asthma. The matter of availability of drugs with or without prescription is one for State drug scheduling committees.
(2) Ventolin (salbutamol) and Bricanyl (terbutaline) have actions and uses similar to fenoterol but they have not been associated with reports of increased mortality.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Burr Mr M.A.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Aged, Family and Health Services, upon notice, on 14 February 1991:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What is the cost of the increase to pensions to compensate for the $2.50 charge resulting from the changes to the Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme.
(2) What savings have resulted from the changes to the Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Staples The Hon P.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The 1990-91 Budget provided for a reduction in outlays on the Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme (PBS) of $148.6m due to the introduction of the $2.50 pensioner charge and associated safety net arrangements, with an offsetting increase of $169.4m in Social Security pension payments. The estimated full year effect of these changes in 1991-92 was $323.2m and $291.8m respectively. These figures are published on pages 3.11 and 3.15 of Budget Paper No 1.

(2) It is not yet possible to indicate the actual savings being achieved in the PBS. As a result of the usual delays associated with submission and processing of pharmacists claims for payments under the PBS and the short term distortion in payment trends resulting from the substantial hoarding of prescription drugs by pensioners prior to the introduction of the $2.50 charge, analysis of several months of claims payment data will be required before there is a reasonable basis to review the estimated savings.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: McGauran Mr P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Administrative Services, upon notice, on 19 February 1991:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What local content requirements must be met by suppliers to the Government of (a) computer and (b) other equipment.
(2) What is the function of the (a) supplier list and (b) panel contract list with respect to preferred suppliers.

(3) With respect to the lists referred to in part (2), (a) how does a company seek entry to each, (b) what benefits accrue to those entered on each respecting Government contracts and (c) what criteria must be met to be entered on each.
(4) What procedures does the Government employ to evaluate local content levels in equipment purchases especially computer related equipment.
(5) With respect to the computer industry, what criteria must an item, or component in an item, meet in order to satisfy local content requirements.

(6) Is Kambrook a preferred supplier on any list; if so, (a) what evaluation has been carried out to assess the company's claim that its locally produced personal computer range includes between 50 and 60 per cent local content and (b) does the personal computer range meet the level of local content claimed by Kambrook.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Beddall The Hon D.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Administrative Services has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

ANSWER.PARA: 1 (a) &(b) The Australian and New Zealand (ANZ) supplies policy aims to maximise opportunities for ANZ suppliers to compete for Commonwealth business on the basis of value for money. The policy is explained in Commonwealth Procurement Guideline No. 12. Amongst other things, the ANZ supplies policy encourages Commonwealth buyers to consider the advantages which ANZ suppliers can offer over their offshore counterparts. The policy does not, however, automatically reward suppliers because their products are of ANZ origin, nor does it discriminate on the basis of ownership of a supplier. Under the current policy, there are therefore no local content requirements which must be met by suppliers to the Government.

Contracts for purchases for which Requests for Tender were issued before 1 November 1989, however, continue to finality in accordance with the previous policy, which gave a margin of preference to ANZ content. In contracts established under that policy, contractors are obliged by contract conditions to maintain at least the levels claimed in their tenders for the life of the contract.
(2) (a) A `supplier list' is a register of known suppliers of goods and services. Its function is to provide buyers with information about suppliers of goods and services which they buy regularly.

(2) (b) A `panel contract list' is a list of suppliers selected to supply certain goods and/or services to the Commonwealth. Its function is to provide buyers with a list of suppliers that have been selected to supply certain goods and/or services to the Commonwealth at agreed prices and conditions.
3 (a) (i) Suppliers may apply to buying agencies to be included in any registers of suppliers which the agencies may maintain.

3 (a) (ii) A supplier must offer its goods and/or services in response to a Request for Offer or similar. If the goods and/or services are determined (see response to 3 (c) (ii)) to provide value-for-money options for the Commonwealth, the supplier is included in the panel.

3 (b) The main benefit to common use `panel contract' suppliers is direct access to Commonwealth agencies and other approved users on the basis that their goods and/or services have been evaluated as offering value for money. They are thus generally able to avoid further detailed and complex technical evaluations. In addition, each agency subject to the Audit Act and Finance Regulations is required to use `common use contracts' arranged or approved by the Department of Administrative Services where they meet the agency's needs. Other benefits include free marketing to Commonwealth agencies through the Period Contract Awareness Service (PCAS), and the distinction of having been awarded a Government contract.

3 (c) (ii) To be selected on a `panel contract' a supplier must satisfy the requirements of the Commonwealth and demonstrate that the goods and/or services offered are value-for-money options for the Commonwealth. The evaluation methodology and evaluation criteria used to assess value for money vary for each list but should be published at the time offers are sought.
4 Under the previous policy, local content was calculated, on a `build-down' basis, by deducting from the total net tender price:
(a) the value of imported components and materials from third countries (i.e. not from Australia or New Zealand);
(b) selling, distribution and installation expenses; and
Despite this approach, some reliance on `build-up' analysis remained unavoidable when ANZ content claims needed verifying.

There are several large contracts for computer equipment which have not yet expired and to which these procedures still apply. For example, a comprehensive audit of small computer systems supplied under a number of Commonwealth contracts (including PE40, the `common-use panel contract' for the supply of small computing systems) is presently being undertaken.

6 As Kambrook is a supplier under PE40, the local content of Kambrook's personal computer range is presently being audited. However, the audit is incomplete at this time and it would be inappropriate to pre-empt its outcome. Kambrook has not claimed 50 to 60 per cent local content for its personal computer products.
